Full_citation: Scheuerell, M., Moore, J., Schindler, D., & Harvey, C. (2007). Varying effects of anadromous sockeye salmon on the trophic ecology of two species of resident salmonids in southwest Alaska. Freshwater Biology, 52(10), 1944-1956.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Determining bionenergetics input of sockeye salmon to rainbow trout and arctic grayling in Bristol Bay, AK.
Essential_notes: -Benefit 16-20 describe the 4 key results from this paper; direct consumption is more important for rainbow trout, indirect consumption is more important for Arctic grayling
Benefit_1:
ESB: Rainbow trout
ESP: salmon eggs, flesh, carcasses --> blowflies
Sentence describing benefit: "Ration size and energy intake increased by 480–620% for both species after salmon arrived...[R]ainbow trout switched to consuming salmon eggs, salmon flesh and blowflies that colonized salmon carcasses" (1944)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Arctic grayling
ESP: redd construction --> benthic invertebrates
Sentence describing benefit: "Ration size and energy intake increased by 480–620% for both species after salmon arrived...[G]rayling primarily ate more benthic invertebrates that were presumably made available because of physical disturbances by spawning salmon." (1944)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Periphyton, macroinvertebrates, fish
ESP: Anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Because adult salmon gain >95% of their biomass at sea, the nutrients and carbon transported upstream in adults represent substantial subsidies that contribute to the production of periphyton, macroinvertebrates and fish (e.g. Kline et al., 1990; Bilby et al., 1998; Wipfli, Hudson & Caouette, 1998; Chaloner & Wipfli, 2002; Wipfli et al., 2003; Mitchell & Lamberti, 2005)." (1945)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Terrestrial wildlife
ESP: Salmon eggs and carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Terrestrial wildlife, such as birds, mammals and insects also consume salmon eggs and carcasses (Cederholm et al., 1989; Willson, Gende & Marson, 1998; Gende et al., 2002)." (1945)
Benefit_5:
ESB: Riparian vegetation
ESP: salmon carcasses --> bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Largely through the action of bears (Ursus arctos Linnaeus, U. americanus Pallas), salmon carcasses are transported into riparian areas where their nutrients ultimately make their way into vegetation (Ben-David, Hanley & Schell, 1998; Hilderbrand et al., 1999; Helfield & Naiman, 2006). " (1945)
Benefit_6:
ESB: marine mammals and fish
ESP: smolts
Sentence describing benefit: "Juvenile salmon (smolts) rearing in fresh water also transport nutrients back to the sea (Moore & Schindler, 2004; Scheuerell et al., 2005) and provide food subsidies to marine mammals and fish upon their entry into the estuary and ocean (Wood et al., 1993; Orr et al., 2004). " (1945)
Benefit_7:
ESB: Freshwater ecosystems, fish species
ESP: Spawning adult salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Some studies have shown that salmon can account for 30–75% of the nitrogen source in freshwater ecosystems (Naiman et al., 2002). Fish such as sculpin (Cottus spp.), char (Salvelinus spp.) and trout (Oncorhynchus spp.), that reside in streams used by spawning adult salmon, often have high stable isotope ratios indicating the accumulation of marine-derived nutrients (Kline et al., 1990, 1993; Chaloner et al., 2002)." (1945)
Benefit_8:
ESB: Juvenile salmonids
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "the experimental addition of carcasses has shown seasonal increases in the growth rates of juvenile salmonids (Wipfli et al., 2003)." (1945)
Benefit_9:
ESB: Rainbow trout
ESP: salmon eggs, flesh, blowflies
Sentence describing benefit: "After the arrival of salmon, rainbow trout diets shifted to consist primarily of salmon eggs (64%), larval blowflies (Diptera: Calliphoridae) (11%) and salmon flesh (9%)." (1948)
Benefit_10:
ESB: Grayling and rainbow trout
ESP: Arrival of sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Following the arrival of salmon on their freshwater spawning grounds, the diets of resident grayling and rainbow trout shifted to include direct salmon resources and indirect subsidies, significantly increasing the total mass and energy content of their food intake over a few weeks." (1950)
Benefit_11:
ESB: Rainbow trout and grayling
ESP: Eggs and blowflies
Sentence describing benefit: "These salmon-derived resources represented not only an increase in food quantity, but also an increase in food quality because of the relatively high energy densities of salmon eggs and larval blowflies that feed on salmon carcasses (Table 1)." (1950)
Benefit_12:
ESB: juvenile coho and steelhead
ESP: coho salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Bilby et al. (1998) demonstrated that the additions of coho salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch Walbaum) carcasses to small streams in southwestern Washington led to increased density and body condition of juvenile coho and steelhead (O. mykiss), and that eggs and salmon flesh dominated the diets of those fish during the 1 month they were available. " (1950)
Benefit_13:
ESB: juvenile cutthroat trout
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Following the addition of salmon carcasses to small experimental stream channels in southeast Alaska, Wipfli et al. (2003) found significant increases in the growth rates of juvenile cutthroat trout (Oncorhynchus clarkii Richardson) and Dolly Varden (Salvelinus malma Walbaum)" (1951)
Benefit_14:
ESB: Juvenile rainbow and cutthroat trout
ESP: Chinook carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Recently, Wilzbach et al. (2005) found that additions of chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha Walbaum) carcasses had some positive effect on the growth rates of young rainbow and cutthroat trout, but only in stream reaches where the riparian vegetation had been cut." (1951)
Benefit_15:
ESB: Freshwater ecosystems
ESP: Spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "This is very important because salmon are more than simple bags of nutrients, but rather serve as ecosystem engineers via the large disturbance of sediments and benthic invertebrates (Moore et al., 2004; Moore, 2006) while altering the foraging behaviour of stream fish (M.D. Scheuerell, J.W. Moore, D.E. Schindler, pers. obs)" (1951)
Benefit_16:
ESB: stream-resident fish
ESP: salmon eggs and carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "stream-resident fish directly consume the eggs and carcasses of salmon" (1951)
Benefit_17:
ESB: benthic macroinvertebrates
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Secondly, a wide variety of benthic macroinvertebrates, including mayflies (Ephemeroptera), stoneflies (Plecoptera), caddisflies (Tricoptera) and true flies (Diptera), colonize carcasses within the stream and feed off of them directly (Wipfli et al., 1998; Reimchen et al., 2003; Winder et al., 2005)." (1951)
Benefit_18:
ESB: fish
ESP: salmon carcasses, blowflies
Sentence describing benefit: "terrestrial blowflies (Diptera: Calliphoridae) will lay their eggs on carcasses stranded on gravel bars or the shoreline, with an average of 35 000 larval blowflies per sockeye salmon carcass typically devouring it within a week (Meehan, Seminet-Reneau & Quinn, 2005). Some of those larval blowflies are then washed into the streams and rivers because of floods or disturbance by bears, where they serve as food resources for fish (Cederholm et al., 1989; Meehan et al., 2005)." (1951)
Benefit_19:
ESB: benthic invertebrates, fish
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Thirdly, nutrients from decomposing carcasses can increase stream primary productivity, subsequently leading to a greater biomass of the benthic invertebrates that fish feed upon (Wipfli et al., 1998; Minakawa & Gara, 1999; Chaloner & Wipfli, 2002). " (1951)
Benefit_20:
ESB: Fish
ESP: Stream disturbance by spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Fourthly, nest-digging by adult salmon dislodges benthic invertebrates that are subsequently consumed by fish (Peterson & Foote, 2000)." (1951)

Full_citation: Chaloner, D., Lamberti, G., Merritt, R., Mitchell, N., Ostrom, P., & Wipfli, M. (2004). Variation in responses to spawning Pacific salmon among three south-eastern Alaska streams. Freshwater Biology, 49(5), 587-599.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Determining effect of spawning salmon on streamwater chemistry and benthic biota in 3 streams in southeastern AK.
Location: Fish Creek (58°19′N, 134°35′W), Peterson Creek (58°28′N, 134°44′W) and Salmon Creek (58°19′N, 134°27′W), near Juneau, south-eastern Alaska
Essential_notes: -Authors found inter-stream variation such that they argue the following: "Global assumptions about influence of salmon spawners on streams (e.g. the ‘MDN-productivity paradigm’) cannot be made." (596)
Benefit_1:
ESB: Benthic producers and consumers
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon spawners in general, and salmon tissue specifically, can increase the abundance or biomass of benthic producers and consumers (e.g. Wipfli et al., 1999; Chaloner & Wipfli, 2002) and increase dissolved ammonium and phosphorus concentrations (e.g. Bilby, Fransen & Bisson, 1996; Minakawa & Gara, 1999)." (588)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Aquatic organisms
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Furthermore, stable isotope studies show that salmon can be an important source of nitrogen and carbon for aquatic organisms (e.g. Bilby et al., 1996; Chaloner et al., 2002)." (588)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Streamwater chemistry
ESP: Spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Ammonium and SRP [soluble reactive phosphorus] concentrations were significantly higher in stream reaches containing salmon spawners than in reaches lacking spawners (P < 0.002; Fig. 3)" (592)
Benefit_4:
ESB: stream productivity
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Epilithic chlorophyll a and AFDM [ash-free dry mass] were both significantly higher in stream reaches containing salmon spawners (P < 0.01; Fig. 4)" (592)
Benefit_5:
ESB: chironomids (macroinvert species)
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Of the individual taxa analysed, only the biomass of chironomids was significantly higher in stream reaches containing salmon spawners (P < 0.001; Fig. 5b)." (592)
Benefit_6:
ESB: chironomids
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In previous studies, chironomids responded positively to the addition to streams of organic and inorganic material (e.g. Warren et al., 1964; Mundie et al., 1991) including salmon carcasses (e.g. Wipfli et al., 1999)." (594)
Benefit_7:
ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:
Benefit_8:
ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:

Full_citation: Lessard, J., Merritt, R., & Cummins, K. (2003). Spring growth of caddisflies (Limnephilidae : Trichoptera) in response to marine-derived nutrients and food type in a Southeast Alaskan stream. Annales De Limnologie, 39(1), 3-14.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Determining effect of salmon presence and food source on growth of caddisflies (shredders and scrapers) in Harris River on Prince of Wales Island, Southeast Alaska.
Essential_notes: -Authors found no influence of marine-derived nutrients (MDN) on the caddisflies over the 40 experimental period.

Full_citation: Lewis, D., Dundas, S., Kling, D., Lew, D., & Hacker, S. (2019). The non-market benefits of early and partial gains in managing threatened salmon. PloS One, 14(8), E0220260.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Preference choice experiment to determine benefit of partial gains (i.e. not full recovery) for coho populations along the Oregon Coast.
Essential_notes: -Authors call these non-use, non-market values, but survey only asked for WTP not why.
Benefit_1:
ESB: College graduates
ESP: increased coho returns
Sentence describing benefit: " In particular, college graduates are WTP approximately $31/y more per 100,000 returning fish than those without a college degree. " (9)
Benefit_2:
ESB: PNW residents
ESP: increasing coho populations
Sentence describing benefit: "We find that benefits to the population of Pacific Northwest residents are as much as $518 million/y for an extra 100,000 returning salmon and as much as $277 million/y for quick vs. slow increases in returning fish." (10)
Benefit_3:
ESB: PNW residents
ESP: coho conservation
Sentence describing benefit: "We find that the average household WTP for the most ambitious recovery program-one that involves OC Coho salmon reaching recovered status under the ESA-is $179/y. ... Given that the most ambitious recovery program in our experimental design is based on the OC Coho Conservation Plan for the State of Oregon [10], the population benefit estimates represent the non-market economic value associated with successfully implementing this state-level conservation plan." (11)
Benefit_4:
ESB: public
ESP: habitat restoration
Sentence describing benefit: "Importantly, we also find that the public has significant WTP for habitat restoration programs that generate much smaller changes in salmon abundance, even for programs that do not result in the stock becoming de-listed from the ESA." (11)
Benefit_5:
ESB: public
ESP: rapid salmon returns
Sentence describing benefit: "A second important and novel finding from this study is clear quantitative evidence that the public prefers receiving non-market benefits from OC Coho salmon sooner rather than later. Holding other conservation attributes constant, the average household WTP for a quick rate of increase in salmon returns is up to $34/y (Fig 3 ), contingent on the levels of the other program attributes." (11)

Full_citation: Gillespie, N., Epstein, J., Alexander, S., Bowker, J., Medel, R., Leonard, M., & Thoms, A. (2018). Socioeconomic Benefits of Recreational, Commercial, and Subsistence Fishing Associated with National Forests. Fisheries (Bethesda), 43(9), 432-439.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: This paper is the US Forestry Service's perspective on the benefits of fishing (commercial, recreational, and subsistence) in National Forests.
Essential_notes: -Somewhat vague on benefits; this is a review/propaganda piece for USFS
Benefit_1:
ESB: Fisheries
ESP: National Forest
Sentence describing benefit: "National forests in the Pacific Northwest and the western USA, particularly Alaska, support significant commercial and subsistence salmon fisheries." (433)
Benefit_2:
ESB: recreational fisheries
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " In southeast Alaska, world-class ocean, estuarine, and freshwater fisheries support a destination sportfishing and charter industry, where two of every three harvested fish are salmon. The salmon fishery supported an estimated total of $358.7 million in southeast Alaska sportfishing revenues during 2007 (TWC Economics 2010)." (435)
Benefit_3:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: Tongass Forest
Sentence describing benefit: "The Tongass National Forest is charged with the protection, maintenance, and restoration (as needed) of the 25,370 km (15,764 mi) of streams and rivers supporting and producing wild salmon, as well as 83,770 ha (207,000 acres) of lakes and ponds...Figure 5 illustrates that of 11 State Commercial Salmon Harvest Management Areas, southeast Alaska produced nearly 34% of Alaska's total harvest (60.1 of 177.9 million salmon) on average from 1994 to 2015, worth an annual ex-vessel value (paid to the fishers) of $108.9 million from 2010 to 2014 (NPAFC 2016)." (435)
Benefit_4:
ESB: commercial fishers
ESP: Tongass National Forest
Sentence describing benefit: "For the period 1994–2015, this national forest produced on average about 49 million wild salmon annually, with an average direct value of $100 million paid to fishers (ex-vessel) between 2010 and 2014." (436)
Benefit_5:
ESB: Commercial fishers
ESP: Commercial fisheries via Tongass
Sentence describing benefit: "As for indirect outputs associated with salmon in Southeast Alaska, the commercial salmon fishery supports 1 in 10 jobs (totaling over 4,500), both in direct fishing and in the processing of salmon (TWC Economics 2010)." (436)
Benefit_6:
ESB: USFS
ESP: Jamestown S'Klallam
Sentence describing benefit: "Two recipients of the USFS 2016 National Rise to the Future Awards given for outstanding leadership in fisheries and watershed programs reflect the integrated planning and significant ecological and cultural accomplishments achieved through relationships and partnerships with two separate tribal governments: the Confederated Tribes of the Warm Springs Reservation in Oregon (see Case Study) and the Jamestown S’Klallam Tribe in Washington to implement recovery action plans for steelhead Oncorhynchus mykiss, Bull Trout Salvelinus confluentus, and spring Chinook Salmon O. tshawytscha." (436)
Benefit_7:
ESB: Tribes
ESP: Tongass
Sentence describing benefit: "Subsistence use by Native communities and Rural Alaskans represents a culturally invaluable amenity and way of life: (A) Sockeye Salmon Oncorhynchus nerka population monitoring at Sitkoh Lake (photo credit: W. Owen); and (B) Angoon residents Roger Williams, Sr. and Roger Williams, Jr. seining Sockeye Salmon for a population study at Sitkoh Lake to inform subsistence harvest on the Tongass National Forest. Photo credit: D. Martin." (437)
Benefit_8:
ESB: Alaskan tribes and rural communities
ESP: wild salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "This dependence on wild resources, including salmon, finfish, and shellfish, is cultural, social, and economic." (436)
Benefit_9:
ESB: Alaskan tribes and rural communities
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "For both users, subsistence fishing provides an important protein source with high substitute values, incalculable cultural importance, and a link to a way of life that has vanished in most of the continental United States. The state's rural residents harvest about 19,958 metric tons (22,000 tons) of wild foods each year—an average of 170 kg (375 lb) per person. Fish make up about 60% of this harvest statewide (ADFG 2000). Nowhere else in the United States is there such a heavy reliance upon wild foods." (437)
Benefit_10:
ESB: Tribes
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The Tribes’ Fisheries Program Mission is deeply embedded as part of their cultural heritage: “to provide fisheries populations at harvestable levels, allowing opportunities for tribal members to exercise their treaty rights of harvest using information gained from research, management and habitat programs within the Natural Resources branch.”" (435)

Full_citation: Rüegg, J., Chaloner, D., Levi, P., Tank, J., Tiegs, S., & Lamberti, G. (2012). Environmental variability and the ecological effects of spawning Pacific salmon on stream biofilm. Freshwater Biology, 57(1), 129-142.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors measure environmental parameters of streams (esp. related to chlorophyll aka biofilm) for 7 AK streams over 3 years, both before and during the salmon run.
Essential_notes: -Authors found predictability and generalizability to be low across years and streams.
Benefit_1:
ESB: Stream organisms
ESP: Spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Adult salmon spawners deliver marine-derived nutrients and energy, which can increase the abundance, biomass or production of stream organisms (Chaloner et al., 2004, 2007)." (130)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Biofilm
ESP: MDN from salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Biofilm, the assemblage of algae, bacteria, and fungi growing on submerged surfaces, can respond positively to salmon-derived nutrient enrichment (Mitchell & Lamberti, 2005; Rüegg et al., 2011) and negatively from salmon scour (Moore et al., 2004; Tiegs et al., 2009)." (130)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Biofilm chl a
ESP: adult salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Biofilm chl a was significantly affected by salmon presence (rmanova, P = 0.001) and study year (P < 0.001), but not by stream identity (P = 0.214) (Table 1). " (134)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Autotrophic index of biofilm
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "However, salmon effects were evident in certain streams and years (P < 0.05 for interactions). For example, MAY and TWE showed large increases in the AI with salmon arrival compared with other streams (Fig. 4e)" (136)
Benefit_5:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We found that biofilm biomass increased with the presence of spawning salmon, but the magnitude varied markedly among streams and years" (137)
Benefit_6:
ESB: stram heterogeneity
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The arrival of salmon increased biofilm variability and such changes, while inconsistent among streams, were usually higher for chl a and the AI than for AFDM, again emphasising the influence of chl a on the AI." (137)
Benefit_7:
ESB: downstream ecosystem
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "However, salmon bioturbation can redistribute nutrients to downstream areas, such as lakes (Moore et al., 2007), thus creating localised nutrient fluxes. " (139)
Benefit_8:
ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:

Full_citation: Tiegs, S., Levi, P., Rüegg, J., Chaloner, D., Tank, J., & Lamberti, G. (2011). Ecological Effects of Live Salmon Exceed Those of Carcasses During an Annual Spawning Migration. Ecosystems (New York), 14(4), 598-614.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors augment stream's ability to retain salmon carcasses and then measure stream chemistry over a 5-month period, including a spawning run, in southeast AK.
Essential_notes: -Authors found adult salmon to be more influential on stream nutrient concentrations and biofilm than salmon carcasses, which they think is because salmon lose a lot of their 'meat' before becoming carcasses.
Benefit_1:
ESB: Stream nutrients
ESP: live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Concentrations of dissolved and particulate N and P followed distinctly unimodal patterns through time, which tracked the abundance of live salmon, and we observed strong predictive relationships between live-salmon abundance and streamwater-nutrient concentrations" (598)
Benefit_2:
ESB: microbial autotrophs and heterotrophs
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "the spawning migrations of diverse anadromous fishes including salmon, herring, eel, alewife, eulachon, and shark transfer marine-derived nutrients into freshwater ecosystems (for example, Post and Walters 2009; MacAvoy and others 2009; Tiegs and others 2009; Flecker and others 2010). During migrations, these fish excrete compounds that contain nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P), which are assimilated by microbial autotrophs and heterotrophs and are believed by researchers to have positive bottom-up effects on the productivity of aquatic and riparian food webs (for example, Gende and Quinn 2006)." (599)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Stream biofilm community
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "a substantial proportion of marine-derived nutrients that initially enters the stream channel early in the migration is released as gametes and excreted as metabolic wastes before the death of the salmon. These excreted nutrients are in a mineral form that is immediately available for uptake by members of the stream biofilm community whereas nutrients bound in carcasses must be mineralized before being readily assimilated" (600)
Benefit_4:
ESB: streamwater nutrient levels
ESP: live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Clear increases in dissolved and particulate nutrients [NH4+, N03-, and SRP] coincided with the onset of salmon migration, and continued until the time when live- salmon abundance began to decline" (605)
Benefit_5:
ESB: stream nutrient levels
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "however, following the onset of carcass accumulation, dissolved nutrients tended to be slightly greater in the carcass-retention reach relative to the reference reach (Figure 3)" (605)
Benefit_6:
ESB: nutrient flux
ESP: live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Nutrient fluxes peaked at the end of August, near the date of maximum live-salmon abundance" (607)
Benefit_7:
ESB: Autotrophs and heterotrophs
ESP: live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Before the salmon run, autotrophs and heterotrophs of NDS Were co-limited by N and P in both reaches, as evidenced by significant increases in chLz and respiration when N and P were amended together. Responses to treatments with N or P alone were of a relatively minor magnitude, but statistically significant (Appendices 2 and 3 in Supplementary material). During the salmon run when both live salmon and carcasses were present, autotrophs were no longer nutrient limited" (608)
Benefit_8:
ESB: Biofilm
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Biofilm biomass increased with the onset of the salmon run on the relatively large rocks that we sampled. Chlorophyll a and AFDM both reached a maximum on August 14, before declining to approximately pre-salmon run values by late September" (608)
Benefit_9:
ESB: nutrient levels
ESP: excretion by live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The increases in NH4+ and SRP concentrations can be directly attributed to salmon excretion, or in the case of NO з~, excretion of NH4+ followed by nitrification (Levi and others unpublished data)" (610)
Benefit_10:
ESB: particulate nutrient concentrations
ESP: salmon disturbance
Sentence describing benefit: "Increases in concentrations of particulate nutrients observed in our study can be best explained by benthic biofilm and associated particulates that become dislodged and entrained during salmon migration and nest construction" (610)
Benefit_11:
ESB: freshwater organisms
ESP: pink salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Based on Gende and others (2004), this approach indicates that from the time a typical male pink salmon begins upstream migration to the time of senescent death it excretes 13.6 g of N and 1.5 g of P" (610)
Benefit_12:
ESB: stream chemistry
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, carcasses deposited on riparian soils during high discharge can provide nutrients to streams following the completion of the salmon run (Fellman and others 2008), and may have carry-over effects into subsequent summers (Verspoor and others 2010)." (612)
Benefit_13:
ESB: estuaries
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit:"Salmon nutrients, in the form of carcasses and dissolved nutrients, can also spiral into the estuaries of salmon streams and enrich those ecosystems (Cak and others 2008)." (612)
Benefit_14:
ESB: terrestrial and aquatic animals
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Finally,, numerous terrestrial and aquatic vertebrate and invertebrate species feed on carcasses, which can constitute a large fraction of their caloric intake (Cederholm and others 1999; Adams and others 2010)" (612)

Full_citation: Schmitz, O., Hawlena, D., & Trussell, G. (2010). Predator control of ecosystem nutrient dynamics. Ecology Letters, 13(10), 1199-1209.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors review relationship between predators and nutrient dynamics in ecosystems.
Essential_notes: NA
Benefit_1:
ESB: bear and ecosystem
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "mean redistribution rates of salmon-derived N by adult female brown bears were 37.2 ± 2.9 kg year−1 per bear (range 23.1–56.3), of which 96% (35.7 ± 2.7 kg year−1 per bear) was excreted in urine, 3% (1.1 ± 0.1 kg year−1 per bear) was egested in faeces and < 1% (0.3 ± 0.1 kg year−1 per bear) was retained in the body." (1203)
Benefit_2:
ESB: spruce trees
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "This level of nutrient input may seem small but 15.5–17.8% of the total N in spruce foliage within 500 m of the stream was derived from salmon in this highly nutrient-limited system (Hilderbrand et al. 1999)." (1203)
Benefit_3:
ESB: forestry services
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon feeding by bears also elevates total inorganic N pools (NH4+ + NO3−) threefold, and gaseous N2O flux by 32-fold compared to riparian areas with lower bear activity (Holtgrieve et al. 2009). This level of nitrogen input provides on average c. 2.2 g N m−2 to the riparian zone and constitutes up to 24% of the total riparian N budget (Helfield & Naiman 2006), a level that approaches fertilization inputs needed to sustain silvicultural activities in the same kind of forest ecosystem (Quinn et al. 2009)." (1203)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Bristol Bay riparian zones
ESP: sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "A large run of 20 million sockeye to the Bristol Bay region of Alaska (Gende et al. 2002) can deliver as much as 5.4 × 107 kg of body tissue for the slow-cycle pathway upon death after spawning, yielding 2.4 × 105 kg of P, 18 × 106 kg of N and 2.7 × 106 kg of Ca, plus other macroelements to riparian zones. This nutrient delivery is equivalent to the amount of fertilizer used to support 56 000 ha of intensive corn production in the US Midwest." (1204)
Benefit_5:

Full_citation: Swain, N., Hocking, M., Harding, J., & Reynolds, J. (2014). Effects of salmon on the diet and condition of stream-resident sculpins (vol 71, pg 521, 2014). Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences, 71(7), 1121.
Journal: Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors study the how salmon presence affects sculpin diet.
Essential_notes: -all about effect of salmon on diet (aka one ecosystem service)

ESB: Sculpin
ESP: spawning salmon --> salmon eggs

ESB: freshwater consumers

They may also support consumers by affecting primary production and the longer term recycling of limiting nutrients such as nitrogen in stream food webs (Wipfli et al. 1998; Verspoor et al. 2010, 2011)." (521)

Full_citation: Walsh, J., Pendray, J., Godwin, S., Artelle, K., Kindsvater, H., Field, R., . . . Reynolds, J. (2020). Relationships between Pacific salmon and aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems: Implications for ecosystem‐based management. Ecology (Durham), 101(9), E03060-N/a.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors review papers on the relationship between Pacific salmon density or abundance on a variety of environmental variables (species abundance, species diversity, food provisioning, individual growth, concentration of marine-derived isotopes, nutrient enhancement, phenology, etc).
Type_of_salmon: Chum, chinook, sockeye, pink, coho, masu
Essential_notes: -Authors described #s of different relationships rather than providing specifics of the relationship, so I dug into Supplementary data S2, which had specifics about positive, negative, and null relationships taken from the literature. The positive ones I included, paraphrasing where indicated.
Benefit_1:
ESB: Fisheries, species
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Six species of Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) support valuable commercial, recreational, and Indigenous fisheries (Criddle and Shimizu 2014, Amberson et al. 2016), while also providing an important source of food and nutrients for many species in the marine, freshwater, and terrestrial realms (Helfield and Naiman 2001, Quinn et al. 2003, Williams et al. 2011, Field and Reynolds 2013)." (2)
Benefit_2:
ESB: salmon consumers
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The influx of salmon can lead to direct or indirect effects via several mechanisms, including (1) nutrient subsidies to species that directly consume wild salmon or their carcasses, (2) fertilization through excretion or decomposition, with indirect ecological effects at higher trophic levels, and (3) disturbance or bioturbation of sediment during spawning (Gende et al. 2002, Janetski et al. 2009, Moore and Schindler 2010, Hocking and Reynolds 2011)." (2)

Full_citation: Morris, A., Stark, J., & Gilbert, B. (2005). Evaluation of isotopic fractionation error on calculations of marine-derived nitrogen in terrestrial ecosystems. Canadian Journal of Forest Research, 35(7), 1604-1616.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors propose a new approach for estimating d15N and tracing transfer of MDN through salmon, bears, and ecosystems.
Location: Koeye River and Glendale River, British Columbia, Canada
Essential_notes: -Paper is more a comparison of approaches, focused on the transfer of nutrients along the following pathway: pink salmon flesh --> bear feces --> soil --> plants (salmonberry, false lily, salal, bunchberry).
Benefit_1:
ESB: Riparian plants
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Recent studies have found elevated δ^sup 15^N in plants near salmon spawning streams compared to levels at locations either where salmon did not spawn (Ben-David et al. 1998a, 1998b; Mathewson et al. 2003; Reimchen 2003) or that were far from spawning streams (Hilderbrand et al. 1999a)." (1605); Mechanism: "Considering the large number of intermediate steps involved in N transfer from salmon through bears and soil and into terrestrial plants, there would seem to be a high potential for isotopic fractionation during N transfer. " (1605)

Full_citation: Helfield, J., & Naiman, R. (2006). Keystone Interactions: Salmon and Bear in Riparian Forests of Alaska. Ecosystems (New York), 9(2), 167-180.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors analyze nutrient (nitrogen) flux in a riparian ecosystem, specifically looking at contributions of salmon and bears vs. other contributors.
Essential_notes: -This paper keeps popping up (will need to include): On the Olympic Peninsula of Washington, where brown bear are absent and black bear (U. americanus) are relatively scarce, Cederholm and others (1989) list 22 species of mammals and birds known to consume salmon carcasses." (169)
Benefit_1:
ESB: Vertebrate predators and scavengers
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon have been described as keystone species in coastal ecosystems because of their importance as a food resource for vertebrate predators and scavengers (Willson and Halupka 1995; Willson and others 1998)." (168)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Alaskan forest ecosystems
ESP: Bear via salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Similarly, salmon and bear have been described as interacting mobile link organisms because of their role in transporting marine-derived nutrients to forest ecosystems in Alaska (Lundberg and Moberg 2003)." (168)
Benefit_3:
ESB: mammal and bird species, periphyton, aquatic macros, stream-resident fish, juvenile salmon
ESP: spawning salmon, salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Having spent most of their lives feeding and growing at sea, Pacific salmon returning to spawn and die in their natal streams carry marine-derived nutrients in their body tissues. Returning salmon are eaten by numerous mammal and bird species (Cederholm and others 1989; Willson and others 1998), and nutrients from decaying salmon carcasses support the production of periphyton, aquatic macroinvertebrates, resident freshwater fishes and juvenile salmon in spawning streams (Mathis en and others 1988; Kline and others 1990, 1993; Schuldt and Hershey 1995; Michael 1995; Bilby)" (168)
Benefit_4:
ESB: terrestrial vegetation
ESP: salmon carcasse
Sentence describing benefit: "Having spent most of their lives feeding and growing at sea, Pacific salmon returning to spawn and die ​in their natal streams carry marine-derived nutrients in their body tissues. . . These nutrients are also delivered to terrestrial vegetation." (168)
Benefit_5:
ESB: Bears
ESP: Spawning salmon, salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon are an important seasonal food source for coastal bear populations (Hilderbrand and others 1996, 1999b), and bears frequently consume a large proportion of total spawner biomass, either through predation or scavenging of post-spawn carcasses (Quinn and Kinnison 1999; Quinn and Buck 2000; Reimchen 2000; Ruggerone and others 2000; Gende and others 2001; Quinn and others 2001" (169)
Benefit_6:
ESB: soil
ESP: bears via salmon
Sentence describing benefit: ". Marine-derived nutrients are then made available to riparian vegetation through dissemination of partially-eaten salmon carcasses and salmon-enriched wastes" (169)
Benefit_7:
ESB: white spruce
ESP: bears via salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Hilderbrand and others (1999a) report that brown bears on the Kenai Peninsula, Alaska, deliver 83 -84% of marine-derived N detected in white spruce (Picea glauca) foliage within 500 m of spawning streams" (169)
Benefit_8:
ESB: river otter, mink, marten
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "River otter (Lontra canadensis) and mink (Mustela vision) feed regularly on salmon (Blundell and others 1998; Ben-David and others 1997a), whereas marten (Martes americana) incorporate salmon into their diets during years of low abundance of principal prey species (Ben-David and others 1997b" (169)
Benefit_9:
ESB: bald eagle, gulls
ESP: salmon, esp. carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Bald eagle (Haliaeetus leucocephalus) and gulls (Larus spp.) also scavenge and occasionally kill salmon in Alaskan streams (Ben-David and others 1998; Quinn and Buck 2000)." (169)
Benefit_10:
ESB: riparian ecosystems, stream bugs
ESP: stream bugs, salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Aquatic larvae of numerous stonefly (Plecoptera), caddisfly (Trichoptera) and midge (Diptera: Chironomidae) species feed directly on salmon carcasses in streams, whereas mayflies (Ephemeroptera), blackflies (Diptera: Simuliidae) and midges feed on fine particles immediately downstream from decomposing carcasses (Minakawa 1997; Wipfli and others 1998; Minakawa and Gara 1999). Salmon-derived nutrients are also incorporated into the body tissues of predatory stoneflies and dragonflies (Odonata) through trophic interactions (Kline and others 1990; Bilby and others 1996). These materials are subsequently transferred to adjacent terrestrial ecosystems with the emergence of the adult insects and their subsequent death or consumption by terrestrial insectivores" (169)
Benefit_11:
ESB: terrestrial fly larvae
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon carcasses deposited on exposed gravel bars and in the riparian zone are quickly colonized and consumed by larval forms of terrestrial flies (Diptera: Calliphoridae and Scathophagidae) and carrion beetles (Coleoptera: Silphidae)" (169)
Benefit_12:
ESB: riparian ecosystems
ESP: spawning sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: " O'Keefe and Edwards (2003) reported that concentrations of ammonium (NH4) and soluble reactive phosphorus increased significantly in a southwestern Alaskan stream following entry of spawning sockeye salmon, and that nutrient-enriched surface water subsequently entered the hyporheic zone beneath the riparian forest" (169)
Benefit_13:
ESB: riparian plant communities
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Recent studies have found that foliar N content, basal area growth and stem densities of riparian trees are enhanced at sites near spawning streams (Helfield and Naiman 2001, 2002; Bartz and Naiman 2005), whereas species richness and density of understory plants are decreased, relative to comparable sites without salmon (Bartz and Naiman 2005). " (170)
Benefit_14:
ESB: salmon babies
ESP: riparian plant community via salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "nutrients carried upstream by adult salmon help to enhance the productivity of subsequent generations of salmon and other stream-dwelling fishes." (170) Mechanism: salmon carcass --> trees --> LWD, shading, stream productivity --> bb salmon
Benefit_15:
ESB: bears
ESP: sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The area supports a population of approximately 2.8 bears per 100 km2 (Van Daele 1998), all of whom feed on salmon throughout the spawning season." (170)
Benefit_16:
ESB: riparian ecosystems
ESP: sockeye salmo
Sentence describing benefit: "At minimum levels of escapement, marine-derived N accounts for approximately 7% of total annual riparian N influx. At maximum levels of escapement, this percentage increases to 39%" (174)
Benefit_17:
ESB: terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: salmon carcasses via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "The majority of bear-mediated N is distributed via partially-eaten salmon carcasses (that is, ort)" (174)
Benefit_18:
ESB: terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: bears via salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Although a greater mass of N is distributed via ort, N distributed via excretion is more widespread" (174)
Benefit_19:
ESB: baby salmon
ESP: bears via salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "To the extent that bear rely on salmon as an essential food source, and to the extent that bear-mediated fertilization of riparian forests helps to enhance habitat for juvenile salmonids, salmon and bear populations are mutually dependent not only in their role as nutrient vectors, but also for their long-term persistence." (176)

Full_citation: Campbell, S., & Butler, V. (2010). Archaeological Evidence for Resilience of Pacific Northwest Salmon Populations and the Socioecological System over the last ~7,500 years. Ecology and Society, 15(1), 17.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors look at the ~7,500-year-long fish bone record for salmon in the PNW; it is an archaeological review of salmon use and explanations for the populations' resilience over time.
Essential_notes: -Authors point out the historical relationship of native tribes and salmon, as well as the influence of the species on their social development. They argue for making salmon personal again and emphasize that resilience requires full-ecosystem focus.
Benefit_1:
ESB: indigenous peoples
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The earliest anthropologists surveying indigenous cultures in North America highlighted the importance of salmon to peoples living in both regions and defined the “Salmon Area” to reflect this commonality." (np)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Indigenous societies
ESP: salmon abundance
Sentence describing benefit: "Because of its sheer abundance, salmon is at the heart of most explanations for how wild, rather than domesticated, resources could support large sedentary populations with complex social and political life ways, and also when and how such societies evolved from early mobile foragers." (np)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Indigenous fishery
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "On the south–central Northwest Coast, coastline sitesdisplay a range of values for every time period, suggesting salmon was the focus of the fishery in some locations, and only a minor or moderate constituent in others" (np)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Tribes
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Our results indicate few trends in use overall, but do confirm that salmon were a persistently important resource throughout time. Salmon remains were present in every dated component, making Salmonidae the most ubiquitous, out of the 24 fish families present" (np)
Benefit_5:
ESB: Tribes
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Our record is based on the remains of salmon harvested by people over the last 7,500 years and thus is germane to the resilience of the human–salmon interaction, not just the salmonids themselves. " (np)
Benefit_6:
ESB: historic tribes
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Haggan et al. (2006) propose an annual average per person consumption rate of 230 kg/yr based on two 19th-century estimates. At this rate, 200,000 people would annually consume 46,000 metric tons (50,706 tons) of salmon, comparable in magnitude to the average yearly commercial catch between 1901 and 2000 (Jones 2002)." (np)
Benefit_7:
ESB: Tribes
ESP: tribal innovation via salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The diversity and ingenuity of the fishing technology developed by Northwest Coast peoples has long been appreciated (Rostlund 1952)." (np)
Benefit_8:
ESB: commercial and indigenous fisheries
ESP: marine and spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "today, the commercial fishery focuses on coastal and estuary settings, whereas the indigenous fishery targeted salmon after they entered freshwater" (np)
Benefit_9:
ESB: tribes
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The methods used in historic times for capturing fish represent the culmination of thousands of years of development, during which people continually modified their strategies for catching fish, presumably to increase productivity" (np)
Benefit_10:
ESB: tribes
ESP: salmon via tribal members 
Sentence describing benefit: "The preservation and storage of large quantities of fish for storage and for trade, not simply immediate consumption, would have affected the marginal value of salmon by extending the use well outside the season of availability...Storage of fish over winter is estimated to have occurred by at least 4,000 years ago (Ames and Maschner 1999) or, alternatively, as far back as 7,000 years ago (Cannon and Yang 2006)." (np)
Benefit_11:
ESB: salmon
ESP: tribes
Sentence describing benefit: "Maintenance of salmon streams by removing debris, a form of habitat enhancement, is reported for the Heiltsuk of northern British Columbia by Jones (2002)" (np)
Benefit_12:
ESB: Nuu-chah-nulth Tribe
ESP: tribal management
Sentence describing benefit: "There is a record from the 1860s of the Nuu-chah-nulth of Vancouver Island transporting salmon eggs between water systems (Sproat 1868), but the extent to which this was practiced is unknown. " (np)
Benefit_13:
ESB: tribes
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Despite the importance of salmon in the diet of indigenous peoples, salmon harvesting needs to be understood in the context of other resource use, not in isolation. Overall diet breadth and a generalized subsistence strategy afforded past peoples considerable flexibility and the capacity to respond to environmental fluctuations, contributing to resilience in the human populations. " (np)
Benefit_14:
ESB: Northwest Coast natives
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In the historic period, Northwest Coast natives practiced a broad-based fishery (Suttles 1990). This applies to the more distant past as well, as indicated in our archaeological assemblages by measures of ubiquity and relative abundance of fish families exploited" (np)
Benefit_15:
ESB: Native societies
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Loss or decline of runs in the Fraser River system significantly affected human population density and/or mobility as demonstrated by settlement pattern changes (Hayden and Ryder 1991, 2003, Kuijt 2001, Prentiss et al. 2005)." (np)
Benefit_16:
ESB: Tribal social institutions
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Although it is likely that the broad-based diet contributed to the resilience of the human–ecological system, we suggest that social institutions and behaviors related to regulating the harvest and associated activities were especially important (see also Trosper 2003). " (np)
Benefit_17:
ESB: tribal society and culture
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Second, and even more compelling, the ethnographic and oral tradition literature from both the Northwest Coast and the Plateau is rich with examples of harvest regulations, beliefs, and rituals, practices argued to contribute to resource conservation in other small-scale societies (TurneyHigh 1941 as cited in Trosper 2002, Richardson 1982, Haggan et al. 2006)" (np)
Benefit_18:
ESB: tribal social structures
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Examples of ownership of salmon capture locations are ubiquitous and typically linked with constructed facilities (traps, weirs, reef nets) that target locations where fish are concentrated and accessible. Social regulations at such sites not only involved who had the right to fish there but also timing of access and allowing for escapement. In many cases, chiefly managers gave permission for use of capture locations or gear and expected a share of the harvests in return for use (Swezey and Heizer 1977, Johnsen 2001, Trosper 2002, Haggan et al. 2006)." (np)
Benefit_19:
ESB: tribes
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Timing of salmon harvest was socially regulated as well, most notably by the extremely widespread “first salmon ceremony” (e.g., Gunther 1926, Swezey and Heizer 1977). (2006), that traditions and facilities that regulated the fishery were not isolated traits, but woven into the social fabric of life. Thus, cooperative behavior was supported in the broader cultural context. This included potlatches, structured ceremonial rituals where corporate household heads gave away surplus to other households." (np)

The fishery for Chinook salmon was highly structured and organized, with lengthy periods of ritual preceding any fishing activity."
Benefit_22:
ESB: Tribes
ESP: chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Later in the year, usually in June–July at the peak of the summer run, another period of ritual and communal activities occurred, focusing on construction of large fish weirs on the Klamath and Trinity Rivers. Ritual specialists directed the building of the weirs, which spanned the entire width of the rivers. Construction of the weir at Kepel on the Klamath River by Yurok people, involved an elaborate 10-d ritual of weir building. Several hundred men from multiple villages were directed to cut wood and construct the elaborate structure. The Kepel weir had nine openings that led to pens in which salmon were held, then removed and dried mainly for later use. " (np)
Benefit_23:
ESB: salmon via tribes
ESP: tribes via salmo
Sentence describing benefit: "We assert that the institutions, beliefs, and rituals known for the indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest had the effect of managing human behavior so that salmon harvest timing and intensity were moderated by some group or central decisionmaking process. These constraints on salmon harvests converted an open-access resource into a common-pool resource and contributed to the sustainability and resilience of the Native American salmon fishery in historic times"
Benefit_24:
ESB: the public
ESP: salmon

Benefit_25:
ESB: conservation activists
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Although they are a strong cultural symbol of the Pacific Northwest (Lang 2003), only a small fraction of our modern society has direct interaction with the fish. . . Nonprofit organizations up and down the Pacific Coast already are working to engage the public about salmon and other resources  . . . These groups host community celebrations, develop educational curricula, and organize volunteers for diverse tasks such as replanting stream sides, removing barriers to migration, decorating buses with educational and inspirational messages, and painting signs on storm sewer openings" (np)

Full_citation: Verspoor, J., Braun, D., Stubbs, M., & Reynolds, J. (2011). Persistent ecological effects of a salmon-derived nutrient pulse on stream invertebrate communities. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 2(2), Art18-17.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors looked at the relationship between stream characteristics and salmon abundance with invertebrate communities over time and 21 streams.
Essential_notes: -Important to note that stream characteristics (freezing, leaf litter input, floods/other discharges, etc.) influence nutrient retention and longevity of that impact/input on the system.
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW ecosystems
ESP: anadromous salmo
Sentence describing benefit: "Across the north Pacific, millions of anadromous salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) deliver an annual nutrient subsidy to freshwater ecosystems, which can have important ecological consequences (reviewed by Gende et al. 2002, Naiman et al. 2002, Schindler et al. 2003, Janetski et al. 2009)....that can both directly influence organisms that consume salmon eggs or carcasses (e.g., Bilby et al. 1998, Minakawa et al. 2002) and indirectly alter ecosystem processes when organisms switch their diets to salmon (Zhang et al. 2003)." (2)
Benefit_2:
ESB: stream chem
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Decomposing carcasses can also elevate dissolved nutrient levels, which may increase primary productivity and improve the nutritional quality of biofilm if nutrients are limited (e.g., Johnston et al. 2004, Peterson and Matthews 2009)." (2)
Benefit_3:
ESB: chironomids
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In coastal southeast Alaska, chironomid midges had higher abundances over ten months after spawning in two stream reaches that received a salmon nutrient pulse, while several mayfly genera showed the opposite relationship (Lessard et al. 2009)." (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Invertebrates
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Total invertebrate abundance increased with both salmon density and stream temperature" (7)
Benefit_5:
ESB: mayflies
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The abundance of heptageniid mayflies increased with salmon density, stream temperature, and substrate size" (7)
Benefit_6:
ESB: stoneflies
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Chloroperlid stoneflies followed a similar pattern to heptageniid mayflies, with higher numbers in streams that had more salmon and warmer water" (7)
Benefit_7:
ESB: chironomids
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Chironomids were also most abundant in warmer streams with more salmon" (7)
Benefit_8:
ESB: chironomids
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Chironomids have been shown to colonize salmon carcasses (e.g., Chaloner et al. 2002), presumably utilizing them directly as a food source, which may benefit growth and survival throughout the year. It has also been suggested that they might suffer less from substrate disturbance during spawning than larger bodied taxa, allowing the positive influence of salmon nutrients to be more obviously reflected in their abundances (Lessard et al. 2009)." (10)
Benefit_9:
ESB: stoneflies
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Alternatively, chloroperlids have also been known to scavenge from dead salmon eggs and alevins, which could explain their higher abundances (Ellis 1970). That they have been seen colonizing salmon carcasses in the study region supports this hypothesis (Johnston et al. 2004)." (10)
Benefit_10:
ESB: riparian ecosystems

Sentence describing benefit: "Further, as emerging adult aquatic insects can provide an important nutrient pulse to riparian ecosystems (Richardson et al. 2010; but see Francis et al. 2006), our findings highlight how one resource subsidy [nutrients from salmon] can influence another." (11)

Full_citation: Bentley, K., Schindler, D., Armstrong, J., Zhang, R., Ruff, C., & Lisi, P. (2012). Foraging and growth responses of stream-dwelling fishes to inter-annual variation in a pulsed resource subsidy. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 3(12), Art113-17.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of salmon pulse magnitude on foraging and growth of Rainbow Trout and Arctic Grayling, based on 11 years of field data.
Essential_notes: -Authors point out that systems have a saturation point after which additional salmon have no additional effect on stream-resident fish.
Benefit_1:
ESB: humans
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) have long been valued as an annual source of renewable food for humans (Lichatowich 2001), returning to freshwater ecosystems throughout the Northern Pacific Rim by the millions to spawn after accumulating >95% of their body mass at sea (Quinn 2005)." (2)
Benefit_2:
ESB: FW and terrestrial organisms
ESP: Spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon spawning migrations generate massive resource fluxes into freshwater and terrestrial ecosystems, producing a pulse of nutrients and energy to inland food webs that often surpass background levels of in situ productivity (Gende et al. 2002). These pulsed subsidies are utilized by a wide range of taxa, including everything from periphyton, macroinvertebrates and fishes (Kline et al. 1993, Holtgrieve et al. 2010) to terrestrial mammals and birds (Willson and Halupka 1995, Hilderbrand et al. 1999)." (2)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream-resident fish
ESP: salmon, especially eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "It has become clear that stream‐dwelling freshwater fishes directly benefit from spawning salmon through the consumption of salmon tissues (particularly eggs; Bilby et al. 1996, Scheuerell et al. 2007, Denton et al. 2009). Although the duration of this seasonal pulse of food is relatively brief, salmon eggs are 2–3 times as energy dense as benthic and terrestrial invertebrates (Cummins and Wuycheck 1971, Armstrong 2010) and can be available when other sources of food are low in abundance (Moore and Schindler 2010)." (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: stream-resident fish
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Additionally, spawning behavior of salmon can indirectly benefit resident fishes by dislodging otherwise relatively inaccessible benthic invertebrates during their nest construction (Scheuerell et al. 2007)." (2-3)
Benefit_5:
ESB: rainbow trout and arctic grayling
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We observed an increase in the total average ration size [proportion of salmon in diet] of rainbow trout and Arctic grayling coinciding with an increase in salmon density in both Lynx and Hidden creeks (Fig. 2). " (7)
Benefit_6:
ESB: rainbow trout and arctic grayling
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In high salmon years, nearly all rainbow trout switched to an entirely salmon based diet, while Arctic grayling continued to display a wide range of individual variation, with some switching to salmon derived resources while others consumed mainly in situ derived prey." (8)
Benefit_7:

(8)

Full_citation: Levi, P., & Tank, J. (2013). Nonnative Pacific salmon alter hot spots of sediment nitrification in Great Lakes tributaries. Journal of Geophysical Research. Biogeosciences, 118(2), 436-444.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of nonnative (hatchery) Pacific salmon on biogeochemical transformations in tributaries for the Great Lakes.
Essential_notes: -Salmon provide nutrients, but influence and extent of provision varies by location.
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW streams
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) provide an ammonium (NH4+) subsidy to streams during their annual spawning runs, which may be transformed to nitrate (NO3−) via sediment nitrification." (436)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Great Lakes streams
ESP: introduced salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Nonnative salmon provide a pulsed source of inorganic nitrogen to Great Lakes tributaries, yet dissimilatory biogeochemical transformations such as nitrification may alter the form of the NH4+ subsidy and potentially influence downstream lakes via export of both NH4+ and NO3−." (436)
Benefit_3:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "[14] Stream water NH4+ concentrations were influenced by salmon biomass (p < 0.001; Figure 2 and Table 2). Also, concentrations were significantly higher in the streams with large runs relative to those with small runs among all time periods (mean NH4+ ± SE = 80.7 ± 12.8 and 9.4 ± 0.9 µg N L−1, respectively)."
Benefit_4:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Although nitrification rates did not vary consistently through time (p = 0.5; Table 2), salmon biomass was a significant co-variate (p < 0.001) mediating the nitrification response through time. " (440)
Benefit_5:
ESB: stream chem (nitrification rates)
ESP: live salmon, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In the channel margin, sediment nitrification rates were higher in the presence of live salmon and carcasses. This positive relationship may reflect an increase in the availability of NH4+ via salmon excretion or a shift in secondary controls on nitrification via benthic disturbance from spawning salmon [e.g., Peterson and Foote, 2000; Gende et al., 2002; Tiegs et al., 2009]. " (443)
Benefit_6:

ESP: introduced salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Nonnative Pacific salmon represent a managed, human-mediated N subsidy to the Great Lakes tributaries and have multiple effects on streams throughout their introduced range." (443)

'But they use the fish the same way we all do up and down the coast; medicine and culture and celebration and trading for other items that they need. M 50–80'" (1398)

Full_citation: Kreitzman, M., Ashander, J., Driscoll, J., Bateman, A., Chan, K., Lewis, M., & Krkosek, M. (2018). Wild Salmon Sustain the Effectiveness of Parasite Control on Salmon Farms: Conservation Implications from an Evolutionary Ecosystem Service. Conservation Letters, 11(2), N/a.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors argue that presence of wild salmon and their sea lice near hatcheries facilitates input of sea lice to said hatcheries that have NOT been exposed to pesticides and thereby slows development of pesticide resistence in hatchery sea lice. They review the literature and a few different models/mechanisms for this to occur and constraints on efficacy.
Essential_notes:
-caveats on the benefit: "Our model shows that even assuming the existence of large wild salmon populations is not enough to avoid resistance if regional migrating populations are small or in decline. Taken together, these results point to two features of the salmon/sea lice system that have critical conservation and management implications: (1) the ratio of total wild salmon to total farmed salmon biomass and (2) the flow of susceptible alleles from the refuge to the farm." (7)
-call for this research: "A comprehensive ecosystem services analysis of salmon would account both for externalized benefits that are nonmaterial, collective, or long-term and for internalized benefits that have immediate economic impacts. To date, there is no comprehensive ecosystem services assessment of salmon to allow for comparison of trade-offs in future scenarios involving aquaculture development, status quo, or intensive restoration." (8)
Benefit_1:
ESB: hatchery salmon
ESP: wild salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "This theoretical and observational data suggests that wild salmon (both oceanic populations that function as a refuge and local migratory populations that connect this refuge to domesticated environments) provide an evosystem service by prolonging parasiticide efficacy. " (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: BC residents
ESP: wild salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In BC, wild salmon are an important food and cultural resource but have also served as a nuisance to the salmon farming industry, both as a source of naturally occurring pathogens like sea lice (Costello 2009) and as a source of economic competition and negative publicity (Rayner & Howlett 2007). " (4-5)
Benefit_3:
ESB: hatcheries and salmon
ESP: wild salmon (and their sea lice)
Sentence describing benefit: "In the absence of any connectivity between the farm and wild environment, susceptible lice dominated on farms at low treatment levels, and resistant lice reached 100% at high treatment levels (Murray 2011). Similarly, McEwan et al. (2015) showed that resistance evolved more slowly when connectivity increased. Both studies also showed that in the presence of connectivity, the relative size of farm lice urn:x-wiley:1755263X:media:conl12395:conl12395-math-0011 and wild lice urn:x-wiley:1755263X:media:conl12395:conl12395-math-0012 affects resistance evolution: McEwan et al. (2015) showed resistance might not evolve when wild hosts equal or outnumbered farm hosts, even with no cost of resistance. Similarly, Murray (2011) showed that when farms are large relative to wild populations, resistance emerged quickly." (5)
Benefit_4:
ESB: farmed salmon
ESP: wild salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Previous results (Murray 2011; McEwan et al. 2015) agree that large wild salmon populations connected to farms will slow, or possibly preclude, the emergence of EB resistance" (7)
Benefit_5:
ESB: BC salmon farming industry
ESP: maintenance of non-EB resistent genes
Sentence describing benefit: "In concrete terms, the BC salmon farming industry likely derives an economic benefit from the maintenance of EB susceptibility, by avoiding costs associated with resistance. " (8)
Benefit_6:
ESB: varied
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "As a cultural keystone species, wild salmon provides a long list of valuable ecosystem services including nutrient cycling value for forests (Helfield & Naiman 2001), commercial value, subsistence value, spiritual value, and recreation value (Turner & Garibaldi 2004). To these, we can now add the value of mitigating pesticide resistance on salmon farms." (8)
Benefit_7:
ESB: aquaculture
ESP: wild salmon sea lice
Sentence describing benefit: "Our synthesis of evolutionary models of pesticide resistance for the sea lice salmon system indicates two related but distinct mechanisms for delaying resistance, both of which have implications for the conservation of wild salmon and for the management of aquaculture. The first mechanism involves changes in the ratio of total wild salmon to total farmed salmon biomass. When the wild sea louse population shrinks relative to the farm population, resistance emerges faster (Murray 2011; McEwan et al. 2015). The second mechanism is the flow of susceptible sea louse alleles from the refuge to the farm through salmon populations that migrate past salmon farms (Figure 3). " (9)

Full_citation: Andersson, L., & Reynolds, J. (2018). Habitat features mediate selective consumption of salmon by bears. Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences, 75(6), 955-963.
Journal: Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors studied prey selection and consumption by bears to determine whether they favored more energetically efficient parts of salmon or what else might influence selection and consumption behavior.
Location: Heiltsuk First Nation territory, Great Bear Rainforest, British Columbia, Canada
Essential_notes: -amount of prey catch was influenced by stream characteristics
Benefit_1:
ESB: aquatic and terrestrial systems
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon provide a key source of marine-derived nutrients to aquatic and surrounding terrestrial habitats in coastal areas of the North Pacific. " (955)
Benefit_2:
ESB: riparian zones
ESP: salmon carcass via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Bears are a major predator of salmon and provide an important pathway for carcass transfer to riparian zones. " (955)
Benefit_3:
ESB: aquatic and terrestrial systems
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "After spawning, they die and deliver valuable nutrients to surrounding aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems (Schindler et al. 2003; Helfield and Naiman 2006)." (955)
Benefit_4:
ESB: terrestrial systems
ESP: spawning salmo via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Foraging bears facilitate salmon nutrient transfer to terrestrial habitats, as they pull live fish out of streams and leave their carcasses on land nearby (Hilderbrand et al. 1999; Quinn et al. 2009). Once a salmon carcass is abandoned by a bear, the remains become available to a suite of other species (e.g., insects and scavenging birds) that transfer nutrients (reviewed in Gende et al. 2002 and Janetski et al. 2009). These nutrients are also incorporated into surrounding plant matter (Hocking and Reynolds 2011; Hocking and Reynolds 2012) and can have impacts on local breeding bird communities (Christie and Reimchen 2008; Field and Reynolds 2011)." (955)
Benefit_5:
ESB: riparian systems
ESP: bear-killed salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Carcasses left in the riparian zone are particularly important to nutrient transfer because they are less likely to be washed downstream into the estuary than the senescent salmon that die in the streams (Cederholm et al. 1989). Even bear-killed salmon abandoned within streams have more value, in nutrient terms, than senescent salmon carcasses, for certain species. For example, caddisfly (Trichoptera) larvae preferentially colonize bear-killed salmon due to increased temporal availability, energetic content, and accessibility of tissue (Winder et al. 2005). The amount of salmon biomass abandoned by bears is, therefore, an important component to overall nutrient transfer to both terrestrial and aquatic pathways." (955)
Benefit_6:
ESB: wolf
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "we excluded measurements of wolf-killed salmon, which are distinguished by their clean, surgical removal of the brain case and abandonment of the rest of the carcass (Darimont et al. 2003). " (957)
Benefit_7:
ESB: salmon, esp. more energetic females and chum
ESP: Bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Bears selectively consumed 31% of all carcasses examined across the 12 streams (n = 659), with a higher proportion of selective consumption of females (38.6%) than of males (20%), and more on chum (35.7%) than on pink salmon (25.4%). In species by gender subgroups, selective consumption occurred on 31.2% of pink females, 15.3% of pink males, 44.6% of chum females, and 23.7% of chum males." (959) --> indicates energy selection
Benefit_8:
ESB: bears
ESP: female salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The alternative scoring system, which does not include energy-rich parts, revealed that bears were more likely to eat the majority (>50%) of a female carcass than a male carcass, probably because females are smaller and, therefore, the same number of bites on prey of each sex would result in a higher proportion of the carcasses of females being consumed." (961)

Full_citation: Utter, F., & Epifanio, J. (2002). Marine aquaculture: Genetic potentialities and pitfalls. Reviews in Fish Biology and Fisheries, 12(1), 59-77.
Journal: Reviews in Fish Biology and Fisheries
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors describe different types of aquaculture, provide case studies, and make recommendations for aquaculture moving forward.
Benefit_1:
ESB: winter chinook population
ESP: hatchery chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Declines in the winter run of chinook salmon (O. tshawytscha) in the Sacramento River from more than 100,000 in 1969 to less than 200 in 1991 led to listing of this run as endangered under the ESA in 1994 (e.g., Hedrick et al., 2000). A program has been initiated to supplement natural production through capture of a portion of the wild run to increase egg and juvenile survival and to guard against catastrophic natural juvenile losses. The breeding protocol, designed to equalize the contributions from captive spawners, succeeded in maintaining the effective population size of the overall population. " (66)
Benefit_2:
ESB: winter run chinook
ESP: hatchery salmon via hatchery engineering
Sentence describing benefit: "the inadvertent use of some non-winter-run spawners coupled with imprinted adults returning to the rearing location rather than to the mainstream spawning site of natural winter-run fish reduced the program’s initial effectiveness. Correction of these problems by the construction of a new rearing facility adjacent to the natural spawning site and the current molecular genetic screening of all spawners to exclude all but winter-run fish are necessary steps that have been taken to fulfill the goals of this program." (66)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Japanese commercial fisheries
ESP: hatchery chum salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Hatchery releases account for more than 90% of Japanese catch, increasing from 20 to 60 million fish between 1975 and 1990" (67)
Benefit_4:
ESB: spring chinook populations
ESP: hatcheries
Sentence describing benefit: "The spring-run chinook salmon returning to the Carson National Fish Hatchery represent the earliest and most extensive ongoing operation of this nature (Myers et al., 1998). The Carson spring-run enhancement effort was initiated in 1955 using fish destined for the upper Columbia and Snake rivers. These fish were intercepted at the Bonneville Dam – the most downstream mainstem dam – and transported to the Carson Hatchery on the Wind River, which enters the Columbia River on the Washington side approximately 40 km upstream in the Bonneville pool (Ricker, 1972). The stock became self-perpetuating by 1960. Subsequently, Carson fish have been released in large numbers from the hatchery as well as extensively reintroduced to upstream ancestral areas of the Columbia and Snake rivers (Mullan, 1987; Utter et al., 1995; Myers et al., 1998)." (68)

Full_citation: Holtgrieve, G., Schindler, D., Gowell, C., Ruff, C., & Lisi, P. (2010). Stream geomorphology regulates the effects on periphyton of ecosystem engineering and nutrient enrichment by Pacific salmon. Freshwater Biology, 55(12), 2598-2611.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors look at the relationship between stream rock size and uptake of MDN by periphyton.
Location: Wood River System, Bristol Bay, AK
Essential_notes: -While authors reveal some minor positive effects in this paper, largely the effect is negative for the recipients of interest: "After weighting the rock-scale effect of salmon on benthic algae by the observed frequency distributions of particle sizes in each individual stream, we found that in all but a few cases the overall net effect of salmon was negative...The dominant overall effect of salmon in these tributaries of the Wood River is therefore one of disturbance rather than fertilisation with marine-derived nutrients. " (2608)

ESB: periphyton
ESP: spawning salmon

Benefit_2:

Full_citation: Quinn, T., Cunningham, C., & Wirsing, A. (2016). Diverse foraging opportunities drive the functional response of local and landscape-scale bear predation on Pacific salmon. Oecologia, 183(2), 415-429.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors model the relationship between salmon density in streams and predation by brown bears.
Location: Wood River System, Bristol Bay, AK
Essential_notes: -Main takeaway: "In summary, the proportion of salmon killed by brown bears depended strongly on stream depth (and also width) but the total number killed at high densities (asymptotic upper predation limit) did not." (427)
Benefit_1:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Bears are highly omnivorous (Mowat and Heard 2006) but need to accumulate energy in the late summer and fall for over-wintering (Farley and Robbins 1995; Watts and Jonkel 1988), so the abundance of salmon makes them a focal resource for bears in many coastal systems (Hilderbrand et al. 1999; Reimchen 2000; Van Daele et al. 2013)." (416)
Benefit_2:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon carcass
Sentence describing benefit: "As previously noted (Quinn et al. 2001, 2003), some salmon that die of senescence are scavenged by bears postmortem (Quinn and Buck 2000) and so might be misclassified as bear-killed." (418)
Benefit_3:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The semelparous salmon inevitably die after spawning, so the nutrients in their bodies imported from the ocean will enter the ecosystem (Naiman et al. 2002; Willson et al. 2004) regardless of whether the fish are killed prior to spawning or not. " (423)
Benefit_4:
ESB: riparian systems
ESP: salmon via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Sampling in three of the streams included in the present study (Hansen, Bear, and Yako creeks) revealed that bear predation increased carcass deposition on land, and carcasses in deeper, more structurally complex streams were more likely to remain within the channel than in shallow, simple streams (Meehan et al. 2005). Thus, stream habitat affects nutrient cycling indirectly, via bear predation rate, and directly, via carcass deposition patterns." (423-4)
Benefit_5:
ESB: soil, land bugs
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Carcasses in the riparian zone (mostly deposited by bears) are extensively scavenged by blowfly maggots (Meehan et al. 2005) and other terrestrial insects (Hocking et al. 2009) and birds (Quinn and Buck 2000), and the nutrients are cycled through the soils of the riparian zone (Gende et al. 2007; Holtgrieve et al. 2009)." (424)
Benefit_6:
ESB: streams, caddisflies
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "bear-killed carcasses deposited in streams may be scavenged by larval caddis flies (Winder et al. 2005) but much of the decomposing tissue remains in aquatic systems (Kline et al. 1993)." (424)
Benefit_7:
ESB: salmon runs

Full_citation: Chaloner, D., Lamberti, G., Cak, A., Blair, N., & Edwards, R. (2007). Inter-annual variation in responses of water chemistry and epilithon to Pacific salmon spawners in an Alaskan stream. Freshwater Biology, 52(3), 478-490.

Location: Fish Creek, Douglas Island, Southeastern AK, USA
