Full_citation: Yanai, S., & Kochi, K. (2005). Effects of salmon carcasses on experimental stream ecosystems in Hokkaido, Japan. Ecological Research, 20(4), 471-480.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors examined the effect of salmon carcasses on dissolved nutrients, ephithilic production, leaf decomposition rates, and macroinvertebrates in artificial stream channels.
Essential_notes:
-3 treatments:
1) salmon + inverts
2) only inverts
3) no salmon or inverts
Benefit_1:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon carcass
Sentence describing benefit: "The NH +4 in stream water and chlorophyll concentrations of epilithic algae were higher in the salmon treatment than the other treatments, and the maple leaves decomposed faster in the salmon treatment than in the other treatments." (471)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Goerodes satoi macroinvertebrate
ESP: salmon carcass
Sentence describing benefit: "However, the stable N isotope ratio in G. satoi was nearly 3‰ higher in the salmon treatment, suggesting that around 20% of salmon-derived N was taken up by this shredder." (471)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream ecosystems
ESP: salmon carcass
Sentence describing benefit: "Our results indicate that salmon carcasses affect stream ecosystems directly by enhancing primary production, indirectly by accelerating woody leaf decomposition, and finally by incorporating into the food web primary consumers that utilize fertilized woody leaves." (471)
Benefit_4:
ESB: stream ecosystems
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Recent studies in North America have demonstrated that salmon carcasses influence the nutrient levels of stream water and enhance primary productivity, which in turn affect the stream bed and abundance of invertebrate consumers (Kline et al. 1990, 1993; Bilby et al. 1996, 1998; Cederholm et al. 1999; Fisher Wold and Hershey 1999). These effects are largely a result of the release of limiting nutrients, such as P and N (Schudt and Hershey 1995; Bilby et al. 1996), and the cascading effects of enhanced nutrient levels on primary producers, primary and secondary macroinvertebrate consumers, and predacious fish including juvenile salmonids (Bilby et al. 1996; Wipfli et al. 1998, 1999; Minakawa and Gara 1999; Giannico 2000; Minakawa et al. 2002; Chaloner et al. 2002)." (471)
Benefit_5:
ESB: terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: salmon via bears, etc.
Sentence describing benefit: "The effects of salmon carcasses extend beyond aquatic ecosystems, because carcasses that are moved to forests by large mammals such as fox, mink, and bear (Cederholm et al. 1989; Ben-David 1997; Hilderbrand et al. 1996, 1999; Reimchen 2000) enrich forest soil and enhance the growth of trees in riparian zones (Bilby et al. 1996; Helfield and Naiman 2001, 2002). " (471-2)
Benefit_6:
ESB: downstream ecosystems
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Not only upstream ecosystems in the vicinity of spawning areas but also lower parts of river systems, including estuarine macroalgal primary producers and primary consumers, especially copepods, benefit from such salmon-derived nutrients (Fujiwara and Highsmith 1997). " (472)
Benefit_7:
ESB: unclear
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In Japan, Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) is an important socio-economic resource." (472)
Benefit_8:
ESB: microbial communities, amphipods
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Although a laboratory experiment has shown that salmon carcasses enhance bacterial activity on maple leaves and accelerate the growth rate of amphipods (Ito 2003), more rigorous examination of the pathways through which salmon-derived energy is transferred to aquatic food webs is required." (472)
Benefit_9:
ESB: phytoplankton
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "We observed significantly higher concentrations of chlorophyll in the salmon treatment throughout the experiment than in the other treatments (Fig. 3, Table 2). The initial concentration was 182 mg m−2, which gradually declined to 112 mg m−2 over time in this treatment. In contrast, in the other treatments it remained at around 50 mg m−2, approximately 3 times lower than in the salmon treatment." (475)
Benefit_10:
ESB: unclear
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The salmon treatment resulted in the highest decomposition rate, with 71% of the initial mass remaining after 40 days, whereas the decomposition rate in the control was the lowest (80% remaining after 40 days; Fig. 4). The k obtained from the negative exponential models was highest for the salmon treatment (k=0.0104), followed by those for the invertebrate treatment (k=0.0082) and the control (k=0.0064) (Table 3). Although the leaf mass-loss trajectory among the three treatments was insignificant, the treatment effect was significant (Table 4)." (475)
Benefit_11:
ESB: invertebrates
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "We found a greater biomass of other invertebrates in the salmon treatment after 40 days than in the invertebrate treatment, which was owing to the invasion of large Tipula larvae." (475)
Benefit_12:
ESB: stream chem
ESP: salmon carcasses 
Sentence describing benefit: "The salmon treatment showed nearly 3‰ higher N isotope values than did the invertebrate treatment throughout the experimental period (Table 7). " (475)
Benefit_13:
ESB: stream chem
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "We observed significantly higher levels of NH +4 and chlorophyll in the streams treated with salmon carcasses than in control streams." (476)
Benefit_14:
ESB: microbes
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The presence of salmon carcasses changed the quality of the allochthonous terrestrial leaves. The leaf decomposition rate was significantly higher in the salmon treatment than in the other treatments. Leaf decomposition began with leaching, followed by microbial colonization and consumption by macroinvertebrates (Anderson and Sedell 1979). The difference between the salmon and the invertebrate treatments (Fig. 4) is attributed to enhanced microbial decomposition, because few significant treatment effects were observed in the abundance and biomass of the invertebrates." (476-7)
Benefit_15:
ESB: G. satoi
ESP: salmon carcasses via microbes
Sentence describing benefit: "However, we detected significant increases in δ15N in G. satoi immediately downstream of the carcasses, which confirms the incorporation of carcass-derived N into the stream biota. The uptake of the N isotope into G. satoi was thought to have occurred as a result of the stable heavy isotope of N being released from salmon tissue and then being incorporated by microbes growing on the surfaces of leaves. This can produce higher microbial activity and the accretion of biomass associated with leaf material following nutrient enrichment. G. satoi in turn consumed the microbes along with the leaf tissue, thereby accumulating stable heavy N isotope." (478)
Benefit_16:
ESB: macroinverts (shredders)
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Several studies using stable isotope analysis have reported that salmon-derived N is taken up by shredders, whereas C is not used. Bilby et al. (1996) observed that shredders took up 24% of salmon-derived N, while the contribution of C was zero. Johnston et al. (1997) found that aquatic macroinvertebrates incorporated N at levels between 15% and 60%. However, insect C values were independent of spawner densities, suggesting that little salmon-derived C was incorporated into the benthic insect fauna. We therefore conclude that marine-derived N definitely affects shredders, whereas C does not." (478)

Full_citation: Christie, K., & Reimchen, T. (2008). Presence of Salmon Increases Passerine Density on Pacific Northwest Streams. The Auk, 125(1), 51-59.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors compare bird abundances near salmon-bearing and non-salmon-bearing stream reaches.
Essential_notes:
-distance from river was another important factor in songbird abundance 
-mechanisms by which birds could be affected include: increase in chironomids means more food for birds; eating adult flies that larvaed on salmon carcasses
Benefit_1:
ESB: terrestrial systems
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The annual migration of Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) to freshwater streams and lakes provides an important nutrient subsidy to terrestrial systems in North America." (51)
Benefit_2:
ESB: song birds
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: ". In our comparisons of salmon-bearing and non-salmon-bearing reaches of two rivers that had waterfall barriers to salmon partway upstream, we found that position above or below the falls and proximity to the stream were the major predictors of songbird abundance. Each species, except for Chestnut-backed Chickadee, had higher densities below the falls at both rivers. Our results suggest that salmon-derived nutrients influence songbird density, and thus benefit multiple trophic levels within riparian ecosystems" (51)
Benefit_3:
ESB: freshwater systems
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: ". One important nutrient subsidy on the north Pacific coast is the annual spawning of anadromous salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.). Salmon spend most of their lives sequestering nutrients from the ocean, but spawn and die in freshwater streams and lakes, thus transporting large quantities of marine-derived nutrients to these areas (Bilby et al. 1996, Cederholm et al. 2001)." (51)
Benefit_4:
ESB: terrestrial systems
ESP: salmon via predators
Sentence describing benefit: "Large quantities of salmon biomass are transported to forests adjacent to streams and lakes from occasional flooding (Willson et al. 1998) and through the activities of scavengers and predators including bears (Ursus spp.), American Martens (Martes americana), Gray Wolves (Canis lupus), gulls (Larus spp.), Common Ravens (Corvus corax), and Bald Eagles (Haliaeetus leucocephalus) (Reimchen 1994, 2000; Ben-David et al.1998; Hilderbrand et al. 1999; Gende et al. 2002; Darimont et al 2003; Reimchen et al. 2003; Christie and Reimchen 2005)." (51)
Benefit_5:
ESB: plants, inverts, vertebrates
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The ecological consequences of salmon-derived nutrients can be far-reaching and include increased vertebrate density, plant productivity, and aquatic and terrestrial invertebrate biomass (Willson et al. 1998, Wipfli et al. 1998, Helfield and Naiman 2001, Chaloner et al. 2002). These nutrients have been detected in plants, invertebrates, and vertebrates adjacent to salmon streams" (51)
Benefit_6:
ESB: breeding birds
ESP: salmon (indirectly)
Sentence describing benefit: "Gende and Willson (2001) found that overall songbird density and diversity were slightly higher adjacent to salmon streams than adjacent to streams with no salmon in Alaska, which suggests that salmon-derived nutrients may indirectly influence breeding birds." (52)
Benefit_7:
ESB: birds
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Parameter estimates indicated that bird abundance was always higher below the falls, where salmon spawned, than above the falls, where there were no spawning salmon (Table 2 and Fig. 1)" (53)
Benefit_8:
ESB: birds
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon was an important predictor of songbird abundance for most species, and large differences in density were detected over the waterfall barrier. The observed differences in abundance over a sharp ecological gradient suggest that upper-level consumers respond numerically to the presence of salmon-derived nutrients." (55)
Benefit_9:
ESB: chironomids
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " However, certain aquatic invertebrates, such as chironomid larvae, accumulate in large numbers on salmon carcasses and emerge as adults into terrestrial systems in the spring (Wipfli et al. 1998, Chaloner et al. 2002)." (55)
Benefit_10:
ESB: Winter Wren
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The Winter Wren, a ground-foraging bird that incorporates aquatic invertebrates into its diet in the the spring (Murakami and Nakano 2001) as well as fly larvae hatched from salmon carcasses in the fall (K. S. Christie pers. obs.), may be particularly responsive to the presence of salmon-derived nutrients. Isotopic evidence showing the presence of salmonderived nutrients in tissues of Winter Wrens further reflects the importance of salmon to this species (Christie 2005)." (55)

Full_citation: Scott, D., Harris, S., Hebert, A., & Van Poorten, B. (2017). Nutrient dynamics in a highly managed reservoir system: Considering anadromous sockeye salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka) and nutrient restoration. Lake and Reservoir Management, 33(1), 14-22.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors model nutrient flux with return of anadromous sockeye and the relationship between those nutrients and nutrient inputs for maintaining the kokenee.
Essential_notes:
-salmon returns are from a population of kokanee that was non-anadromous for 90 years!
-looks like juveniles and spillway exports more nutrients than are imported by the returning adults; however, net gain in returns at current survival rate would result in net gain of N+P
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW and terrestrial ecosystems

Benefit_2:
ESB: ecosystem dynamics
ESP: juvenile salmon

In nutrient-managed freshwater systems, anadromous salmon may therefore play an important role in nutrient flux dynamics." (15)
Benefit_3:
ESB: ecosystem

Benefit_4:
ESB: ecosystem
ESP: salmon

Benefit_5:

Full_citation: Quinn, T., Helfield, J., Austin, C., Hovel, R., & Bunn, A. (2018). A multidecade experiment shows that fertilization by salmon carcasses enhanced tree growth in the riparian zone. Ecology (Durham), 99(11), 2433-2441.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Experiment in which salmon carcasses were transferred from one side of the stream (depleted) to the other (enhanced), and researchers looked at the effect on tree growth and stable isotope ratios.
Location: Hansen Creek, Wood River System, Bristol Bay, AK
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW and riparian ecosystems
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "As they return to spawn and die in their natal streams, anadromous, semelparous fishes such as Pacific salmon import marine-derived nutrients to otherwise nutrient-poor freshwater and riparian ecosystems. " (2433)
Benefit_2:
ESB: trees
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Stable isotope analysis indicated that marine-derived N was incorporated into the new growth of the trees on the enhanced bank." (2433)
Benefit_3:
ESB: trees
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Analysis of tree cores indicated that in the two decades prior to our enhancement experiment, trees on the south-facing (subsequently the depleted) bank grew faster than those on the north-facing (later enhanced) bank. This difference was reduced significantly during the two decades of fertilization, indicating an effect of the carcass transfer experiment against the background of other factors affecting tree growth." (2433) --> tree growth
Benefit_4:
ESB: riparian and FW ecosystems
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Over the past several decades, increasing evidence has indicated that the return of anadromous, semelparous fishes to coastal rivers can bring great quantities of marine-derived nutrients to otherwise nutrient-poor freshwater and riparian ecosystems (Janetski et al. 2009, Naiman et al. 2009). These nutrients are transported upriver during spawning migrations by clupeids such as American shad (Alosa sapidissima) and alewife (A. pseudoharengus; MacAvoy et al. 2009, Twining et al. 2017), petromyzontids (Nislow and Kynard 2009), and Pacific salmon of the genus Oncorhynchus (Kline et al. 1990, Bilby et al. 1996, Janetski et al. 2009)." (2433)
Benefit_5:
ESB: insects, birds, other aquatic organisms
ESP: salmon

Benefit_6:
ESB: bears

Benefit_7:

(2434)

ESB: glaucous-winged gulls

Sentence describing benefit: "many salmon were killed by bears, and killing and scavenging of carcasses by Glaucous-winged Gulls is also common (Quinn and Buck 2001)." (2434)
Benefit_12:
ESB: terrestrial zone
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Average annual N contributions from these carcasses to the enhanced and depleted bank were 401.4 and 67.8 kg, respectively. Corresponding P contributions were 53.5 and 9.0 kg." (2437)
Benefit_13:
ESB: tree needles
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The needles on the enhanced bank had significantly higher d15N (mean 10.7; 95% CI: 7.5, 16.2) than did those on the depleted bank (mean 6.4; 95% CI: 3.2, 11.9; t84(2) = 7.65, P < 0.0001)" (2437)
Benefit_14:
ESB: white spruce
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "As predicted, the analysis of N stable isotope values of white spruce needles collected in 2016 revealed a significant difference between the two banks of Hansen Creek, consistent with fertilization from salmon carcasses" (2438)
Benefit_15:
ESB: soil
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The significantly higher foliar %MDN on the enhanced bank indicated a relatively quick response (i.e., within two decades), consistent with the findings of previous work indicating that salmon carcasses can deliver pulses of bioavailable N to forest soils within months of deposition (Drake et al. 2005)" (2438)
Benefit_16:
ESB: trees
ESP: historical presence of salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The fact that trees on the depleted bank still had such high %MDN values after 20 yr of artificial carcass depletion suggests that the foliar d15N signal, resulting from centuries of MDN inputs, may persist for at least two decades following a reduction in MDN inputs." (2438)
Benefit_17:
ESB: tree growth rate
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Growth rates were significantly lower on the left, northfacing bank prior to fertilization but were increased by the additions of salmon carcasses to the extent that they no longer differed significantly from those of the south-facing slope" (2439)
Benefit_18:
ESB: aquatic bugs + bacteria
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " In the water, they would have been decomposed by scavenging aquatic insects (Minakawa and Gara 1999, Winder et al. 2005) and bacteria. " (2439)
Benefit_19:
ESB: blowflies
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "If exposed to the air, many carcasses are scavenged by blowflies, which are an important source of nutrient transfer in this system (Meehan et al. 2005), as are terrestrial insects elsewhere (Hocking and Reimchen 2006, Hocking et al. 2009)." (2439)

Full_citation: Joy, P., Stricker, C., Ivanoff, R., Wipfli, M., Seitz, A., & Tyers, M. (2019). Bridging the Gap Between Salmon Spawner Abundance and Marine Nutrient Assimilation by Juvenile Salmon: Seasonal Cycles and Landscape Effects at the Watershed Scale. Ecosystems (New York), 23(2), 338-358.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors look at the effect of adult salmon spawner density on uptake of MDN by juvenile salmon AT A WATERSHED SCALE.
Benefit_1:
ESB: juvenile salmonids
ESP: spawning adults
Sentence describing benefit: "Anadromous Pacific salmon are semelparous, and resource subsidies from spawning adults (marine-derived nutrients, or MDN) benefit juvenile salmonids rearing in freshwater." (338)
Benefit_2:
ESB: juvenile salmon
ESP: adult spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "After adult spawning, MDN use by juvenile salmon was a product of spawner abundance." (339)
Benefit_3:
ESB: juvenile salmon
ESP: pink and chinook spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "MDN use by juveniles was related to pink and Chinook, but not chum, salmon biomass." (339)
Benefit_4:
ESB: terrestrial food webs
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Marine subsidies from spawning salmon are assimilated into freshwater and terrestrial food webs and can have large effects on multiple trophic levels. " (339)
Benefit_5:
ESB: biofilm + microbial community
ESP: salmon carcasses, adult salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "MDN from carcasses and fish excretion can stimulate stream biofilms and increase microbial productivity (Bilby and others 1996; Wipfli and others 1998; Gende and others 2002; Mitchell and Lamberti 2005). " (339)
Benefit_6:
ESB: terrestrial soil, bugs, plants
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Riparian vegetation, soil, and insect communities become enriched in MDN (Ben-David and others 1998; Reimchen and others 2002; Hocking and Reimchen 2009)" (339)
Benefit_7:
ESB: terrestrial scavengers (birds, bears, wolves)
ESP: adult salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "terrestrial scavengers, including birds, bears, and wolves feed on salmon and further disperse nutrients in the riparian zone (Hilderbrand and others 1999; Adams and others 2010). " (339)
Benefit_8:
ESB: aquatic food webs
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Within aquatic food webs, freshwater consumers, including juvenile salmon and other fishes, benefit from MDN through a variety of trophic pathways." (339)
Benefit_9:
ESB: juvenile salmon 
ESP: eggs, carcasses, fry, smolt
Sentence describing benefit: "Juvenile salmon feed directly on eggs and carcasses during the spawning season (Bilby and others 1998; Pearsons and Fritts 1999; Armstrong and others 2010) and on fry and smolt in the spring (Parker 1971; Hargreaves and LeBrasseur 1985; Ruggerone and Rogers 1992; Denton and others 2009)." (339)
Benefit_10:
ESB: stream production, inverts
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Indirectly, nitrogen and phosphorous from decaying carcasses are incorporated into aquatic and riparian food webs, thus increasing primary production and bolstering invertebrate communities (Wipfli and others 1999, 2003; Chaloner and others 2004; Hicks and others 2005; Lang and others 2006). " (339)
Benefit_11:
ESB: midge, caddisfly, stone flies, blowflies
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "invertebrates colonize and feed on salmon carcasses thus increasing the size and abundance of potential food items such as midge larvae (family Chironomidae; Chaloner and others 2004; Hicks and others 2005), caddisflies (order Trichoptera; Chaloner and Wipfli 2002; Winder and others 2005; Hicks and others 2005), stoneflies (order Plecoptera; Ellis 1970; Wipfli and others 1998), and blowflies (family Calliphoridae; Armstrong and others 2010)." (339)
Benefit_12:
ESB: juvenile coho salmon, Dolly Varden
ESP: adult spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Juvenile coho salmon exhibited increased growth (Wipfli and others 2003, 2010) and lipid content (Heintz and others 2004, 2010) in response to pink salmon carcasses, and coho salmon and Dolly Varden (Salvelinus malma) also demonstrated elevated growth rates and energy content with increasing salmon spawning density in Southcentral Alaska streams (Rinella and others 2012)." (339)
Benefit_13:
ESB: 1) juvenile coho, 2) coho, Dolly Varden, rainbow trout
ESP: 1) adult pink salmon, 2) sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "In British Columbia, juvenile coho salmon abundance was positively related to adult pink salmon abundance (Nelson and Reynolds 2014) and Sockeye Salmon in southwest Alaska have been shown to benefit stream-dwelling salmonids, including coho salmon, Dolly Varden, and Rainbow Trout (O. mykiss), by increasing ration size, body condition, and growth (Scheurell and others 2007; Denton and others 2009; Armstrong and others 2010).
Benefit_14:
ESB: juvenile coho and chinook
ESP: chinook and pink spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "After Chinook, chum, and pink salmon spawned, fall MDN assimilation was positively related to early summer MDN assimilation and pink and Chinook salmon spawning biomass from the current year, but unrelated to chum salmon biomass (Table 1 and Figure 6; marginal and conditional R2 from best model = 0.38 and 0.63, respectively)." (346)
Benefit_15:
ESB: juvenile salmon
ESP: spawning adults
Sentence describing benefit: "This study demonstrated that MDN assimilation in juvenile salmon is a function of species-specific spawner abundance and seasonality in MDN assimilation may be masked by high retention of MDN in complex habitat. " (348)
Benefit_16:
ESB: fall juvenile salmon
ESP: pink and chinook spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "In the fall, after spawning by pink, chum, and Chinook salmon, MDN assimilation by juvenile salmon was a product of both residual MDN (early summer MDN assimilation) and pink and Chinook salmon spawning biomass (Figures 6 and 8), but was not significantly related to habitat variables." (348)
Benefit_17:
ESB: juvenile salmon
ESP: pink salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pink salmon were the only species whose spawner biomass was associated with both pre-spawning early summer MDN (albeit weakly) and fall, post-spawning, MDN assimilation." (349)
Benefit_18:
ESB: smolt
ESP: adult spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Out-migrating smolts of both species demonstrated high MDN assimilation with levels similar to winter and late fall parr (Figure 3). " (353)
Benefit_19:
ESB:  juvenile salmon
ESP: pink and chum salmon smolts
Sentence describing benefit: "Subsequently, high MDN assimilation would be maintained on their way to the ocean as smolt migrated through enriched MDN areas (that is, Site 6; Figures 1 and 4) where they preyed on pink and chum salmon smolts and aquatic invertebrates associated with early summer MDN such as chloroperlid stoneflies (Ellis 1970; P. Joy, unpublished data)." (353)
Benefit_20:
ESB: juvenile salmon
ESP: spawning chinook and pink
Sentence describing benefit: "MDN assimilation in juvenile salmon in the fall, after annual spawning migrations, was reflective of pink and, to a lesser extent, Chinook salmon biomass and escapements, but pre-spawning MDN levels were more a function of habitat complexity and much less a function of spawner biomass from the previous year." (354)

Full_citation: Taal Levi, Grant V. Hilderbrand, Morgan D. Hocking, Thomas P. Quinn, Kevin S. White, Megan S. Adams, . . . Christopher C. Wilmers. (2020). Community Ecology and Conservation of Bear-Salmon Ecosystems. Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution, 8, Frontiers in ecology and evolution, 2020-12-01, Vol.8.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors review biogeography of bear-salmon interactions and the effect of salmon-consuming bears on different ecosystem functions and properties.
Essential_notes: -paper focused on the community-level
Benefit_1:
ESB: bears
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In temperate ecosystems throughout much of the Northern Hemisphere, abundant adult anadromous fishes, especially Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.; and perhaps historically Atlantic salmon, Salmo salar) support dense bear populations. Bear populations that consume more salmon have larger litters, greater body mass, and occur at much higher population densities than do bears with less access to such meat." (2)
Benefit_2:
ESB: brown bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, brown bears range from 5 bears per 1000 km2 in interior systems where salmon are rare or absent to over 500 bears per 1000 km2 in coastal regions where salmon are abundant (Hilderbrand et al., 1999b)." (2)
Benefit_3:
ESB: brown bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In Hokkaido, stable isotope analysis suggests that brown bears consume much less salmon, and terrestrial meat, than a century ago (Matsubayashi et al., 2015), which has resulted in a substantial reduction in the body size of bears (Matsubayashi et al., 2016). " (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: FW + terrestrial species
ESP: adult and carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Live and dead salmon provide a predictable pulsed resource for several hundred freshwater and terrestrial species of vertebrates and invertebrates throughout the Pacific Rim (Willson and Halupka, 1995; Cederholm et al., 1999; Gende et al., 2002; Hocking et al., 2009; Reimchen, 2017). " (3)
Benefit_5:
ESB: bears, scavengers
ESP: adult salmon, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "When salmon abundance is high, and stream habitat facilitates access (e.g., shallow water), bears feed selectively on energy-rich parts of fish (Gende et al., 2001), consuming as little as 25% of the salmon they kill (Lincoln and Quinn, 2018) and distributing carcass remains to vertebrate and invertebrate scavengers up to several hundred meters from waterways (Reimchen, 2000; Gende et al., 2001; Hocking and Reimchen, 2009; Levi et al., 2015). " (3-4)
Benefit_6:
ESB: terrestrial food webs
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The nutrients in these carcass remains can influence all trophic levels from primary producers to large carnivores in both terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems (Helfield and Naiman, 2006; Hocking and Reynolds, 2011)." (4)
Benefit_7:
ESB: terrestrial vertebrates
ESP: salmon, esp. carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Cederholm et al. (1999) reported that more than 80 species of terrestrial vertebrates feed regularly on adult salmon, ranging from shrews, mink, coyotes, and marten to corvids, bald eagles, and owls." (4)
Benefit_8:
ESB: riverine and coastal mink
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Ben-David et al. (1997b) found that nearly 60% of the diets of riverine mink (Neovison vison) and nearly a quarter of the diets of coastal mink were comprised of salmon in autumn, and the timing of reproduction in female mink was shifted in salmon ecosystems so that lactation coincided with salmon carcass availability (Ben-David, 1997). " (4)
Benefit_9:
ESB: marten
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Stable isotope analyses in Southeast Alaska indicated that salmon comprised a significant portion of marten (Martes americana) diet when rodents were scarce (Ben-David et al., 1997a). "(4)
Benefit_10:
ESB: wolves
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Behavioral, stable isotope, and fecal data from coastal British Columbia has found that wolves forage extensively on salmon with peaks on salmon consumption on islands (Darimont et al., 2003, 2008, 2009)." (4)
Benefit_11:
ESB: coyotes and red foxes
ESP: adult and carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Coyotes (Levi et al., 2015) and red foxes (Gard, 1971) have been observed both catching and scavenging salmon, but we are aware of no detailed research about the extent of salmon in their diets, the degree to which they predate or scavenge salmon, or the fitness benefits of salmon consumption." (4)
Benefit_12:
ESB: bobcat
ESP: adult coho salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Even less is known about consumption of salmon by felids, but in 2016 a park range in Olympic National Park filmed a bobcat catching a large coho salmon (Petri, 2016), suggesting that this may be an underappreciated ecological interaction. " (4)
Benefit_13:
ESB: birds
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Higher densities of passerine birds were also found in riparian forests bordering salmon-bearing streams versus non-salmon streams, perhaps because of increased densities of terrestrial invertebrates associated with salmon carcasses deposited on land by bears (Gende and Willson, 2001; Christie et al., 2008; Christie and Reimchen, 2008; Field and Reynolds, 2011). " (4)
Benefit_14:
ESB: bears, esp. brown bears
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Bears themselves can also be important scavengers of salmon as well as predators. Many salmon that die of senescence or are killed and partially consumed are subsequently consumed by brown bears (Lincoln et al., 2020)." (4)
Benefit_15:
ESB: invertebrates
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, a total of 60 species of invertebrates were collected from salmon carcasses from two streams in coastal British Columbia, which include obligate carrion specialists and more opportunistic scavengers or predators on salmon carcasses (Hocking et al., 2009)." (4)
Benefit_16:
ESB: invertebrates
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In coastal British Columbia and Alaska, three main groups of invertebrates dominate salmon carcass decomposition in terrestrial habitats: (1) the Diptera (flies) consisting of several dominant families, the Calliphoridae and Dryomyzidae, among others; (2) the Coleoptera (beetles), dominated by the Silphidae, Staphylinidae, and Leiodidae; and (3) parasitic Hymenoptera (wasps) (Ichneumonidae, Braconidae, Figitidae) (Meehan et al., 2005; Hocking and Reimchen, 2006; Hocking et al., 2009). " (4)
Benefit_17:
ESB: blowflies, plants
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, blow flies (Calliphoridae) were the numerically dominant consumers of salmon (Meehan et al., 2005) and can time their summer emergence to the timing of sockeye salmon spawning in Alaska, which also secondarily affects the bloom timing of plant species that rely on flies as pollinators (Lisi and Schindler, 2011)." (4-5)
Benefit_18:
ESB: burying beetle
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Among the Coleoptera, the burying beetles (Silphidae), such as Nicrophorus investigator, exhibit specialized communal breeding of many females per carcass to produce up to 750 larvae (Hocking and Reimchen, 2006; Hocking et al., 2009)." (5)
Benefit_19:
ESB: parasitic wasps
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In another trophic connection related to bears, several species of parasitic wasps (Ichneumonidae: Atractodes sp., and Braconidae: Alysia alticola) parasitize the fly larvae that consume salmon carcasses (Hocking et al., 2009). Stable isotope analysis of these invertebrates indicates that they occur at very high trophic positions (equivalent to harbor seals and walruses), suggesting that nearly all of their biomass is derived from salmon (Hocking et al., 2009)." (5)
Benefit_20:
ESB: riparian plants
ESP: salmon carcasses via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Bears can also distribute salmon nutrients to terrestrial ecosystems through distribution of their urine and feces (Hilderbrand et al., 1999a), which is taken up by riparian plants living beside wildlife trails (Wilkinson et al., 2005)." (5)
Benefit_21:
ESB: streamside plants
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Studies of the role of salmon in riparian plant nutrition have typically found increasing stable isotope ratios of heavy to light nitrogen (δ15N) in plant leaves across natural gradients in salmon spawning density or beside salmon carcass sites (Bilby et al., 2003; Bartz and Naiman, 2005; Nagasaka et al., 2006; Hocking and Reimchen, 2009; Holtgrieve et al., 2009; Hocking and Reynolds, 2012; Reimchen, 2017; Walsh et al., 2020). This suggests that salmon carcasses, which contain higher δ15N (∼12‰) than terrestrial sources of N (∼0‰), provide an important source of nitrogen to streamside plants." (5)
Benefit_22:
ESB: plants (physiology)
ESP: salmon carcasses via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon subsidies increase foliar %N, decrease foliar C/N ratio and can even increase foliar stomatal density (Hocking and Reynolds, 2011; Hocking and Reynolds, 2012; van den Top et al., 2018). " (5)
Benefit_23:
ESB: riparian trees and plants
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "At larger scales, inputs of salmon nutrients can increase the productivity of the riparian zone, increase tree growth and shift plant communities toward species adapted to nutrient-rich sites (Helfield and Naiman, 2006; Hocking and Reynolds, 2011; Reimchen, 2017). For example, in a recent multi-decade fertilization experiment where salmon carcasses were moved by researchers into the forest along a 2 km stretch of one bank of a stream but not the other, long-term salmon carcass fertilization resulted in increased tree growth on the bank that was fertilized, though the effect was small compared to other factors (Quinn et al., 2018)." (5
Benefit_24:
ESB: riparian ecosystems
ESP: salmon carcasses via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Bear foraging on salmon increases marine nutrient retention in watersheds, which thus alters how plants access, use and compete for these resources. When the bear-salmon association is maintained long-term, plant community assembly may be altered such that the riparian zone is dominated by nutrient-loving species from diverse phylogenies rather than closely related species (e.g., the Ericaceae) in a phylogenetic cluster that are specifically adapted to low nutrient environments (Hocking and Reynolds, 2011; Hurteau et al., 2016). Therefore, particularly in small watersheds where floodplain processes are less dominant, bears can mediate key riparian ecosystem processes such as plant palatability and litter quality, rates of N turnover, berry production, and plant resource allocation toward stem and leaf growth rather than root development and foliar defense." (5)
Benefit_25:
ESB: stream-resident fish
ESP: salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "While egg consumption saturates for individual consumers, large pulses of egg availability provide feeding opportunities to less dominant sizes and species of fish (Bailey and Moore, 2020). " (5)
Benefit_26:
ESB: bears
ESP: spawning females
Sentence describing benefit: "Moreover, to the extent that they can, bears preferentially kill newly arrived salmon (Gende et al., 2004) and, in the case of females, preferentially consume their eggs (Lincoln and Quinn, 2018)." (5)
Benefit_27:
ESB: stream-resident fish
ESP: salmon carcasses via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon carcasses also indirectly benefit piscivorous fish by subsidizing aquatic invertebrates such as caddisflies (Trichoptera) and stoneflies (Plecoptera) that adapt shredding mouthparts to colonize and consume salmon carcasses with higher colonization efficiency for bear-killed than senescent salmon (Minakawa and Gara, 1999; Winder et al., 2005). " (6)
Benefit_28:
ESB: fly and beetle larvae
ESP: salmon carcasses via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Bears also facilitate the colonization of salmon carcasses on land by fly and beetle larvae, which provide a “value added” trophic resource for resident fish by transforming salmon flesh depleted by the energetic requirements of migration and spawning activity into energy-dense invertebrate larvae. " (6)
Benefit_29:
ESB: stream resident fish
ESP: bugs via salmon carcasses on land
Sentence describing benefit: "Fall rains wash larvae back into streams, and provide energy rich prey for stream fishes (e.g., Denton et al., 2009)." (6)
Benefit_30:
ESB: brown bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Brown bears traverse watersheds to consume salmon from multiple populations that spawn at different times (Schindler et al., 2013; Deacy et al., 2016)." (6)
Benefit_31:
ESB: freshwater fish
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Overall, the marine-based diets and population productivities of freshwater fishes such as sculpins (Cottus spp.), Dolly Varden (Salvelinus malma), and juvenile coho salmon (O. kisutch) are positively related to increasing salmon spawning densities in streams (Bilby et al., 1998; Wipfli et al., 2003; Denton et al., 2009; Swain and Reynolds, 2015)" (6)
Benefit_32:
ESB: brown bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In salmon systems, the energy requirements of brown bears are often largely derived from salmon (Figure 5). Bears are by far the dominant predator of salmon (Levi et al., 2015; Quinn, 2018)" (10)
Benefit_33:
ESB: plants
ESP: brown bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Further, Shakeri et al. (2018) demonstrated that brown bears in salmon systems dispersed far more seeds, from 12 distinct plant species, than previously recognized. " (11)

Full_citation: Hilderbrand, G., Hanley, T., Robbins, C., & Schwartz, C. (1999). Role of Brown Bears (Ursus arctos) in the Flow of Marine Nitrogen into a Terrestrial Ecosystem. Oecologia, 121(4), 546-550.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors estimate the amount and inflluence of salmon-derived nutrients on the terrestrial landscape of Kenai Peninsula
Benefit_1:
ESB: white spruce
ESP: spawning salmon (via brown bears)
Sentence describing benefit: "We tested and confirmed the hypothesis that the stable isotope signature (6'5N) of N in foliage of white spruce (Picea glauca) was inversely proportional to the distance from salmon-spawning streams (r=-0.99 and P<0.05 in two separate watersheds" (546)
Benefit_2:
ESB: terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: adult salmon via brown bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Mean rates of redistribution of salmon-derived N by adult female brown bears were 37.2±2.9 kg/year per bear (range 23.1-56.3), of which 96% (35.7±2.7 kg/year per bear) was excreted in urine, 3% (1.1+0.1 kg/year per bear) was excreted in feces, and <1% (0.3± 0.1 kg/year per bear) was retained in the body" (546)
Benefit_3:
ESB: terrestrial ecosystems

Benefit_4:
ESB: mammals and birds

Benefit_6:
ESB: FW and terrestrial ecosystems

Benefit_8:
ESB: Sitka spruce, devil's club, fern

Benefit_9:
ESB: sitka spruce
ESP: spawning salmon

ESB: salmon nursery

Benefit_8:

Full_citation: Bartz, K., & Naiman, R. (2005). Effects of Salmon-Borne Nutrients on Riparian Soils and Vegetation in Southwest Alaska. Ecosystems (New York), 8(5), 529-545.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Quantifying effect of MDN from salmon on soil and vegetation located upstream and downstream of spawning sites.
Location: Wood, Kvichak, and Naknek river systems, AK, USA
Essential_notes: -how and where and for how long MDN is stored will depend on the riparian system
Benefit_1:
ESB: riparian ecosystems
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Spawning Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) contribute marine-derived nutrients to riparian ecosystems" (529)
Benefit_2:
ESB: soil and picea glauca
ESP: spawning salmon 
Sentence describing benefit: "Of the ten soil and vegetative characteristics that differed upstream to downstream, two (O horizon and Picea glauca 815N) were correlated with the density of spawning salmon" (529)
Benefit_3:
ESB: lakes and streams
ESP: anadromous pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Anadromous Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) transfer nutrients from the ocean, where they mature, to oligotrophic lakes and streams, where they spawn and die." (529)
Benefit_4:
ESB: FW foodwebs
ESP: salmon carcasses and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "The nutrients enter freshwater foodwebs, either through consumption of salmon carcasses and eggs (Eastman 1996, Bilby and others 1998) or through incorporation of carcass byproducts released during decomposition (Piorkowski 1995, Schuldt and Hershey 1995)." (529)
Benefit_5:
ESB: riparian ecosystems
ESP: salmon via predators, scavengers, floods, and hyporheic flowpaths
Sentence describing benefit: " The transfer of salmon-borne nutrients extends to riparian ecosystems through redistribution by predators, scavengers, floods and hyporheic flow paths (Cederholm and others 1989, Ben-David and others 1998, O'Keefe and Edwards 2002)." (529)
Benefit_6:
ESB: sitka spruce
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Helfield and Naiman (2001) found increased growth rates in Sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis) near spawning streams in southeast Alaska." (530)
Benefit_7:
ESB: white spruce
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "A similar study reported increased growth rates in white spruce (Picea glauca) near spawning streams in southwest Alaska, but the increase was contingent upon the absence of N-fixing green alder (Alnus crispa, Helfield and Naiman 2002)" (530)
Benefit_8:
ESB: understory vegetation
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "A third study reported increased cover and diversity in understory vegetation, as well as increased cover, density and diversity in ground layer vegetation near spawning streams in Washington State (Bilby and others 2003)." (530)
Benefit_9:
ESB: soil
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "differences in O horizon d15N increased with spawning density (r=0.63, p=0.05, Figure 3a)" (537)
Benefit_10:
ESB: white spruce
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Likewise, differences in white spruce d15N increased with spawning density (r=0.78, p=0.04, Figure 3d)" (537)
Benefit_11:
ESB: soil
ESP: salmon carcasses, spawning
Sentence describing benefit: "recent studies in British Columbia found significant soil 15N enrichment at sites with high salmon carcass density and piscivore activity (Morris 2002, Reimchen and others 2003)" (538)
Benefit_12:
ESB: soil, terrestrial vegetation, terrestrial herbivores, streams
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon-borne nutrients arrive in forms both available and unavailable to plants. Soils retain some portion of these inputs, enriching O horizon and surface mineral soil S15N. Vegetation obtains another portion, causing comparable enrichment in foliar S15N. Vegetative uptake also alters community structure and composition. Overstory stem density increases, perhaps through the accelerated growth of willows, while understory stem density decreases, perhaps through shading or herbivory. Ground layer non-vascular and dwarf shrub covers also decrease, possibly through displacement by other ground layer species. Together, these differences should increase the standing stocks of nutrients, the quality of allochthonous inputs to streams, and the quality of food for terrestrial herbivores" (543)

Full_citation: Compton, J., Andersen, C., Phillips, D., Brooks, J., Johnson, M., Church, M., . . . Shaff, C. (2006). Ecological and Water Quality Consequences of Nutrient Addition for Salmon Restoration in the Pacific Northwest. Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment, 4(1), 18-26.
Journal: Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors respond to the practice of adding nutrients to streams (via carcasses, analogs, etc.) by looking at potential effects (adverse or otherwise) and recommending additional monitoring to determine whether the practice is indeed successful.
Essential_notes:
-similar to paper 47, where and how and for how long MDN is stored varies by stream system: "Bilby et al. (1996) found that primary production accounted for only a small proportion of SDN incorporation in a western Washington stream; main pathways were direct consumption by insects and juvenile fish, sorption to the streambed, and uptake by secondary producers." (21)
-increases in stream ammonium is only a service if the stream benefits from that; artificially inflating an already high ammonium concentration can lead to algal blooms and eutrophication
Benefit_1:
ESB: invertebrates, fish, and wildlife
ESP: salmon carcasses and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Carcass flesh and eggs can be directly consumed by invertebrates, fish, and wildlife, while inorganic and mineral-associated nutrients have little direct food value for invertebrates and fish" (20)
Benefit_2:
ESB: FW foodwebs
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Salmon carcasses are a seasonal source of organic matter and are incorporated into stream food webs via two dominant pathways: primary production, or uptake by stream algae after decay into inorganic forms; and secondary production, or the consumption of eggs and flesh by heterotrophic microbes, invertebrates, fish, or mammals (Figure 2)." (20)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream foodwebs
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The response of primary production to salmon carcass addition has varied from no increase (Minshall et al. 1991), to an increase in primary production only (Richey et al. 1975), and to increased primary production as one of many responses (Wipfli et al. 1998)." (20)
Benefit_4:
ESB: FW foodwebs
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Bilby et al. (1996) found that primary production accounted for only a small proportion of SDN incorporation in a western Washington stream; main pathways were direct consumption by insects and juvenile fish, sorption to the streambed, and uptake by secondary producers." (21)
Benefit_5:
ESB: aquatic invertebrates
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon carcasses can increase biomass and growth of aquatic invertebrates (Wipfli et aL 1998), which could indirectly increase fish production" (21)
Benefit_6:
ESB: invertebrates and juvenile fish
ESP: salmon flesh and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Incorporation of SDN into stream food webs largely occurs via consumption of eggs and flesh by invertebrates and juvenile fish (Chaloner et al.2002)" (21)
Benefit_7:
ESB: salmonids
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Experiments have shown that carcass addition increased growth, condition, and density of salmonids in some PNW streams (Bilby et aL 1998; Wipfli et al. 2003)" (21)
Benefit_8:
ESB: forests
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Examination of stable N isotope ratios provides evidence that returning salmon contribute to forest nutrient pools." (21)
Benefit_9:
ESB: AK streams
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Stream ammonium increased following large returns of Alaskan salmon (Jauquet et al.2003). " (22)
Benefit_10:
ESB: scientists
ESP: juvenile salmon

Benefit_11:
ESB: mink
ESP: spawning salmon

Benefit_12:

Full_citation: Johnston, N., MacIsaac, E., Tschaplinski, P., & Hall, K. (2004). Effects of the abundance of spawning sockeye salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka) on nutrients and algal biomass in forested streams. Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences, 61(3), 384-403.

Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors studied how spawner biomass affects particulate organic matter inputs to streams.
Essential_notes: -again, authors note that degree of influence of salmon on stream chem will vary based on "magnitude, timing, and distribution of spawning runs, carcass retention capactiy, nutrient storage capacity, water temperature and discharge, background inputs of nutrients and allochthonous organic matter, and the composition of the biological community" (385)
Benefit_1:
ESB: stream
ESP: sockeye salmon

Benefit_3:

ESP: salmon carcasses

ESP: carcasses and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Elsewhere direct feeding on carcass tissue and eggs by insects and fish (Bilby et al. 1998; Chaloner et al. 2002) has been important." (397)
Benefit_8:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon carcasses

Benefit_9:

Full_citation: Wipfli, M., Hudson, J., & Caouette, J. (2004). Restoring Productivity of Salmon‐Based Food Webs: Contrasting Effects of Salmon Carcass and Salmon Carcass Analog Additions on Stream‐Resident Salmonids. Transactions of the American Fisheries Society (1900), 133(6), 1440-1454.
Journal: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors looked at whether salmon carcasses increased condition factor, production, and whole body lipid content of stream-resident fish and the effect of stream shading on that enrichment.
Benefit_1:
ESB: stream-resident fish
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Production and lipid content significantly increased in both carcass and analog treatments. " (1440)
Benefit_2:
ESB: cutthroat trout
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In addition, in a small stream where salmon carcasses and analogs were added to two separate tributaries, cutthroat trout O. clarki had higher mean condition, production, and lipid content than fish in stream sections that were not enriched (6 August to 20 2002)." (1440)
Benefit_3:
ESB: juvenile coho salmon
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Furthermore, coho salmon production was also higher in an analog-enriched reach than in control reaches." (1440)
Benefit_4:
ESB: resident and anadromous salmonids
ESP: salmon spawners and carcass analogs
Sentence describing benefit: "This study illustrates that marine subsidies from salmon spawners and salmon analogs increase condition, production, and lipid concentrations of resident and anadromous salmonids." (1440)
Benefit_5:
ESB: juvenile fish
ESP: anadromous Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Fishes such as Pacific salmon Oncorhynchus spp. and eulachon Thaleichthys pacificus hatch in freshwater but spend most of their lives in salt water, sequestering nutrients and carbon derived from or produced in the ocean (Levy 1997; Willson et al. 1998). After returning to freshwater as reproductively mature adults, they mate, spawn, and die; in the process, they deposit nutrients and energy-rich carbon in the same habitats their young will soon occupy. " (1440)
Benefit_6:
ESB: stream-resident salmonids
ESP: salmon eggs and tissue
Sentence describing benefit: " Bilby et al. (1996) showed that stream-resident salmonids consumed salmon eggs and tissue in two Washington streams, and that marine-derived nitrogen and carbon were subsequently taken up by these fishes, as evidenced by the presence of 15N and 13C in body tissues. " (1440)
Benefit_7:
ESB: stream-resident salmonids and aquatic insects
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Chaloner et al. (2002) found that stream-resident salmonids in southeastern Alaska, as well as lower trophic levels including biofilm and several species of aquatic insects, incorporated marine N (up to 73%) and C (up to 52%) in their tissues." (1440)
Benefit_8:
ESB: stream chem, insects, fish
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "These marine nutrients appear to increase food web productivity, elevating stream biofilm and chlorophyll-a levels (Wipfli et al. 1999), invertebrate densities and growth rates (Wipfli et al. 1998; Minakawa and Gara 1999; Chaloner et al. 2002; Chaloner and Wipfli 2002), and fish growth rates and biomass (Bilby et al. 1998; Wipfli et al. 2003)." (1440)
Benefit_9:
ESB: juvenile coho
ESP: salmon carcasses 
Sentence describing benefit: " Heintz et al. (2004) found elevated levels of triacylglycerides (energy reserves) and marine-derived fatty acids (omega-3 fatty acids) in juvenile coho salmon O. kisutch exposed to salmon carcasses, which could lead to increased survival, reproduction, and overall performance (Adams 1998; Olsen 1998)." (1441)
Benefit_10:
ESB: juvenile coho salmon
ESP: carcasses/analogs
Sentence describing benefit: "Coho salmon production was significantly higher in enriched channels (analog P < 0.001; carcass P = 0.002) than in control channels (Table 4; Figure 3). " (1447)
Benefit_11:
ESB: juvenile coho salmon
ESP: carcasses/analog
Sentence describing benefit: "Lipid levels were significantly higher in coho salmon within the enrichment treatments (analog P = 0.002; carcass P = 0.004) than in those from the control treatment (Table 4; Figure 4). " (1448)
Benefit_12:
ESB: cutthroat trout
ESP: carcasses/analog
Sentence describing benefit: "Cutthroat trout condition was significantly higher in both analog-enriched (P = 0.017) and carcass-enriched (P = 0.012) reaches relative to the upstream control reaches (Table 5; Figure 5A), suggesting a possible treatment effect. " (1448-9)
Benefit_13:
ESB: juvenile cutthroat trout, coho
ESP: salmon carcasses/analogs
Sentence describing benefit: "Whole-body lipid levels were higher in fish from the enriched reaches than in those from the control reaches. " (1449)
Benefit_14:

ESP: carcasses/analogs

Benefit_15:
ESB: stream fish and stream bugs
ESP: salmon carcasses and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: ". Biofilm mass and invertebrate densities in southeastern Alaska streams sharply increased following enrichment from salmon carcasses and eggs; more aquatic invertebrates, especially chironomid midges, a key prey category, were provided for stream-resident cutthroat trout, coho salmon, and Dolly Varden (Wipfli 1997). " (1450)

Full_citation: Lang, D., Reeves, G., Hall, J., & Wipfli, M. (2006). The influence of fall-spawning coho salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) on growth and production of juvenile coho salmon rearing in beaver ponds on the Copper River Delta, Alaska. Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences, 63(4), 917-930.
Journal: Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors compared juvenile coho density, growth rate, body condition, and survival to outmigration for three treatments: 1) beaver ponds that received spawners, 2) beaver ponds that did not receive spawners, and 3) beaver ponds artificially enriched with carcasses and eggs.
Essential_notes:
-Limited effects: "However, there was little evidence that the short-term growth benefits observed in the fall led to greater overwinter growth or survival to outmigration when compared with fish from the nonspawning ponds." (917)
-Authors recommend including eggs when managers try to enrich streams for next gen salmon
Benefit_1:
ESB: juvenile coho
ESP: fall spawning coho
Sentence describing benefit: "In some ponds, fall-spawning salmon increased growth rates and improved the condition of juvenile coho salmon" (917)
Benefit_2:
ESB: juvenile coho
ESP: carcasses and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "The enrichment with salmon carcasses and eggs significantly increased growth rates of fish in nonspawning ponds. " (917)
Benefit_3:
ESB: streams, secondary consumers
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Studies have revealed that this process influences primary productivity of streams (Richey et al. 1975; Wipfli et al. 1998) and the population dynamics and growth of secondary consumers (Wipfli et al. 1999), including juvenile salmonids (Eastman 1996; Bilby et al. 1998; Wipfli et al. 2003). " (917-8)
Benefit_4:
ESB: stream-resident fish, including juvenile salmonids
ESP:  carcasses and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Fish can feed directly on carcasses and eggs (Bilby et al. 1998)." (918)
Benefit_5:
ESB: stream-resident fish, including juvenile salmonids
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Nutrients from carcasses can also be obtained by fish through the consumption of macroinvertebrates that feed directly on carcasses and on fungi and bacteria that colonize decaying carcasses (Wipfli et al. 1999). " (918)
Benefit_6:
ESB: stream-resident fish, including juvenile salmonids
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Spawning salmon can also increase invertebrate prey availability by their disturbance of streambed substrates that can dislodge benthic organisms (Peterson and Foote 2000)." (918)
Benefit_7:
ESB: anadromous salmonids and resident trout
ESP: salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon eggs can make up a large portion of the diet of juvenile anadromous salmonids and resident trout during spawning (Eastman 1996; Bilby et al. 1998). Eggs are a high calorie food item (Bilby et al. 1998; Foote and Brown 1998), so their consumption can have short-term as well as long-term benefits." (918)
Benefit_8:
ESB: juvenile coho
ESP: enrichment via carcasses + eggs, natural spawning
Sentence describing benefit: "At the individual pond level, the enrichment, and to some degree natural spawning, had immediate positive influences on the growth rate and body condition of juvenile coho salmon in the fall. These results are consistent with other studies concerning the influence of spawning on the growth of juvenile salmonids (Bilby et al. 1998; Wipfli et al. 2003). These studies were conducted in small stream habitats and artificial channels. Our study confirms that egg and carcass additions can be successful in boosting the short-term growth of juvenile coho salmon rearing in natural beaver pond habitats as well." (927)
Benefit_9:
ESB: juvenile coho
ESP: salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon eggs appeared to be the main resource responsible for increased growth and body condition during enrichment. The diets of fish in the enriched ponds were dominated by eggs (Hicks et al. 2005). During the enrichment, most whole carcasses were intact, with minimal conditioning or decomposition, thus making them unavailable as an immediate food source to juvenile coho salmon. Salmon eggs, on the other hand, were immediately available for consumption by fish in these ponds. Diet analysis of the fish rearing in these ponds confirmed that few juvenile coho salmon consumed carcass flesh during the enrichment (Hicks et al. 2005)." (927)
Benefit_10:
ESB: juvenile coho, rainbow trout, Arctic char
ESP: spawning sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Eastman (1996) found that juvenile coho salmon, rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss), and Arctic char (Salvelinus alpinus) exhibited increased growth and body condition during spawning by sockeye salmon in the Wood Lakes system, Alaska." (928)

Full_citation: Merz, J., & Moyle, P. (2006). Salmon, Wildlife, and Wine: Marine-Derived Nutrients in Human-Dominated Ecosystems of Central California. Ecological Applications, 16(3), 999-1009.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors looked at riparian transfer for two rivers in wine county California, one with Chinook and one without salmon.
Location: Mokelumne and Calaveras rivers, wine county California, USA (San Francisco, Sacramento area)
Benefit_1:
ESB: forest ecosystems
ESP: Pacific salmon

Benefit_2:
ESB: Wine grapes and native vegetation
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Native riparian vegetation as well as cultivated wine grapes adjacent to Mokelumne River spawning sites received 18-25% of foliar N from marine sources, significantly higher than vegetation along the Calaveras River" (999)
Benefit_3:
ESB: terrestrial and aquatic organisms
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Because of their large populations and body sizes, Pacific salmon {Oncorhynchus spp.) are a major food source for terrestrial and aquatic organisms associated with spawning streams, from bears {Ursus spp) to bacteria (Willson et al. 1998, Cederholm et al. 1999, Hilderbrand et al. 1999b)" (999)
Benefit_4:
ESB: oligotrophic stream
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "These tissues provide an important nutrient and energy subsidy to oligotrophic streams where the salmon spawn and eventually die (Willson and Halupka 1995, Wipfli et al. 1998)." (999)
Benefit_5:
ESB: FW streams
ESP: spawning salmon, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Spawning salmon release nutrients into streams through normal metabolic processes, release of gametes, consumption of salmon flesh by predators and scavengers, and decay of carcasses." (999)
Benefit_6:
ESB: terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " Recently, the use of stable isotopes to trace trophic pathways has revealed that marine-derived nutrients from Pacific salmon are transferred not only into aquatic ecosystems, but into adjacent terrestrial ecosystems (Chaloner et al. 2002, Helfield and Naiman 2002, Bilby et al. 2003)." (999)
Benefit_7:
ESB: vertebrates
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Densities of many vertebrates increase around streams in which salmon are spawning as they move in from surrounding areas to feed on the salmon (Gende et al. 2002)." (999)
Benefit_8:
ESB: terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: salmon via scavengers
Sentence describing benefit: "Terrestrial scavengers may move 58% to 90% of all salmon biomass to land, sometimes hundreds of meters from the stream (Reimchen 2000), providing a transport mechanism for as much as 85% of MDN uptake of riparian foliage within 0.5 km of the spawning channel (Hilderbrand et al. 1999a)." (1000)
Benefit_9:
ESB: aquatic invertebrates and fish, trees
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "The salmon subsidy results in an increase in the abundance and growth rates of aquatic invertebrates and fish (Wipfli et al. 2003) and riparian tree production (Helfield and Naiman 2001)." (1000)
Benefit_10:
ESB: juvenile salmon
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon-derived nutrients are also part of a positive feedback loop that benefits salmon populations. These nutrients cause aquatic and terrestrial insect populations to increase, resulting in faster growth and higher survival rates in juvenile salmon (Larkin and Slaney 1997)." (1000)
Benefit_11:
ESB: juvenile, spawning salmon
ESP: tree LWD via salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "The complexity of stream habitat, important for both juvenile and spawning salmon, also increases when large, salmon-fertilized trees fall into the water." (1000)
Benefit_12:
ESB: commercial and recreational fisheries
ESP: salmon

Benefit_13:
ESB: streams
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "This suggests that annual spawning migrations bring as much as 6690 kg (average 4587 kg) of MDN and 35 288 kg (average 24 195 kg) of carbon to the LMR watershed each year, similar to observations in more pristine habitats of the Pacific Northwest (Table 1" (1004)
Benefit_14:
ESB: vertebrates
ESP: salmon carcasses

Benefit_15:
ESB: turkey vultures, racoons, cats
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Turkey Vultures and raccoons were the most common frequenters of salmon carcasses on the Mokelumne River, while Turkey Vultures and a domestic cat were most common on the Calaveras River." (1005)
Benefit_16:
ESB: Fremont cottonwood
ESP: spawning Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Foliar r 515N of Fremont cottonwood was significantly higher at spawning sites than reference sites on the Mokelumne (F= 59.9271, df = 1, 15, P < 0.0001) and Calaveras (F = 59.9271, df = 1, 15, P < 0.0001) rivers and significantly higher on Mokelumne River spawning sites than those on the Calaveras River" (1005)
Benefit_17:
ESB: sandbar willow

Benefit_18:
ESB: wine grapes
ESP: spawning Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: ". Foliar 515N of wine grapes was significantly higher at spawning sites relative to reference sites on the Mokelumne (F = 40.1806, df = 1, 38, P < 0.0001) and Calaveras" (1005)
Benefit_19:
ESB: riparian vegetation (including wine grapes)
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " We estimate that Mokelumne River riparian vegetation, including cultivated wine grapes, adjacent to spawning sites, derived 18-25% of N from a marine source (Table 1), similar to other studies" (1005)
Benefit_20:

Full_citation: Wiese, F., Parrish, J., Thompson, C., & Maranto, C. (2008). Ecosystem-Based Management of Predator-Prey Relationships: Piscivorous Birds and Salmonids. Ecological Applications, 18(3), 681-700.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Bioenergetics estimation of avian consumption of salmonid smolts.
Location: Columbia River Basin, USA and Canada
Essential_notes: -Paper written in context of controlling predation to improve smolt survivorship
Benefit_1:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: Columbia River salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The Columbia River Basin spans over 640 000 km2 and once supported one of the most productive salmon fisheries in the world, with an estimated 7-15 million anadromous fish returning to spawn each year (McClure et al. 2003)" (682)
Benefit_2:
ESB: avian predators
ESP: smolts
Sentence describing benefit: "Piscine predators in the Columbia River basin, exemplified by northern pikeminnow (Zimmerman and Ward 1999), and a suite of avian predators including gulls (Larus spp.), terns (Steminae spp.; York et al. 2000, Collis et al. 2001), Double-crested Cormorants (Phalacrocorax auritus; Collis et al. 2002), and Common Mergansers (Mergus merganser) are known or thought to consume a nontrivial fraction of the outmigrating salmonid smolts." (682)
Benefit_3:
ESB: pike minnow, caspian terns
ESP: smolts
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, pikeminnow consumption is estimated at 8% of total basin production (Beamesderfer et al. 1996), and Caspian Terns (Hydroprogne caspia) in the lower Columbia River removed an estimated 15% of juvenile salmonids that reached the estuary in 1997 and 1998 (Roby et al. 2003)" (682)
Benefit_4:
ESB: birds
ESP: anadromous salmonids
Sentence describing benefit: "A total of 30 different species of fish were found in stomachs (proventriculus and gizzard) of birds shot below Rock Island Dam (mid-Columbia River, Washington, USA) (Appendix B), including four anadromous salmonid species" (688)
Benefit_5:
ESB: birds
ESP: sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "With the exception of 2003, sockeye dominated the salmonid portion of. the avian diet during the early period" (690)
Benefit_6:
ESB: birds
ESP: Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Chinook, presumably sub-yearling chinook, dominated the late period in all years (>76%)." (690)
Benefit_7:
ESB: gulls
ESP: smolts
Sentence describing benefit: "Calculating the past salmonid-consumption scenario for the early season only, we estimate that gulls congregating at dams may have consumed roughly 15647 smolts per year (95% CI 13226-18 387) during 1979-1983. By comparison, early period gulls during 2002-2004 consumed 8207 to 12999 salmonid smolts per year" (694)
Benefit_8:
ESB: common mergansers
ESP: smolt
Sentence describing benefit: "Within the time frame of this study, Common Mergansers were clearly the most important salmonid smolt predator at the population level. Adults collectively consumed just over half of all smolts estimated to have been taken by birds in the study area (Table 2)." (696)

Full_citation: Ford, J., Ellis, G., Olesiuk, P., & Balcomb, K. (2010). Linking killer whale survival and prey abundance: Food limitation in the oceans' apex predator? Biology Letters (2005), 6(1), 139-142.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors looked at resource limitation for two populations of killer whales over 25 years.
Type_of_salmon: Chum, pink, sockeye, but ESP. chinook
Essential_notes: -Authors looked at both northern and southern resident populations
Benefit_1:
ESB: killer whales
ESP: marine Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Here we show, using 25 years of demographic data from two populations of fish-eating killer whales in the northeastern Pacific Ocean, that population trends are driven largely by changes in survival, and that survival rates are strongly correlated with the availability of their principal prey species, Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha). Our results suggest that, although these killer whales may consume a variety of fish species, they are highly specialized and dependent on this single salmonid species to an extent that it is a limiting factor in their population dynamics." (139)
Benefit_2:
ESB: resident killer whales
ESP: marine salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Resident killer whales feed on fishes, particularly salmon, but do not prey on marine mammals, while transient killer whales prey on marine mammals but do not feed on fishes (Ford et al. 1998). " (139)
Benefit_3:
ESB: resident killer whales
ESP: marine Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Resident killer whales are primarily salmonid predators that show strong selectivity for Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha), probably because of this species' comparatively large size, high lipid content, and year-round availability in the whales' coastal habitat (Ford & Ellis 2006). " (139)
Benefit_4:
ESB: resident killer whales
ESP: marine chum
Sentence describing benefit: "Migrating chum salmon (Oncorhynchus keta), the second largest of the Pacific salmonids, are important prey during autumn although Chinook are targeted preferentially when available. " (139)
Benefit_5:
ESB: resident killer whales
ESP: pink and sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "The smaller but seasonally abundant sockeye (Oncorhynchus nerka) and pink salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha), and some demersal fishes such as lingcod (Ophiodon elongatus) and Pacific halibut (Hippoglossus stenolepis), are consumed by resident killer whales but there is no evidence that these species comprise an important component of their diet." (139)
Benefit_6:
ESB: killer whale populations and survivorship
ESP: Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: " This period of reduced Chinook abundance coincided distinctly with the period of unusually high mortalities in both resident killer whale populations. Mortality indices were most strongly correlated with changes in Chinook abundance after a lag of 1 year (figure 2a; F1,22 = 76.7, r2 = 0.777, p < 0.001; see the electronic supplementary material). Birth rate indices, also lagged by 1 year, showed a weaker but significant positive correlation with range-wide Chinook abundance indices (figure 2b; F1,23 = 6.77, r2 = 0.227, p < 0.05)." (140)

Full_citation: Schindler, D., Hilborn, R., Chasco, B., Boatright, C., Quinn, T., Rogers, L., & Webster, M. (2010). Population diversity and the portfolio effect in an exploited species. Nature (London), 465(7298), 609-612.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors argue that sockeye diversity is to be thanked for consistency in escapements from year to year.
Benefit_1:
ESB: fisheries
ESP: sockeye diversity
Sentence describing benefit: "Variability in annual Bristol Bay salmon returns is 2.2 times lower than it would be if the system consisted of a single homogenous population rather than the several hundred discrete populations it currently consists of. Furthermore, if it were a single homogeneous population, such increased variability would lead to ten times more frequent fisheries closures" (609)
Benefit_2:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "From 1950 to 2008, sockeye salmon supported the most valuable fisheries in the United States (landed value, US$7,900,000,000), and 63% of the associated revenue came from Bristol Bay (see Supplementary Information for details)." (609)
Benefit_3:
ESB: unclear
ESP: sockeye salmon

Benefit_4:
ESB: Bristol Bay communities, schools
ESP: sockeye salmon, landings
Sentence describing benefit: "Income from sockeye salmon in Bristol Bay is the major source of personal income for most Bristol Bay communities, and landing taxes provide the major funding for local school districts. " (609)
Benefit_5:
ESB: FW+terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Sockeye release substantial quantities of productivity-limiting nutrients following their post-spawning death (19), and are the dominant food source for a community of mobile predators and scavengers in freshwater and terrestrial ecosystems" (611)
Benefit_6:
ESB: terrestrial landscape
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "These species perform important ecosystem functions such as dispersing salmon-derived nutrients from spawning sites to the broader landscape (20,21)." (611)
Benefit_7:
ESB: fishery, watershed foodwebs
ESP: salmon diversity
Sentence describing benefit: "The life history diversity observed in the seasonal timing of migration and spawning among populations further enhances many ecosystem services by extending the seasonal availability of salmon resources to the fishery and watershed food webs (Fig. 3)." (611)

Full_citation: Obermeyer, Kim E., White, Kevin S., & Willson, Mary F. (2006). Influence of salmon on the nesting ecology of American dippers in Southeastern Alaska. Northwest Science : Official Publication of the Northwest Scientific Association., 80(1), 26-33.
Journal: Northwest Science : Official Publication of the Northwest Scientific Association
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors study the relationship between brood success and salmon presence for American dippers.
Benefit_1:
ESB: dipper broods
ESP: salmon smolts
Sentence describing benefit: "Dippers on reaches with salmon near Juneau, Alaska, had heavier fledglings and less brood reduction than dippers on reaches without salmon. Higher fledgling mass and less brood reduction were associated with the occurrence and nutritional value of young salmon in the nestling diet and not with aquatic macroinvertebrate abundance (which decreased during the salmon spawning period). " (26)
Benefit_2:
ESB: wildlife
ESP: adults, carcasses, eggs, juveniles
Sentence describing benefit: "The seasonal pulse of migratory fish is fed upon by many wildlife species that consume not only adult salmon and carcasses but also salmon eggs and juvenile salmon (Cederholm et al. 1989, 1999; Willson and Halupka 1995). " (26)
Benefit_3:
ESB: mammals
ESP: seasonal salmon supply
Sentence describing benefit: "The reproductive biology of several mammals has been linked to seasonal foraging on salmon (Ben-David 1997, Willson et al. 1998)" (26)
Benefit_4:
ESB: American dipper
ESP: eggs, carcasses, smolts
Sentence describing benefit: "Dippers also consume salmon eggs, bits of salmon carcasses, and small fish (Sullivan 1973, Ealey 1977, Piorkowski 1995, Campbell et al. 1997, Obermeyer et al. 1999)." (26)
Benefit_5:
ESB: baby American dippers
ESP: coho smolts via parent American dippers
Sentence describing benefit: " Fish, primarily young coho salmon, were delivered only by dippers nesting on salmon reaches (Table 2)." (29)
Benefit_6:
ESB: baby American dippers
ESP: salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon eggs, in addition to other foods, were fed to chicks in some second broods on salmon reaches, but eggs constituted <1% of items delivered to all nests." (29)
Benefit_7:
ESB: nestlings
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Overall, although nestling body mass increased significantly with age on both reach types (F3,29 = 25.04, P < 0.001; Figure 2), nestlings were significantly heavier on salmon reaches than on non-salmon reaches (F1,29 = 7.56, P = 0.01);." (29)
Benefit_8:
ESB: Dipper nestlings
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Dippers nesting on salmon reaches in Southeast Alaska had nestlings of higher body mass (at age) and less brood reduction than those nesting on non-salmon streams. These differences in reproductive performance were related to consumption of salmon fry and not to a higher abundance of invertebrates." (30)

Full_citation: Gende, S., Miller, A., & Hood, E. (2007). The effects of salmon carcasses on soil nitrogen pools in a riparian forest of southeastern Alaska. Canadian Journal of Forest Research, 37(7), 1194-1202.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors look at the spatial and temporal effect of salmon carcasses on soil.

Sentence describing benefit: "At their peak, ammonium (N[H.sub.4.sup.+]-N) concentrations in soil 10 cm from carcasses were as much as several orders of magnitude greater than soils in adjacent control plots without carcasses and remained elevated until the onset of winter. " (1194)
Benefit_2:
ESB: bears
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Streams surveyed for more than 10 years in southwestern Alaska revealed mean predation rates of over 30% of the total salmon run, with rates in some streams in some years exceeding 90% (Quinn et al. 2003). " (1194)
Benefit_3:
ESB: riparian plants
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "To date, a number of studies have demonstrated that riparian plants, including trees, understory shrubs, mosses, and liverworts, utilize SDN as evidenced by elevated isotopic signatures of N in aboveground tissue (Bilby et al. 1996; Helfield and Naiman 2002; Bilby et al. 2003; Wilkinson et al. 2005)." (1195)
Benefit_4:

ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Moreover, assuming a turnover time on the order of a day (Stark and Hart 1997), the seasonal range of inorganic N loadings that we recorded would imply that approximately two-thirds of the N in a salmon carcass enters the plant-available N pool in soils during the course of carcass decomposition, suggesting that the loading would even be much higher." (1200)
