Full_citation: Brock, C., Leavitt, P., Schindler, D., & Quay, P. (2007). Variable Effects of Marine-Derived Nutrients on Algal Production in Salmon Nursery Lakes of Alaska during the past 300 Years. Limnology and Oceanography, 52(4), 1588-1598.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of marine nutrient flux on algae growth in freshwater lakes.
Essential_notes: -again, varies by system: "there was little evidence of spatial or temporal coherence in the importance of MDNs among lakes, even in adjacent sites with substantial densities of spawning salmon." (1589)
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW systems
ESP: sockeye, other fish
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, recent estimates suggest that nitrogen (N) from sockeye salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka) can account for over 25% of N influx to Alaskan nursery lakes (Naiman et al. 2002), whereas fish may contribute up to 90% of total phosphorus (P) inputs to coastal freshwater ecosystems (Schmidt et al. 1998; Naiman et al. 2002; Mitchell and Lambe" (1588)
Benefit_2:
ESB: FW ecosystems
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Our analyses showed that while marine-derived N accounted for <30% of total ecosystem N, variation in past salmon abundance has been an important control of algal production in nursery lakes." (1589)
Benefit_3:
ESB: algae production
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Consistent with this view, algal production was positively correlated to measured salmon escapement in Bristol Bay nursery lakes during the past 100 yr and to inferred salmon abundance since - 1700 (Fig. 3)" (1594)
Benefit_4:
ESB: lakes
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In contrast, anadromous salmon can provide up to 90% of P influx to some regional nursery lakes (Schmidt et al. 1998; Finney et al. 2000), a pattern that suggests that lakes may be responding to P from salmon rather than marine-derived N" (1594)

Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors look at how timber harvest (or lack thereof) affects salmon's influence on benthic biota in FW streams.

Essential_notes: -In heavily logged stream reaches, chlorophyll a levels declined precipitously given salmon presence

Benefit_2:

ESP: salmon MDN

Benefit_3:
ESB: FW ecosystem
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Our results show that the physical stream environment can determine whether the dominant role of salmon is nutrient enrichment or physical disturbance, and that this context dependency can be strongly influenced by human activities in the watershed (Fig. 5)" (10)

Full_citation: Moore, J., Schindler, D., & Ruff, C. (2008). Habitat Saturation Drives Thresholds in Stream Subsidies. Ecology (Durham), 89(2), 306-312.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors study the effect of adult salmon abundance on provision of eggs to stream-resident fishes (i.e. does presence of more spawning salmon lead to increased egg consumption?).
Location: Wood River System, Bristol Bay, AK
Essential_notes: -This paper provided context and management applicability (i.e. conflict between commercial fishers benefitting from adult marine sockeye and recreational fishers benefitting from the stream-resident fish that eat those salmon's would-be eggs
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW foodwebs
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "After achieving >99% of their mass while growing large in the ocean (Quinn 2005), salmon return to spawn and die in coastal freshwaters, subsidizing (sensu Polis et al. 1997) these food webs (Schindler et al. 2003)." (306)
Benefit_2:
ESB: organisms
ESP: salmon eggs and carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In addition, salmon tissues (eggs and carcasses) are consumed by a variety of organisms (Willson and Halupka 1995)." (306)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream-resident fish
ESP: eggs
Sentence describing benefit: " Salmon eggs, also derived from oceanic productivity, are an especially important food subsidy for stream fishes (e.g., Bilby et al. 1998, Scheuerell et al. 2007), being rich in nutrients and energy (Gende et al. 2004)." (306)
Benefit_4:
ESB: grayling and trout
ESP: salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Specifically, grayling and trout fed at substantially higher rates during years with higher salmon densities, driven primarily by increased consumption of salmon eggs (Fig. lc, d)." (308)
Benefit_5:
ESB: trout and grayling
ESP: eggs via adult salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, a sixfold increase in salmon densities between 2002 and 2004 led to a 12-fold increase in total ration size (milligrams dry prey per gram of fish) for grayling (Fig. lc, d). For both trout and grayling, the relationship between salmon density and egg consumption was described best by a nonlinear threshold (broken regression) relationship, with an increase in consumption rate occurring above ?0.4 salmon/m2 (Appendix G)." (308)
Benefit_6:
ESB: rainbow trout
ESP: salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Due to substantial increases in prey quantity and prey quality, increased salmon density translated into in creased rainbow trout growth, according to bioenergetics simulations (Fig. le)." (308)
Benefit_7:
ESB: recreational anglers
ESP: trout via salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Recreational fisheries for resident fishes, predominantly rainbow trout, are a growing and important part of Alaskan economies. Anglers often pay >$1000 (US$) per day to fish at some of the fishing lodges that target the rainbow trout and grayling, species that are subsidized by marine-derived nutrients and energy in the form of salmon eggs." (310)
Benefit_8:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: adult sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "In Bristol Bay, commercial fisheries for sockeye salmon are valuable; in 2005 the sockeye catch was worth >91 X 106 US$ (Alaska Department of Fish and Game, unpublished data)." (311)

Full_citation: Cak, A., Chaloner, D., & Lamberti, G. (2008). Effects of spawning salmon on dissolved nutrients and epilithon in coupled stream-estuary systems of southeastern Alaska. Aquatic Sciences, 70(2), 169-178.

Benefit_1:

Benefit_2:
ESB: estuaries
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Salmon runs increased streamwater fluxes of dissolved ammonium and soluble reactive phosphorus to estuaries by 30 – 350% and 14 – 130%, respectively, depending on the stream and period." (169)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream epilithon
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Although epilithon chlorophyll a and biomass increased in streams in response to SDN, epilithon did not increase in associated estuaries." (169)
Benefit_4:
ESB: epilithon
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "One such pathway in aquatic ecosystems is via the uptake of dissolved nutrients by epilithon, which is the community of algae, bacteria, and other microbes attached to inorganic substrates (Lamberti, 1996)." (170)
Benefit_5:
ESB: estuaries
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Fluxes of ammonium (NHþ4 -N) and soluble reactive phosphorus (SRP) increased in the estuaries of all three streams during or after the salmon run (Fig. 2), and in some cases during both periods (e.g., SRP in Fish Creek)." (173)
Benefit_6:
ESB: epilithon
ESP: salmon

Full_citation: Piccolo, J., Adkison, M., & Rue, F. (2009). Linking Alaskan Salmon Fisheries Management with Ecosystem‐based Escapement Goals: A Review and Prospectus. Fisheries (Bethesda), 34(3), 124-134.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors review what has been studied on the impact of salmon on ecosystems and how this has been incorporated into management, if at all.
Essential_notes:
-EBFM context
-results of workshop discussion by Nature Conservancy
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW systems
ESP: Pacific salmo
Sentence describing benefit: "Although die understanding that salmon contribute marine-derived nutrients (MDN) to freshwater systems is not new, research on MDN has increased dramatically in recent years (Gende et al. 2002; Stockner and Ashley 2003)." (124)
Benefit_2:
ESB: FW foodwebs
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Analysis of the stable isotope composition of various trophic levels first allowed researchers to document that MDN were being incorporated into freshwater food webs in lakes and streams (Mathisen et al. 1988; Kline et al. 1990, 1993)." (125)
Benefit_3:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: Alaskan salmon
Sentence describing benefit: ". Many stocks [of Alaskan salmon] appear to be self-sustaining, while supporting large commercial fisheries (Meacham and Clark 1994; Clark et al. 2006)." (125)
Benefit_4:
ESB: streams and lakes
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Decomposing salmon carcasses may increase concentrations of both nutrients (Chaloner et al. 2004; Mitchell and Lamberti 2005) and organic matter (Johnston et al. 2004; McConnachie and Petticrew 2006; Hood et al. 2007). These effects have been documented in both streams (Kline et al. 1990; Schuldt and Hershey 1995; Johnston et al. 2004; Mitchell and Lamberti 2005; Claeson et al. 2006) and lakes (Hartman and Burgner 1972; Mathisen et al. 1988; Kline et al. 1993; Schmidt et al. 1998; Gregory-Eaves et al. 2003,2004)." (125)
Benefit_5:
ESB: FW systems
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Recent work has shown that salmon not only import nutrients by returning to freshwater to spawn, but that their spawning activities can redistribute significant quantities of nutrients within watersheds (Moore et al. 2007)" (125)
Benefit_6:
ESB: plankton and juvenile salmon
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " It is assumed that decomposing salmon carcasses act in much the same way, and stable isotope analysis has shown that MDN are incorporated into both plankton and juvenile salmon (Mathisen et al. 1988)." (126)
Benefit_7:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Wipfli et al. (1998) and Wipfli et al. (1999) provide quantitative relationships between salmon carcasses and biofilm in both natural treams and mesocosms, with clear increases in standing stock at higher salmon densities." (126)
Benefit_8:
ESB: stream and estuary invertebrates
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon carcasses influence aquatic invertebrate populations by providing food directly (Chaloner and Wipfli 2002; Chaloner et al. 2002b), or indirectly through increased primary production (Schuldt and Hershey 1995; Wipfli et al. 1998; Chaloner and Wipfli 2002; Claeson et al. 2006)...Effects of MDN on invertebrates have been documented as far downstream as estuaries (Fujiwara and Highsmith 1997).  " (126)
Benefit_9:
ESB: stream invertebrates
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Both mescosm and field studies have shown increases in stream invertebrate populations (Wipfli et al. 1998,1999; Chaloner and Wipfli 2002), but results have varied both temporally and spatially (Lessard et al. 2003; Claeson et al. 2006)." (126)
Benefit_10:
ESB: juvenile salmon
ESP: carcasses and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Studies also show that juvenile salmon forage directly on salmon carcasses and salmon eggs (Bilby et al. 1998; Hicks et al. 2005). " (126)
Benefit_11:
ESB: juvenile salmon
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Recently, analysis of fatty acids has demonstrated that juvenile salmon derive nutritional benefits from MDN (Heintz et al. 2004)." (126)
Benefit_12:
ESB: terrestrial plants and soils
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon derived nutrients have been shown to be transferred to terrestrial plants and soils (Ben-David et al. 1998b; Helfield 2002; Bilby et al. 2003; Bartz and Naiman 2005; Drake et al. 2005; Wilkinson et al. 2005)" (127)
Benefit_13:
ESB: wine grapes
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Even wine grapes have been shown to grow better in drainages with spawning salmon (Men and Moyle 2005)! " (127)
Benefit_14:
ESB: birds, mammals, and invertebrates
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "A number of studies document the role of salmon as keystone species, being preyed upon by a wide variety of birds, mammals, and invertebrates (Willson and Halupka 1995; Willson et al. 1998; Gende et al. 2002; Jauquet et al. 2003; Hilderbrand et al. 2004)." (127)
Benefit_15:
ESB: researchers, wildlife viewers, trophy hunters
ESP: bears via salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Of all of the species of terrestrial wildlife that depend on salmon during part of their life cycle, bears are arguably one of the most important, and certainly one of most well-studied (Meehan 1961; Gard 1971; Hilderbrand et al. 1996,1999a; Quinn and Kinnison 1999; Gende et al. 2001; Helfield and Naiman 2006). Archetypical "charismatic megafauna," they interest a broad spectrum of researchers as well as public user groups from wildlife viewers to trophy hunters" (127)
Benefit_16:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "A number of studies have quantified how much salmon bears eat (Hilderbrand et al. 1999b; Klinka and Reimchen 2002; Ben-David et al. 2004; Gende and Quinn 2004; Gende et al. 2004a), and the fate of uneaten salmon carcasses (Gende et al. 2004b, 2007)" (127)
Benefit_17:
ESB: bald eagles
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Bald eagles are also a prominent salmon predator for which some quantitative data exists relating to salmon escapement (Knight and Skagen 1988; Stalmaster and Kaiser 1997; Restani et al. 2000)." (127)
Benefit_18:
ESB: mink, otter, wolves
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Many other species of terrestrial animals utilize spawning salmon. Mammals include mink (Ben-David et al. 1997), otter (Ben-David et al. 1998a; Jauquet et al. 2003), and wolves (Darimont and Reimchen 2002; Darimont et al. 2003)." (127)
Benefit_19:
ESB: seabirds and songbirds
ESP: spawning salmon, eggs
Sentence describing benefit: " Seabirds (Mossman 1958) and songbirds (Obermeyer et al. 1999; Gende and Willson 2001) also forage on spawning salmon or eggs." (127)
Benefit_20:
ESB: harbor seals, sea lions, killer whales
ESP: marine salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Marine mammals that commonly prey on Pacific salmon include harbor seals (Bigg et al. 1990; Kvitrud et al. 2005; Wright et al.2007), sea lions (Bigg et al. 1990; Weise and Harvey 2005; Tollit et al. 2007), and killer whales (Nichol and Shackleton 1996; Ford et al. 1998; Au et al. 2004)" (127)

Full_citation: Janetski, D., Chaloner, D., Tiegs, S., & Lamberti, G. (2009). Pacific Salmon Effects on Stream Ecosystems: A Quantitative Synthesis. Oecologia, 159(3), 583-595.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Review of variability in the effect of salmon on ecosystems.
Essential_notes: -main takeaway: "We found that variation in study design, including method of salmon treatment and type of control, as well as variation in salmon biomass, stream discharge, and sediment size can influence the direction and magnitude of the salmon effect" (590)
Benefit_1:
ESB: streams
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) disturb sediments and fertilize streams with marine-derived nutrients during their annual spawning runs, leading researchers to classify these fish as ecosystem engineers and providers of resource subsidies" (583)
Benefit_2:
ESB: stream chem and organisms
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Results obtained from 37 publications that collectively included 79 streams revealed positive, but highly inconsistent, overall effects of salmon on dissolved nutrients, sediment biofilm, macroinvertebrates, resident fish, and isotopic enrichment" (583)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream
ESP: carcasses and live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Dissolved nutrients were positively related to salmon biomass per unit discharge, and the slope of the relationship for natural runs was nine to ten times higher than for carcass additions. Mean effects on ammonium and phosphorus were also greater for natural runs than carcass additions, an effect attributable to excretion by live salmon" (583)
Benefit_4:
ESB: benthic macroinvertebrates and biofilm
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Furthermore, benthic macroinvertebrates and biofilm associated with small sediments (<32 mm) displayed a negative response to salmon while those associated with large sediments (>32 mm) showed a positive response." (583)
Benefit_5:
ESB: unclear
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Disturbance during redd construction can reduce the abundance of benthic organisms (e.g., Minakawa and Gara 1999; Peterson and Foote 2000; Moore et al. 2004), as well as increase sediment export from watersheds (e.g., Hassan et al. 2008)." (584)
Benefit_6:
ESB: freshwater ecosystems
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Marine-derived nutrients delivered by salmon, which accrue 99% of their body mass in the ocean, constitute an influx of hundreds of metric tons of nitrogen and phosphorus to nutrient-poor systems (Gresh et al. 2000)." (584)
Benefit_7:
ESB: stream biota
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Cumulative effect sizes for stable isotopes were all significantly greater than zero, with a generally higher accumulation of salmon-derived nitrogen than carbon by stream biota and a higher assimilation of salmon material by macroinvertebrates than by biofilm or fish (Fig. 2)" (587)
Benefit_8:
ESB: stream chem
ESP: live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "However, a trend towards larger effect sizes for natural salmon treatments than for artificial salmon treatments was evident for two water chemistry variables- NH4+ and SRP (Fig. 3). This trend is notable since the average salmon dose (before natural log transformation) was much higher for studies using artificial treatments than for studies using natural treatments - i.e., doses were over 3,200 x and 6,600 x greater for NH4+ and SRP, respectively. " (588)
Benefit_9:
ESB: stream chem, macroinvertebrates
ESP: carcasses, spawning salmo
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon biomass per unit discharge was positively related to NH4+, NO3~, and SRP (Fig. 4). Furthermore, salmon biomass and chl a were positively related for studies where salmon carcasses were artificially added, and between salmon biomass and AFDM and macroinvertebrates during natural spawning runs, although these last two relationships were driven by outliers (Fig. 4)" (588)
Benefit_10:
ESB: scientists
ESP: salmon-occupied streams
Sentence describing benefit: "Several study designs have been used in salmon stream research, some with a single type of control and others with a combination of controls (e.g., Peterson and Foote 2000; Mitchell and Lamberti 2005)." (590)
Benefit_11:
ESB: stream chem
ESP: live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "On average, we found that live salmon increase NH4+ and SRP concentrations by 50 and 90% more, respectively, than carcasses alone, presumably due to the direct excretion of nitrogen by live fish (Vanni 2002)" (591)
Benefit_12:
ESB: productivity and macroinvertebrates
ESP: carcass supplementation
Sentence describing benefit: "By contrast, carcass additions increase chl a, AFDM, and macroinvertebrate abundance by 50, 60, and 200% more, respectively, than natural salmon runs, presumably due to the lack of spawner disturbance" (591)
Benefit_13:
ESB: water chem *use this one*
ESP: live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Live salmon and carcasses positively influence NH4+ and phosphorus concentrations in the water column, and, with the exception of DOC, the slopes of each relationship are significantly greater for studies of live salmon run" (591)

Full_citation: Bottom, D., Jones, K., Simenstad, C., & Smith, C. (2009). Reconnecting Social and Ecological Resilience in Salmon Ecosystems. Ecology and Society, 14(1), 5.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors propose incorporating resilience framework into salmon management.
Essential_notes:
-paper is the outcome of a conference, much like #65
-they have a whole section on ES, and it is pretty thorough in terms of addressing everything i've read so far
Benefit_1:
ESB: coastal communities, fisheries
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Widespread fish population decline in turn has caused severe economic hardships for many coastal communities (Martin 2008) and has led to season and area restrictions for local salmon fisheries, culminating in coast-wide fishery closures for Pacific Northwest coho salmon in 1994 and Chinook salmon in 2008." (np)
Benefit_2:
ESB: PNW residents

Full_citation: Holtgrieve, G., Schindler, D., & Jewett, P. (2009). Large predators and biogeochemical hotspots: Brown bear (Ursus arctos) predation on salmon alters nitrogen cycling in riparian soils. Ecological Research, 24(5), 1125-1135.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of bear foraging salmon on flux of nitrous oxide and carbion dioxide as well as concentrations of nutrients in riparian soils.
Type_of_salmon: Sockeye, and to lesser extent chinook, chum, pink, coho
Location: Wood River System, Bristol Bay, AK
Benefit_1:
ESB: aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: salmon, esp. via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "An impressive example of both is the large influx of nutrients and organic matter that anadromous salmon supply to inland aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems and the role of predation by brown bears (Ursus arctos) in transferring these marine-derived nutrients (MDN) from freshwater to riparian habitats. " (1125)
Benefit_2:
ESB: soils
ESP: salmon via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Our results show that bears feeding on salmon increased soil ammonium (NH4 +) concentrations three-fold and N2O flux by 32-fold." (1125)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Wood River system
ESP: sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, sockeye salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka) returning to the Wood River System in Bristol Bay, Alaska import 12,700 kg P and 101,000 kg N annually (Moore and Schindler 2004). " (1126)
Benefit_4:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The lakes and streams in this region support a large, commercially harvested stock of sockeye salmon, as well as much smaller populations of Chinook (O. tshawytscha), Chum (O. keta), Pink (O. gorbuscha), and Coho salmon (O. kisutch). " (1126-7)
Benefit_5:
ESB: brown bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Long-term surveys of salmon abundance and bear predation in the Wood River System has shown that annual predation rates by bears on sockeye salmon range from 5 to 82% of spawning individuals (Winder et al. 2005)." (127)
Benefit_6:
ESB: soils
ESP: salmon via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Analysis of 30 site–date combinations showed that the presence of salmon and localized bear foraging activities interacted to significantly enhance N2O flux from riparian soils (Fig. 2a–b; two-way ANOVA, P < 0.01; see Electronic Supplementary Material for ANOVA tables). " (1129)
Benefit_7:
ESB: soils
ESP: salmon via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "After salmon arrival, soil N2O emissions showed a large and statistically significant increase in sites with concentrated bear feeding activity but not in nearby reference sites on salmon streams (Fig. 2b; P < 0.05). " (1129)
Benefit_8:
ESB: soils
ESP: salmon via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "After salmon and in the presence of bears, soil NH4 + concentration increased with a significant interaction effect of salmon and bears (P = 0.05); reference areas without bears did not respond to salmon (Fig. 3a). " (1130)
Benefit_9:
ESB: soils
ESP: salmon via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "In 2005, bears did concentrate their feeding activities in our predicted areas and as a result we observed a significant increase in N2O flux from the Hidden Lake Creek active bear site (LHLC; Fig. 5b; P < 0.05). " (1130)
Benefit_10:
ESB: soils
ESP: salmon via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Soil respiration also showed a tendency to decline following bear exclusion. CO2 flux was initially higher in the Pick Creek exclusion area compared to the reference area (LPC; Fig. 4c; P < 0.05) when sampled after salmon and before the exclusion was initiated. .. The active bear sites at both Pick Creek and Hidden Lake Creeks (UPC & LHLC) showed significant increases in soil CO2 flux after salmon in 2005 (Figs. 4d, 5d; P < 0.05 and P < 0.01, respectively). " (1131)
Benefit_11:
ESB: soils
ESP: salmon via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "As with N2O and CO2 flux, soil NH4 + concentration in the active bears sites (UPC & LHLC) increased significantly after the arrival of salmon in 2005 (Figs. 4f, 5f; P < 0.05 and P < 0.01)." (1131)
Benefit_12:
ESB: soils
ESP: salmon via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Our results show that bears feeding on salmon in riparian zones can alter N cycling processes in soils. After examining active bear middens and reference areas without concentrated bear activity in four drainages across 3 years, we found that bears feeding on salmon significantly increased N2O flux and soil NH4 + concentration in highly localized areas. " (1131)
Benefit_13:
ESB: riparian areas
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The bulk of N transferred to riparian areas is via salmon carcass deposition which must first be decomposed then mineralized by microbes before it is available to plants (Helfield and Naiman 2006). " (1133)

Full_citation: Tiegs, S., Campbell, E., Levi, P., Rüegg, J., Benbow, M., Chaloner, D., . . . Lamberti, G. (2009). Separating physical disturbance and nutrient enrichment caused by Pacific salmon in stream ecosystems. Freshwater Biology, 54(9), 1864-1875.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors analyzed the contrasting and cumulative effects of salmon disturbance and nutrient input on stream chemistry and benthic communities.
Location: Maybeso Creek, Prince of Wales Island, AK, USA
Essential_notes:
-variability between streams: " In aggregate, the results obtained with this latter approach have been highly variable. In some streams the abundance of biota increased during salmon runs (Chaloner et al., 2004; Mitchell & Lamberti, 2005; Cak, Chaloner & Lamberti, 2008); in other streams their abundance decreased (Minakawa & Gara, 1999; Peterson & Foote, 2000), or showed no net effect (Tiegs et al., 2008). " (1865-6)
-importance of sediment size: "Minakawa & Gara (1999), Peterson & Foote (2000) and Moore et al. (2004) all examined streams with sediments that were finer than those of Maybeso Creek, and all showed net reductions in periphyton biomass during the salmon run. Conversely, Chaloner et al. (2004), Cak et al. (2008) and Mitchell & Lamberti (2005) reported net enrichment of benthic algae in streams with sediments similar to, or coarser than, those of Maybeso Creek. " (1871)
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW streams
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) deliver marine-derived nutrients to the streams in which they spawn and die, and these resource subsidies can increase the abundance of stream biota. " (1864)
Benefit_2:
ESB: stream chem
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Streamwater nitrogen and phosphorus concentrations increased sharply with the onset of the salmon run, and highly significant positive relationships were observed between the numbers of salmon present in the stream and these dissolved nutrients." (1864)
Benefit_3:
ESB: periphyton and macroinvertebrates
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Interestingly, however, the net effect of salmon, evaluated by comparing control plots before and during the salmon run, was relatively modest for both periphyton and macroinvertebrates, suggesting that nutrient enrichment effects were largely offset by disturbance." (1864)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Alaskan streams
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In Alaska alone, salmon annually transfer about 100 million kg of carbon, 10 million kg of nitrogen and 2 million kg of phosphorus from the ocean into freshwaters (Gresh, Lichatowich & Schoonmaker, 2000), where these nutrients are introduced as metabolic waste, gametes and carcasses that accumulate in the stream channel following spawning. " (1865)
Benefit_5:
ESB: scientists
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Three approaches have been used in field studies that examine the ecological effects of salmon on stream ecosystems: (i) tests specifically for salmon nutrient effects, (ii) tests specifically for salmon disturbance, and most commonly, (iii) tests that evaluate the net effect of salmon but do not distinguish enrichment from disturbance effects." (1865)
Benefit_6:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Strong positive relationships were observed between the number of salmon present in the stream channel and dissolved concentrations of nitrogen and phosphorus, as ammonium (R2 = 0.92, P < 0.0001), nitrate (R2 = 0.97, P < 0.0001) and SRP (R2 = 0.95, P < 0.0001) (Fig. 3a–c). " (1868)
Benefit_7:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "During the salmon run, biofilm in exclosure plots was exposed to salmon nutrients, but protected from salmon disturbance. Under these conditions mean Chl a increased by 55.32 mg m−2 and AFDM by 7.98 g m−2 over pre-run values (Fig. 5a,b). This ‘nutrient enrichment potential’ was further evinced by a significant time effect for each of the two biofilm attributes examined (Table 1). " (1868)
Benefit_8:
ESB: invertebrates
ESP: spawning salmon 
Sentence describing benefit: "Invertebrate abundance in exclosures averaged 2156 individuals m−2 before the salmon run, but increased to 5752 m−2 in exclosures during the run, suggesting a nutrient enrichment/drift potential of 3596 individuals m−2 (Fig. 5c). " (1870)

Full_citation: Harwell, M., Gentile, J., Cummins, K., Highsmith, R., Hilborn, R., McRoy, C., . . . Weingartner, T. (2010). A Conceptual Model of Natural and Anthropogenic Drivers and Their Influence on the Prince William Sound, Alaska, Ecosystem. Human and Ecological Risk Assessment, 16(4), 672-726.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors create a conceptual ecological model of Prince William Sound
Benefit_1:

ESP: salmon carcasses

Benefit_2:
ESB: streams and lake

Benefit_3:

Full_citation: Moore, J., & Schindler, D. (2010). Spawning salmon and the phenology of emergence in stream insects. Proceedings of the Royal Society. B, Biological Sciences, 277(1688), 1695-1703.
Journal: Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of salmon disturbance timing on timing of insect emergence behavior.
Location: Wood River System, Bristol Bay, AK
Essential_notes: -Insect emergence is movement of insects from aquatic to terrestrial space; it moves the insect materials (nutrients, energy, etc) earthward.
Benefit_1:
ESB: riparian systems
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Thus, salmon regulate the timing and duration of aquatic insect emergence, a cross-ecosystem flux from streams to riparian systems." (1695)
Benefit_2:
ESB: coastal FW ecosystems
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Anadromous and semelparous Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) are a critical structuring component of coastal freshwater ecosystems through cumulative effects as sources of nutrients and energy, and as a source of physical disturbance to spawning habitats (Schindler et al. 2003; Moore 2006; Janetski et al. 2008)." (1695_
Benefit_3:
ESB: foodwebs
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Their carcasses and excreta can fertilize food webs (e.g. Chaloner et al. 2004; Tiegs et al. 2008), and their nest-digging can disturb benthic communities (Peterson & Foote 2000; Moore et al. 2004; Lessard & Merritt 2006; Moore & Schindler 2008; Honea & Gara 2009; Monaghan & Milner 2009)." (1695)
Benefit_4:
ESB: mink
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "To our knowledge, there has only been one study that has explicitly examined how spawning salmon impact the phenology of coastal organisms?Ben-David (1997) found that lactation timing in mink corresponded tightly to the seasonality of salmon carcass availability, upon which they feed." (1695)
Benefit_5:
ESB: insects
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Furthermore, in streams with high densities of salmon, all abundant taxa emerged in the narrow window of early- to mid-July, where 90 per cent of the emerging biomass of insects occurred over a 40-day period (figure 2). This emergence window corresponded to the period immediately prior to the entry of spawning salmon to these streams (figure 1)." (1697_
Benefit_6:
ESB: insects
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "First, insect emergence was significantly earlier in streams with higher salmon density {n = 74, salmon, ^ = 0.21, p < 0.0001)." (1698)
Benefit_7:
ESB: mayflies
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "These mayflies emerged roughly a month earlier in streams with high salmon densities" (1699)
Benefit_8:
ESB: chironomids
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Peak emergence of chironomids streams with higher densities of salmon; with substantial empirical support salmon (n=10, AAICc = 0.0, r^2 =0.50)" (1699)
Benefit_9:
ESB: chloroperlidae
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Chloroperlidae also emerged earlier in streams with higher densities of salmon, the only model with substan tial empirical support only included salmon as a factor (n = 9, AAICc = 0, r2 = 0.39)." (1700)

Full_citation: Darimont, C., Bryan, H., Carlson, S., Hocking, M., MacDuffee, M., Paquet, P., . . . Wilmers, C. (2010). Salmon for terrestrial protected areas. Conservation Letters, 3(6), 379-389.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors propose limiting fishing of pink and chum salmon runs that return to protected streams
Essential_notes: -Interesting, on p. 384: "Moreover, in Canada, a novel landmark policy of the federal government (Wild Salmon Policy, Fisheries and Oceans Canada 2005) has explicitly recognized that nonhuman users of salmon—including those in the terrestrial and freshwater domains—ought to be considered in fisheries management. A specific plan by which such allocation could occur, however, has not yet been proposed."
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW and riparian ecosystems
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Here, we offer a proposal to promote positive “upstream” processes by safeguarding the seasonal pulse of marine nutrients imported into freshwater and riparian ecosystems by spawning migrations of Pacific salmon." (379)
Benefit_2:
ESB: animal consumers and vegetation
ESP: salmon carcasses via bears and other scavengers
Sentence describing benefit: "Their bodies are often transported further “upstream” into riparian areas by terrestrial predators and scavengers, like bears (Ursus spp.), where their remains and nutrients become available to a diversity of other animal consumers as well as vegetation (e.g., Reimchen 1994, 2000; Willson & Halupka 1995; Ben-David et al. 1998; Cederholm et al. 1999; Gende et al. 2002; Naiman et al. 2002; Schindler et al. 2003; Quinn et al. 2009)." (380)
Benefit_3:
ESB: spawning ecosystems
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Because salmon obtain most of their body mass at sea, individuals that survive the oceanic stage import a net positive quantity of marinederived nutrients into spawning areas. This “fertilizer effect” can influence bottom-up ecosystem processes such as primary production, decomposition, and mineral cycling (e.g., Zhang et al. 2003; Mitchell & Lamberti 2005; Hocking & Reimchen 2009) and top-down processes involving competition and predation (e.g., Ben-David et al. 2004; Gende & Quinn 2004; Darimont et al. 2008)." (380)
Benefit_4:
ESB: terrestrial communities
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The breakdown of salmon carcasses in terrestrial habitats also creates areas of high nutrient release (Holtgrieve et al. 2009), which ultimately can affect communities of riparian plants, terrestrial and freshwater invertebrates, resident fish, and songbirds (Bilby et al. 1998; Mathewson et al. 2003; Wilkinson et al. 2005; Christie & Reimchen 2008; Hocking & Reimchen 2009; Hocking et al. 2009)." (380)
Benefit_5:
ESB: estuaries and lakes, and their communities
ESP: spawning salmon, eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon modify creek substrates while spawning and suspend nutrient-rich sediments and salmon eggs in the water column, resulting in substantive nutrient export to estuaries and downstream lakes (Moore et al. 2007, 2008). This process can alter the production of biofilm, rates of detrital processing, and the seasonal abundance of freshwater consumers." (380)
Benefit_6:
ESB: insects, mink
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In addition to a key role played by salmon in ecological interactions, coevolutionary association with other species are also evident. For example, there is evidence that aquatic insects may time their emergence from streams as adults such that they avoid disturbance caused by spawning salmon (Moore & Schindler 2010). It has also been shown that the timing of lactation in mink (Mustela vison)—which is decoupled from that predicted by latitude—occurs during salmon spawning periods (Ben-David 1997)." (380)
Benefit_7:
ESB: white phase black bear
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon have also been linked to the maintenance of a rare polymorphic trait; recent evidence indicated that the unusual white phase of the black bear (U. americanus) in coastal British Columbia, Canada might be a salmon specialist (Klinka & Reimchen 2009)." (380)
Benefit_8:
ESB: commercial, recreational, and subsistence fisheries
ESP: adult salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Commercial, recreational and subsistence fisheries, the former usually subsidized by governments, often catch 50%, and as high as 90%, of returning adult salmon from near shore waters (Quinn 2005)." (381)
Benefit_9:
ESB: salmon managers and fishers
ESP: salmon and habitat
Sentence describing benefit: "Currently, managers of terrestrial protected areas provide critical habitat protection to salmon, with benefits to salmon managers and fishers." (383)
Benefit_10:
ESB: First Nations
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Moreover, in coastal British Columbia, the strength of First Nations’ cultural identity with salmon is matched only by their increasing legal entitlement to this resource." (383)
Benefit_11:
ESB: First Nations
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Furthermore, many groups co-manage several of the new terrestrial protected areas and have developed their own land and resource management plans." (383)
Benefit_12:
ESB: streams
ESP: pink, chum, sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "Additionally, pink, chum, and sockeye contribute most of the marine subsidy and to a large diversity of streams in western North America (Quinn 2005)." (383)
Benefit_13:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: adult salmon 
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, ex-vessel prices in Alaska for these two species in 2002 were $0.06 and $0.16/pound, compared to $0.37, $0.55, and $1.23 for coho, sockeye, and Chinook, respectively" (383)
Benefit_14:
ESB: parks
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Indeed, salmon declines have been identified as a threat to parks" (384)
Benefit_15:
ESB: grizzly bears
ESP: spawning salmon 
Sentence describing benefit: "In grizzly bears (Ursus arctos horribilis), individuals and populations with greater access to salmon had greater litter and body sizes, as well as population density and productivity (Hilderbrand et al. 1999; Mowat & Heard 2006).
Benefit_16:
ESB: songbirds
ESP: salmon-bearing streams
Sentence describing benefit: "On smaller scales, forests adjacent to rivers (or reaches) with salmon had higher songbird density than those without (Gende & Willson 2001; Christie & Reimchen 2008)." (384)
Benefit_17:
ESB: Dolly Varden
ESP: sockeye eggs, juveniles, blowfly maggots 
Sentence describing benefit: "In Alaska, Denton et al. Benefit_9:
ESB: riparian plants
ESP: salmon MDN

Benefit_10:
ESB: riparian plants
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "This shows that increases in leaf 515N with salmon density are caused by both the 81 ^-enriched source of nitrogen from salmon (~12%o) and higher total nitrogen availability (e.g., through increased nitrification) (22,28). Streams with high salmon densities also had plants with high total leaf nitrogen (LME: t42 = 3.0, P= 0.005), driven by strong relationships in two nutrient-rich indicator species, false hly-of-the-valley and salmonberry (Fig. 1, E to H, Table 1, and table Sil). We observed positive relationships between leaf 815N and %N, which can be caused by salmon subsidies and gradients in soil nutrients, site productivity, and plant dependence on mycorrhizal fungi for nitrogen uptake (29-31)" (1610)

Full_citation: LEVI, P., TANK, J., TIEGS, S., RÜEGG, J., CHALONER, D., & LAMBERTI, G. (2011). Does timber harvest influence the dynamics of marine-derived nutrients in Southeast Alaska streams? Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences, 68(8), 1316-1329.
Journal: Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors quantified extent of nutrient enrichment via dissolved and particulate nutrient concentrations before, during, and after spawning for 3 years at 7 streams.
Location: Prince of Wales Island, Southeast AK, USA
Essential_notes:
-Main takeaway: "Our study demonstrates that enrichment via SDN is short-lived and related to run size, whereas timber harvest and carcasses exert little influence on SDN dynamics" (1316); "Nutrient concentrations were only elevated during the period when live salmon were present in the stream" (1323)
-Variation between streams: "These distinctive patterns demonstrate that, in addition to salmon density, stream and watershed characteristics may modify the influence of live salmon on dissolved nutrient dynamics." (1323)
Benefit_1:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon increased concentrations and export of dissolved and particulate nitrogen, phosphorus, and carbon, but the magnitute of increase varied up to 41-fold among streams" (1316)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Pacific Rim streams and lakes
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) deliver nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and carbon (C) to their natal streams and lakes throughout the Pacific Rim during their annual spawning migrations (Gende et al. 2002; Naiman et al. 2002)" (1316)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream communities
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Previous research suggests that salmon-derived nutrients (SDN) are an important subsidy, particularly in low-nutrient stream ecosystems, as evidenced by increases in primary producer biomass (e.g., Schindler et al. 2005), incorporation of SDN into higher trophic levels (e.g., Bilby et al. 1996), and alleviation of biofilm nutrient limitation (Ruegg et al. 2011)." (1317)
Benefit_4:
ESB: streams
ESP: live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The presence of salmon increased the concentrations of all measured forms of dissolved nutrients" (1320)
Benefit_5:
ESB: streams
ESP: live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Consistent with previous studies, we found that salmon increased stream water dissolved and particulate nitroen and phosphorus (see reviews by Gende et al. (2002) and Naiman et al. (2002))." (1343)
Benefit_6:
ESB: stream
ESP: live salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Our results demonstrate that salmon can directly increase particulate nutrient concentrations. Increases in PN, PP, and PC likely result from salmon-related benthic disturbance during migration and spawning (Moore et al. 2007)" (1324)

Full_citation: BRETHERTON, W., KOMINOSKI, J., FISCHER, D., & LEROY, C. (2011). Salmon carcasses alter leaf litter species diversity effects on in-stream decomposition. Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences, 68(8), 1495-1506.
Journal: Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: How salmon carcasses affect leaf litter diversity and decomposition.
Location: McLane Creek, South Puget Sound, near Olympia, Washington
Essential_notes: -caveat: "Although there are some influences of salmon carcasses on leaf litter decomposition rates, most of the variation in the model was explained by litter treatment, not salmon carcass treatment." (1500)
Benefit_1:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In general, salmon carcass presence accelerated litter decomposition (Yanai and Kochi 2005; Claeson et al. 2006; Kohler et al. 2008); however, declines in litter decomposition in the presence of salmon carcasses in one study suggest that shredding invertebrates were drawn to the carcass and away from lower quality litter (Zhang et al. 2003)." (1496)
Benefit_2:
ESB: PNW headwater streams and foodwebs
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In general, PNW headwater streams are characterized by low nutrient concentrations owing to underlying parent material, so salmon carcasses provide important energy and nutrient subsidies (Polis et al. 1997). The presence of carcasses in freshwater habitats has been shown to change nutrient dynamics and productivity of algal biofilms (Fisher Wold and Hershey 1999; Johnston et al. 2004; Payne and Moore 2006), as well as increase energy and nutrients for stream food webs (Hocking and Eimchen 2009; Heintz et al. 2010)." (1496)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream macros
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "One study reported that up to 58% of the nitrogen used by macroinvertebrates was from salmon carcasses (Winder el al. 2005). Carcasses in streams have also been shown to increase shredder growth rates (Chaloner and Wipfli 2002; Minakawa et al. 2002) and macroinvertebrate densities (Wipfli et al. 1998; Verspoor et al 2011) and alter both the trophic structure of stream invertebrate communities (Lessard and Merritt 2006) and the export of insects to adjacent terrestrial forests (Moore and Schindler 2010)." (1496)
Benefit_4:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon carcass presence generally decelerated litter decomposition for all litter treatments, but the time dependent effects of salmon carcass treatments show a stronger influence of carcasses in the middle and late stages of decay (Fig. 3)" (1500)
Benefit_5:
ESB: macroinvertebrates
ESP: salmon carcass
Sentence describing benefit: "Although insects colonizing salmon carcasses were not surveyed for this study..., observationally on visits to the stream site we saw invertebrates of many types feeding on the salmon carcasses (Gastropoda, Trichoptera, Diptera, etc.)" (1501)
Benefit_6:
ESB: macroinvertebrate communities
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon carcass presence significantly influenced macroinvertebrate communities, and shredder communities varied based on leaf treatments" (1503)

Full_citation: Lisi, P., & Schindler, D. (2011). Spatial variation in timing of marine subsidies influences riparian phenology through a plant-pollinator mutualism. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 2(9), Art101-14.

Sentence describing benefit: "Blowflies (Calliphoridae) are an important consumer of salmon carcasses as larvae and pollinate Apiaceae as adults. Stable isotope analyses indicate that adult blowflies received the majority (85%) of their carbon and nitrogen from salmon carcasses and the remainder from riparian plants." (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Angelica
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We found that salmon spawning date explained a substantial amount of the observed seasonal variation in peak flowering dates among streams and, when combined with longitude, explained 88% of the variation in seasonal phenology of Angelica among streams." (1)

Nutrients and energy from salmon permeate aquatic and terrestrial systems via a wide variety of direct trophic pathways (Bilby et al. 1996, Helfield and Naiman 2001, Hilderbrand et al. 2004, Hocking and Reimchen 2006)." (2)

ESP: adult salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Over the last 50 years, sockeye salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka) escapement (fish that escape the commercial fishery to spawn) to the Wood River system has averaged 1.1 million (Baker et al. 2006)." (3)

ESP: salmon via stream chem

Benefit_4:
ESB: streams

Full_citation: Cram, J., Kiffney, P., Klett, R., & Edmonds, R. (2011). Do fall additions of salmon carcasses benefit food webs in experimental streams? Hydrobiologia, 675(1), 197-209.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors tested whether adding salmon carcasses would increase the potential of streams to produce new biomass during fall and early winter.
Benefit_1:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon carcass
Sentence describing benefit: "We found little evidence that carcasses influenced primary producer biomass or fish growth; however, nutrients and some primary consumer populations increased with loading rate." (197)
Benefit_2:
ESB: freshwater ecosystems and communities
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Recent research has highlighted the critical contributions that salmon make to the biological productivity of their natal watersheds where they release energy and nutrients accumulated at sea (Naiman et al., 2002). These energy rich resources can affect trophic productivity and fishes of freshwater ecosystems via three pathways: (1) nutrients released by carcasses can stimulate primary productivity, which leads to higher secondary production and prey availability; (2) direct consumption of carcass material by aquatic or terrestrial invertebrates, also leading to higher prey availability; and (3) juvenile fish directly consuming eggs and salmon flesh." (197-8)
Benefit_3:
ESB: future generations
ESP: salmon managers
Sentence describing benefit: "Such experiments are critical from a management perspective as millions of dollars (US) are spent annually to restore Pacific salmon populations." (198)
Benefit_4:
ESB: sculpins
ESP: salmon carcasses via lower trophic levels
Sentence describing benefit: "Carcass additions led to positive responses in lower trophic levels that support fishes, but evidence for increased growth or condition of fishes was minimal except for sculpins: sculpin condition factor was markedly higher at intermediate treatment levels (*1.0–2.0 kg/m2, Fig. 5)." (202)
Benefit_5:
ESB: stream chem
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Concentrations of biologically important elements increased as a function of carcass loading rate, but this relationship was not consistent over the course of the experiment. Dissolved PO4-P and NH4-N were the most responsive nutrient species to carcass treatment, consistent with other studies (Claeson et al., 2006, 2007), while NO3-N exhibited little pattern with loading rate." (204-5)
Benefit_6:
ESB: stream chem
ESP: carcasses 
Sentence describing benefit: "Previous studies have found strong bottom-up effects of carcasses on biofilm chlorophyll a and AFDM (Wipfli et al., 1998, 1999; Chaloner et al., 2007), but these studies were conducted in summer when incident light and water temperature were relatively high." (206)
Benefit_7:
ESB: fungus
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Alternatively, or in addition to high invertebrate consumption, fungal growth on carcasses may have absorbed limiting nutrients making them unavailable for primary producers (Mackenzie, 2001). We observed an abundance of this fungus in channels receiving high (2.0–4.0 kg/m2) amounts of carcass material." (206)
Benefit_8:
ESB: chironomids
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "A number of studies have shown that chironomids respond positively to carcass additions (Wipfli et al., 1999; Claeson et al., 2006). Therefore, chironomids, which were represented by the collector-gatherer functional feeding group in our study (Merritt & Cummins, 1996), appeared to be most the successful taxon at exploiting the resources provided by salmon carcasses" (207)
Benefit_9:
ESB: juvenile coho salmon, steelhead
ESP: salmon carcasses (likely with eggs)
Sentence describing benefit: "For instance, Bilby et al. (1998) observed a transient positive effect of adding salmon carcasses on the condition factor of juvenile coho salmon and steelhead trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss)  during winter in two Western Washington streams."

Full_citation: Field, R., & Reynolds, J. (2011). Sea to sky: Impacts of residual salmon-derived nutrients on estuarine breeding bird communities. Proceedings of the Royal Society. B, Biological Sciences, 278(1721), 3081-3088.
Journal: Proceedings of the Royal Society B
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of residual MDN on summer breeding birds.
Location: Heiltsuk First Nation territory, Great Bear Rainforest, British Columbia, Canada
Essential_notes: -asymptotic relationship: i.e. there is a level of salmon biomass after which no further benefits are deferred to birds
Benefit_1:
ESB: North Pacific Rim ecosystems
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon ( Oncorhynchus spp.) returning to streams around the North Pacific Rim provide a nutrient subsidy to these ecosystems" (3081)
Benefit_2:
ESB: animal species
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "While many species of animals feed directly on salmon carcasses each autumn, salmon-derived nutrients can also be stored in coastal habitats throughout the year" (3081)
Benefit_3:
ESB: birds (insectivore, golden-crowned kinglet, and Pacific wren)
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We discovered that total bird, insectivore, golden-crowned kinglet and Pacific wren densities and Shannon's diversity in the summer were strongly predicted by salmon biomass in the autumn." (3081)
Benefit_4:
ESB: aquatic, terrestrial, and coastal marine systems
ESP: Pacific salmon via water movement and predators
Sentence describing benefit: "When they return to spawn in their natal streams, the marine-derived nutrients that they have sequestered are transferred to aquatic, terrestrial and coastal marine systems by water movement and by predators such as bears ( Ursus spp.) and wolves (Canis lupus)" (3081)
Benefit_5:
ESB: researchers (including tribal)
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon counts were done jointly by the Heiltsuk First Nation, the Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans and by our team from Simon Fraser University" (3082)
Benefit_6:
ESB: aquatic invertebrates
ESP: salmon flesh and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon flesh are consumed both by aquatic invertebrates directly, and indirectly through grazing of nitrogen-benthic algae and microbial decomposers [39]." (3085)
Benefit_7:
ESB: Pacific wrens
ESP: salmon via invertebrates
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific wrens frequently consume aquatic invertebrates [37], and isotopic analyses of their tissues have confirmed that they consume salmon nitrogen-enriched prey items [42] ." (3086)
Benefit_8:
ESB: terrestrial invertebrates
ESP: salmon via bears, wolves, etc.
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon carcasses that have been transferred to adjacent terrestrial zones by bears, wolves and other species are quickly colonized by terrestrial invertebrates, which trans- fer these nutrients to terrestrial food webs" (3086)
Benefit_9:
ESB: flies
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, large biomasses of flies accumulate on and deposit their eggs on these carcasses, leaving their offspring to consume the salmon tissues and over-winter as pupae in surround- ing soils [43]." (3086)
Benefit_10:
ESB: Plants
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Plants can grow more quickly when they are fertilized by salmon nutrients [45]" (3086)

Full_citation: Williams, R., Krkošek, M., Ashe, E., Branch, T., Clark, S., Hammond, P., . . . Winship, A. (2011). Competing conservation objectives for predators and prey: Estimating killer whale prey requirements for Chinook salmon. PloS One, 6(11), E26738.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Estimating prey needed to achieve killer whale conservation objectives.
Benefit_1:
ESB: Southern Resident Killer Whale
ESP: Chinook salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Such a conflict may be emerging in the northeastern Pacific for southern resident killer whales (Orcinus orca) and their primary prey, Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha)." (np)
Benefit_2:
ESB: fisheries, conservation activists
ESP: Chinook salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Prey requirements of southern resident killer whales are difficult to reconcile with fisheries and conservation objectives for Chinook salmon, because the number of fish required is large relative to annual returns and fishery catches." (np)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Southern Resident Killer Whales
ESP: chinook salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Unlike the mammal-eating transient killer whale population, SRKWs prey exclusively on fish, and specialize almost exclusively on Chinook salmon [17], [18]." (np)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Canadian commercial fisheries
ESP: Chinook salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In Canada, stocks of commercially valuable marine fish species are normally managed using traditional fisheries-management tools, rather than endangered species legislation [23]. By 1998, the total Canadian catch of all salmon species was at its historic low for the 20th Century, with Chinook and coho experiencing the most severe declines [24]
Benefit_5:
ESB: Southern Resident Killer Whales
ESP: Chinook salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Dedicated field studies have demonstrated prey selectivity, in that resident killer whales were found to target Chinook salmon even when Chinook abundance was low relative to other salmonids [17]. In fact, it has been suggested that resident killer whales are "highly specialized and dependent on this single salmonid species to an extent that it is a limiting factor in their population dynamics" [29]. As a result of this specialization, reduced availability of Chinook salmon is linked to increased adult mortality [29] and reduced reproduction [30] of resident killer whales." (np)
Benefit_6:
ESB: Scottish citizens
ESP: Atlantic salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "More recently, the establishment of Special Areas for Conservation under the EU Habitats Directive for harbour seals and Atlantic salmon in Scotland raises issues similar to those for SRKWs and Chinook salmon [39]." (np)
Benefit_7:
ESB: whales, commercial and recreational fisheries
ESP: chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Availability of Fraser River Chinook in the marine environment is approximated by the sum of: (a) the number of fish taken by the whales; (b) takes by commercial and recreational fisheries, which averaged 18,000 annually from 2004-2008 in the Strait of Georgia [47]; and (c) terminal run size (number of fish available after marine predation and at-sea mortality), which is approximately 300,000 annually [47]." (np)
Benefit_8:
ESB: sport fishery, First Nations fisheries
ESP: chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Note that although in-river fisheries by sport and First Nations fisheries increase average annual fishery takes to 64,000 [47], in-river fisheries remove fish after they have been counted in the terminal run size, and are therefore excluded from these calculations." (np)
Benefit_9:
ESB: Southern Resident Killer Whales
ESP: Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "In summer months (May through September), 83% of the SRKW diet is composed of Chinook salmon, 90% of which are of Fraser River origin [18]." (np)
Benefit_10:
ESB: fisheries
ESP: chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Average fisheries catch of Fraser River Chinook is 18,000 fish and average terminal run size is 300,000 [47]." (np)
Benefit_11:
ESB: commercial and sport fisheries
ESP: Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Total abundance of Chinook may be higher than our estimates suggest because, north of the Salish Sea, Chinook salmon are harvested in commercial and sport fisheries, and by-caught in fisheries for other salmon." (np)
Benefit_12:
ESB: tribes and fisheries, commercial, recreational, killer whales
ESP: chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "A multi-species or ecosystem approach to fisheries stock assessments and management may be needed to balance the needs of the fishery (First Nations, North American Tribes, commercial and recreational) and the needs of the endangered species (to maintain killer whales at their current population size and to promote recovery)." (np)

Full_citation: Sturdevant, M., Orsi, J., & Fergusson, E. (2012). Diets and Trophic Linkages of Epipelagic Fish Predators in Coastal Southeast Alaska during a Period of Warm and Cold Climate Years, 1997–2011. Marine and Coastal Fisheries, 4(1), 526-545.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Trawl-based diet study to determine what fish eat.
Benefit_1:
ESB: predator fish
ESP: fish prey (including juvenile salmon)
Sentence describing benefit: "The most common fish prey consumed were fish larvae, juvenile salmon, Pacific herring Clupea pallasii, capelin Mallotus villosus, walleye pollock, lanternfishes (Myctophidae), and Pacific sand lance Ammodytes hexapterus, whereas the most common invertebrate prey consumed were euphausiids, decapod larvae, pteropods, and amphipods." (526)
Benefit_2:
ESB: NOAA scientists
ESP: juvenile Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The Southeast Coastal Monitoring (SECM) project of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Auke Bay Laboratories, Alaska Fisheries Science Center, has collected fish diet data during fisheries oceanography surveys annually since 1997 (Orsi et al. 2007, 2011). The research has emphasized long-term monitoring of strait and coastal marine habitats used by juvenile Pacific salmon Oncorhynchus spp. and associated epipelagic fishes in Southeast Alaska in order to understand how environmental variation affects salmon resources." (527)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Chinook salmon, coho salmon, pink salmon, walleye pollock, sablefish, spiny dogfish, pacific sandfish, pomfret
ESP: juvenile salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The next four most common categories (unidentified fish larvae, juvenile salmon, Pacific herring, and capelin Mallotus villosus) were present in nearly half of the predator species, generally at lower incidence. Juvenile salmon in juvenile sablefish guts was an exception (FO% = 34%)." (531)
Benefit_4:
ESB: spiny dogfish, salmon shark
ESP: adult marine salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Only spiny dogfish and the salmon shark ate adult salmon." (533)
Benefit_5:
ESB: juvenile coho salmon
ESP: pink and chum fry
Sentence describing benefit: "Other studies have shown conspecific interactions between additional salmon life stages, such as juvenile coho salmon predating on pink and chum salmon fry (Heard 1991; Nagasawa 1998)." (540)
Benefit_6:
ESB: juvenile sablefish, adult coho
ESP: juvenile salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We found juvenile salmon were utilized most by juvenile sablefish and adult coho salmon predators" (540)
Benefit_7:
ESB: spiny dogfish
ESP: juvenile salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Juvenile salmon were themost frequently occurring identifiable fish prey for spiny dogfish (FO% = 5%, W% =16%) in our study, but only 51% of dogfish had been feeding." (541)

Full_citation: RINELLA, D., WIPFLI, M., STRICKER, C., HEINTZ, R., & RINELLA, M. (2012). Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) runs and consumer fitness: Growth and energy storage in stream-dwelling salmonids increase with salmon spawner density. Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences, 69(1), 73-84.
Journal: Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: How MDN affect nutritional status of stream-resident fish
Location: Chugach-St. Elias Mountains ecoregion, Cook Inlet Basin ecoregion, and Gulf of Alaska coast ecoregion in Kenai Peninsula, south-central AK, USA
Essential_notes: -no saturation/asymptote relationship observed here
Benefit_1:
ESB: juvenile coho salmon, Dolly Varden
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Growth rate (as indexed by RNA-DNA rations), energy density, and d15N enrichment in spring-sampled fishes increased with spawner biomass, indicating the persistence of spawner effects more than 6 months after salmon spawning...In a follow up analysis where growth rate and energy density were modeled as a function of d15N enrichment, results suggested that both increased with MDN assimilation, especially in juvenile coho salmon" (73)
Benefit_2:
ESB: FW and riparian ecosystems
ESP: spawning salmon, eggs, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Marine-derived nutrients (MDN) delivered to riverine systems in the form of salmon excreta, eggs, and carcasses represent a seasonally pulsed subsidy that enhance productivity of freshwater and riparian ecosystems (Gende et al. 2002; Naiman et al. 2002; Janetski et al. 2009)." (74)
Benefit_3:
ESB: juvenile salmonids
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Juvenile salmonids can consume large quantities of MDN (Scheurerell et al. 2007), and their growth rates (Bilby et al. 1996; Wipfli et al. 2003; Giannico and Hinch 2007), body condition (Bilby et al. 1998), and energy storage (Heintz et al. 2004, 2010) have been shown to increase in association with MDN." (74)
Benefit_4:
ESB: coho salmon and Dolly Varden
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "An increase in spawner biomass of 1 kg/m2 corresponded with energy density increases of 0.77 kJ/g...and 0.44 kJ/g... for spring-sampled coho salmon and Dolly Varden, respectively, and 0.95 kJ/g... and 0.92kJ/g... for fall-sampled coho salmon and Dolly Varden, respectively (Fig. 2b)" (78)
Benefit_5:
ESB: coho salmon and Dolly Varden
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "An increase in spawner biomass of 1 kg/m2 corresponded with increases in the d15N enrichment index of 1.7%...and 1.7%... for spring-sampled coho salmon and Dolly Varden, respectively, and 1.4% ... and 1.1%... for fall-sampled coho salmon and Dolly Varen, respectively (Fig. 2c)." (78)
Benefit_6:
ESB: stream-resident fish
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Our conclusion that MDN further contributed to the enhanced nutritional status of fishes is further supported by the positive associations of d15N enrichment with growth and energy, especially for coho salmon" (78)
Benefit_7:
ESB: stream-resident fish
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Increasing growth, energy, and d15N enrichment in relation to spawner biomass were evident during spring, indicating that these effects carried over through winter, an important energetic bottleneck (Giannico and Hinch 2007)." (80)
Benefit_8:
ESB: rainbow trout and Arctic grayling
ESP: salmon spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "A similar nutritional dichotomy was observed for rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss), which consumed MDN directly, and Arctic grayling (Thymallus arcticus), whose diets were supplemented indirectly by benthic macroinvertebrates dislodged by spawning salmon (Scheuerell et al. 2007)." (82)

Full_citation: Jordan, S., O'Higgins, T., & Dittmar, J. (2012). Ecosystem Services of Coastal Habitats and Fisheries: Multiscale Ecological and Economic Models in Support of Ecosystem-Based Management. Marine and Coastal Fisheries, 4(1), 573-586.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Linking spatial production to economic value for recreational Chinook in the PNW and commercial blue crab and shrimp in the Gulf of Mexico.
Location: WA and OR, USA; Gulf of Mexico, USA
Essential_notes: -Landscape ecology context: "We present examples from coastal fisheries to illustrate how landscape ecology can be used to create a bridge from fine-scale ecosystem properties and functions to ecosystem services that are delivered over extended scales of space and time." (574)
Benefit_1:
ESB: Fisheries
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In the PNW of the United States and Canada, several species and subspecies of Pacific salmon Oncorhynchus spp. support fisheries of great commercial, recreational, and cultural value." (574)
Benefit_2:
ESB: scientists
ESP: declining Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific coast salmon fisheries and their recent declines have been the subject of intense scientific scrutiny and a considerable body of both scientific (reviewed in Knudsen et al. 1999) and economic, cultural, and institutional literature (Hanna et al. 2006; Hanna 2008)." (574)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Native  and current residents of PNW
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon have been culturally important in the PNW for millennia (Meengs and Lackey 2005), but the arrival of European settlers led to major losses and modifications to salmon habitats as well as an increase in the demand for salmon as food." (574)
Benefit_4:
ESB: anglers
ESP: salmon and steelhead
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, Brown et al. (1964) calculated the net economic value of salmon and steelhead in Oregon at US$3million for 1962 ($20.6million in 2007 dollars) based on expenditures by anglers." (574)
Benefit_5:
ESB: recreational anglers
ESP: chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "The total annual value of recreational salmon fishing in the Yaquina estuary, estimated as the product of mean value per angler-day (Table 2) and angler effort, was $540,817." (580)

Full_citation: Levi, T., Darimont, C., Macduffee, M., Mangel, M., Paquet, P., & Wilmers, C. (2012). Using grizzly bears to assess harvest-ecosystem tradeoffs in salmon fisheries. PLoS Biology, 10(4), E1001303.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Ecosystem tradeoffs between salmon users: bears vs. fisheries
Location: Bristol Bay, AK and British Columbia, Canada
Benefit_1:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "Alaskan landings alone surpass 300,000 metric tons and ex-vessel values exceed US$260 million annually [5]." (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: orcas, salmon sharks, pinnipeds, grizzly bears
ESP: adult wild salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "They are the dominant prey of a number of marine and terrestrial predators such as orcas [7], salmon sharks [8], pinnipeds [9], and grizzly bears [10]." (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: freshwater systems
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon carcasses, distributed primarily by bears during spawning events, contribute annual pulses of marine-derived nutrients to freshwater systems that propagate through food webs and influence primary producers, invertebrates, fish, and wildlife [11]." (1)
Benefit_4:
ESB: grizzly bears, seabirds, pinnipeds, sharks
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "bears are the terminal predator, consuming salmon in their final life history phase; thus, if there are enough salmon to sustain healthy bear densities, we reason that there should be sufficient salmon numbers to sustain populations of earlier salmon-life-history predators such as seabirds, pinnipeds, and sharks (Figure 1A and 1B)" (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: vertebrate and invertebrate scavengers
ESP: carcasses via bears
Sentence describing benefit: After capturing salmon in estuaries and streams, grizzly bears typically move to land to consume each fish, distributing carcass remains to vertebrate and invertebrate scavengers up to several hundred meters from waterways [17, 18]" (2)
Benefit_6:
ESB: riparian plant communities
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Carcass remains (nutrients and energy) can influence all tropic levels from primary producers to large carnivores in both terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems [16,19, 20]. Described as a "keystone interaction", this coupled grizzly-salmon association (at high bear densities) can provide up to a quarter of the nitrogen budget to plant communities in riparian areas adjacent to spawning grounds [19]." (2)
Benefit_7:
ESB: the public
ESP: grizzly bears via salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Additional benefits provided by a focus on grizzly bears are their charismatic appeal to the public and their status as a large carnivore commonly of conservation concern" (2)
Benefit_8:
ESB: grizzly bears
ESP: adult salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We estimated that the salmon biomass density necessary to constitute roughly 45% of bear diets...is 80.08 kg/km2, with a 95% confidence interval from 50.9 to 128.4 kg/km2." (3)
Benefit_9:
ESB: subsistence fishers
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Retaining lower escapement goals may benefit subsistence fishers, who must harvest some fish each year but face restrictions if escapements are perceived to be too low" (6)
Benefit_10:
ESB: primary producers (FW and terrestrial), invertebrates, songbirds, resident fish (including bb salmon)
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Compelling support for an "abundance matters hypothesis is now emerging [28]; that is, while often site-specific, evidence is accumulating that suggests increased spawning density is associated with positive ecological responses across a broad array of taxa, including aquatic primary productivity [29], terrestrial vegetation growth [30, 31], invertebrate density [31], songbird density [32], and growth rates of resident fish (including juvenile salmon [33]), as well as other aquatic and terrestrial ecological processes" (7)
Benefit_11:
ESB: eco-tourism
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: Higher salmon escapement might also provide increased opportunities for salmon-based eco-tourism [28]" (7)

Full_citation: Nagata, M., Miyakoshi, Y., Urabe, H., Fujiwara, M., Sasaki, Y., Kasugai, K., . . . Kaeriyama, M. (2011). An overview of salmon enhancement and the need to manage and monitor natural spawning in Hokkaido, Japan. Environmental Biology of Fishes, 94(1), 311-323.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors review hatchery effects, status of wild salmon, and key management issues related to MSC.
Benefit_1:
ESB: Humans
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon were eaten for subsistence during the Mid-Jomon period, beginning 5,500 years ago." (311)
Benefit_2:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Commercial fisheries using coastal trap nets for capturing salmon began in the 19 century in Hokkaido." (311)
Benefit_3:
ESB: commercial fisheries, researchers
ESP: hatchery pink and chum
Sentence describing benefit: "We used data of commercial catch numbers in the sea and stream catch numbers for hatchery programs of chum and pink salmon (Hokkaido Salmon Hatchery 1971–1998; National Salmon Resources Center 1999–2009). Chum salmon and pink salmon are caught by trap (set) net fishing in the coastal waters from late August to mid December and from late July to early October, respectively." (313)
Benefit_4:
ESB: commercial fisheries, researchers
ESP: hatchery masu salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We also report data on commercial catch in the sea and hatchery brood stock take in streams by hatcheries releasing masu salmon in Hokkaido (Hokkaido Fish Hatchery 1983–2007; Hokkaido Salmon Hatchery 1971–1998; National Salmon Resources Center 1999–2009)." (313)
Benefit_5:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: hatcheries
Sentence describing benefit: "Although the effectiveness of hatchery releases has not been explicitly examined, commercial chum salmon catches have increased dramatically since the 1970s (r=0.910, p<0.001) and has shown strong coherence with the amount of brood stock take in hatchery streams (Fig. 1A)." (313)
Benefit_6:
ESB: pink salmon commercial fisheries
ESP: hatchery chum salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Further, pink salmon commercial catches increased sharply in the early 1990s along with chum salmon hatchery returns from the Okhotsk Sea, suggesting that hatcheries efforts likely contributed to overall abundance in both species (Fig. 1)." (316)
Benefit_7:
ESB: recreational fisheries
ESP: juvenile masu
Sentence describing benefit: "Recreational fishing for juvenile masu is very popular in Hokkaido because of the traditional food culture as well as a rising interest in masu fishing as a rewarding recreational activity" (317)
Benefit_8:
ESB: conservationists, future generations
ESP: Hokkaido government
Sentence describing benefit: "In addition, recreational fishing is prohibited all year in 32 conservation streams and 12 resources conservation streams (except in the winter season). These regulations were established by the national government and the Hokkaido government, respectively, as a means to conserve naturally spawning masu salmon in Hokkaido." (317)
Benefit_9:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: adult hatchery masu salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The contribution of adult hatchery masu salmon to commercial catches was estimated to be 14–26% in Hokkaido (Miyakoshi 2008)." (318)

Full_citation: Dettmers, J., Goddard, C., & Smith, K. (2012). Management of Alewife Using Pacific Salmon in the Great Lakes: Whether to Manage for Economics or the Ecosystem? Fisheries (Bethesda), 37(11), 495-501.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Management possibilities given the introduction of Pacific salmon to the Great Lakes and subsequent ecosystem and use changes (i.e. tension between maintaining a restored ecosystem vs. an introduced sport fishery).
Benefit_1:
ESB: recreational fishery
ESP: stocked salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Public demands for action, coupled with control of sea lamprey, allowed fishery managers to consider stocking Pacific salmon to control alewife and establish a recreational fishery. This effort was successful, reducing alewife numbers and creating a recreational fishery that is estimated at $7 billion annually." (495)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Great Lakes ecosystem
ESP: introduced salmon, esp. Chinook 
Sentence describing benefit: "This strategy worked well in Lakes Huron, Michigan, and Ontario, because the Pacific salmon, especially Chinook salmon, consumed large quantities of alewives, thus reducing alewife populations (Madenjian et al. 2002). By 1984, the biomass of alewives in Lake Michigan was less than 20% of what it had been in 1967 (O’Gorman and Stewart 1999). This shift away from a community dominated by alewife resulted in a more diverse fish community well represented by native fishes during the 1980s and 1990s (Bunnell et al. 2006)." (496)
Benefit_3:
ESB: recreational fishery
ESP: introduced Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "As envisioned by the state of Michigan, an extensive and popular recreational fishery for Pacific salmon developed throughout the Great Lakes. By the late 1970s, catch rates of Pacific salmon were high, and large Chinook salmon (up to 15–20 kg) were harvested by recreational anglers" (496)
Benefit_4:
ESB: charter boat industry
ESP: Pacific salmonids
Sentence describing benefit: "The phenomenally popular recreational fishery also led to widespread establishment of a successful charter boat industry for stocked Pacific salmonids." (496)
Benefit_5:
ESB: Great Lakes states, Province of Ontario
ESP: industries via stocked salmon 
Sentence describing benefit: "This recreational fishery provided significant economic return to the Great Lakes states and the Province of Ontario." (496)
Benefit_6:
ESB: walleye, lake trout
ESP: Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Lakewide research demonstrated that about 80% of the Chinook salmon population is naturally produced (Johnson et al. 2010), and anglers recognize that stocked Chinook salmon are simply feeding existing predators, especially walleye and lake trout." (499)
