Full_citation: DeVries, P. (2012). Salmonid influences on rivers: A geomorphic fish tail. Geomorphology (Amsterdam, Netherlands), 157-158, 66-74.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Review of ways salmonids may physically alter the environment (i.e. how are they ecosystem engineers?)
Benefit_1:
ESB: riparian vegetation
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The most plausible mechanism appears to be the delivery of nutrients derived from carcasses of mass spawning salmon populations to riparian vegetation." (68)
Benefit_2:
ESB: stream beds
ESP: spawning sockeye, chum, chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Gottesfeld et al. (2008) observed that mass spawning of sockeye and chum salmon tends to result in a plane bed channel form, whereas Chinook salmon tend to create more defined dunes and ridges." (69)
Benefit_3:
ESB: spawning salmon
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "As biological corroboration, spawning fish are thought to sometimes select previously spawned substrates because they are already loosened and redd excavation then requires less energy (Quinn, 2005)." (69)
Benefit_4:
ESB: riparian zone
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Mass spawning salmon have been documented to deliver large quantities of nutrients to the riparian zone, which may influence the rate of growth and supply of large wood to channels and the character of stream banks in oligotrophic systems where particular nutrients are limiting (Helfield and Naiman, 2001)." (70)
Benefit_5:
ESB: streams
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Stream segments with salmon spawning habitat have been found to contain increased concentrations of dissolved nitrogen, ammonium ion, and phosphorus, with concomitant higher levels of autotrophic and heterotrophic production compared to streams without (Ben-David et al., 1998; Minakawa and Gara, 1999; Gende et al., 2002; Moore et al., 2007; Cak et al., 2008)." (70)
Benefit_6:
ESB: riparian vegetation
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Isotopic analyses have found riparian vegetation to derive a substantial fraction of foliar nitrogen from SDN, and the influence can extend 100 m or more beyond the channel margin (Helfield and Naiman, 2001; Gende et al., 2002; Naiman et al., 2002; Bilby et al., 2003)." (70)
Benefit_7:
ESB: riparian vegetation, esp. Sitka spruce
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Evidence exists that SDN are associated with increased rates of growth of riparian vegetation (Gende et al., 2002). Helfield and Naiman (2001) estimated rates of growth of Sitka spruce within 25 m of spawning streams to be triple that of trees in reference sites. The enhanced rate of growth corresponded to trees reaching a diameter at breast height equal to 50 cm after about 86 years, compared with about 307 years at the reference sites." (70-1)
Benefit_8:
ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:

Benefit_1:
ESB: Mussels near salmon farms
ESP: salmon farms
Sentence describing benefit: "After a 12-mo period, mussels grown directly on the cages grew faster than mussels 200 m away on all parameters except shell length at 1 location. Mussels grown at 0 m and 200m performed significantly better (p<0.05) in all growth parameters compared with mussels grown at a reference site outside the aquaculture influence." (997)
Benefit_2:
ESB: mussels in integrated aquaculture
ESP: salmon farming
Sentence describing benefit: "Results of a second study in which growth rates for individually tagged mussels was monitored for a 6 mo period confirmed that there is a significant growth benefit for mussels in integrated aquacultre with salmon compared with mussels grown 500 m away at a reference site." (997)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Mussels
ESP: salmon farms
Sentence describing benefit: "Mean growth rates were highest at the cage locations (0.17-0.18mm/day), followed by the 200-m locations (0.12mm/day), with the lowest overall growth rate occurring in mussels at the reference site (0.08mm/day; Table 2)." (1000)
Benefit_4:
ESB: blue mussels
ESP: salmon cages
Sentence describing benefit: "We found a relationship among final SL [shell length] and enhanced growth rate of mussels and close proximity to the salmon cages, which were more apparent at some sites (Atlantic Silver) than others (AquaFish)" (1002-3)
Benefit_5:
ESB: Blue mussels
ESP: salmon cages

Benefit_6:
ESB: blue mussels
ESP: salmon cages
Sentence describing benefit: "In summary, mussels grown adjacent to salmon cages had faster shell growth than mussels held 200m or 500m away from the cages and those held at reference locations outside the direct influence of salmon farms. ESP: spawning salmon

Benefit_2:
ESB: stream ecosystems
ESP: anadromous Pacific salmon

ESB: stream water, riparian zone
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "First, salmon-derived nutrients can enrich stream water and the surrounding riparian zone, resulting in biomass increases in several ecosystem compartments (Chaloner and others 2004; Helfield and Naiman 2006)." (270)
Benefit_4:
ESB: FW habitats
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Second, salmon act as ecosystem engineers (Peterson and Foote 2000) and modify freshwater habitats via scouring and redistribution of sediments during their migration and spawning activities (Moore and others 2004; Tiegs and others 2009)." (270)
Benefit_5:
ESB: stream ecosystems
ESP: salmon run
Sentence describing benefit: "Overall, both ER and GPP increased during the salmon run in both biomes (1-way R-B ANOVA, p = 0.004 and 0.04, respectively; Figure 2)." (274)
Benefit_6:
ESB: stream heterotrophs
ESP: salmon migration
Sentence describing benefit: "Studies have consistently shown that concentrations of N and P increase during the salmon migration (Janetski and others 2009), which enriched stream heterotrophs and, in addition to the direct respiration by salmon, led to increased ER." (280)
Benefit_7:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon via nutrient provision
Sentence describing benefit: "Although physical structure may dictate the response of ecosystem structure to salmon (for example, Holtgrieve and others 2010), ER and GPP were most strongly controlled by stream water nutrients and the salmon subsidy. Whole-stream metabolism reached a maximum when the salmon run and streamwater nutrient concentrations peaked." (280)

ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:

Full_citation: Levi, P., Tank, J., Tiegs, S., Chaloner, D., & Lamberti, G. (2013). Biogeochemical transformation of a nutrient subsidy: Salmon, streams, and nitrification. Biogeochemistry, 113(1-3), 643-655.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Nitrification rates in stream sediments before vs. during salmon runs.
Location: Prince of Wales Island, Southeast AK, USA
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW ecosystems
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Annual migrations of Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) transport nutrients from the marine environment to their natal freshwater ecosystems." (643)
Benefit_2:
ESB: stream sediments
ESP: salmon run
Sentence describing benefit: "Nitrification rates increased 3-fold from before to during the salmon run (mean ± SE = 0.07 ± 0.01 to 0.24 ± 0.02 mgN gAFDlVT1 d~\ respectively)." (643)
Benefit_3:
ESB: sediments
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Sediment nitrification was 2-5 times higher under the carcasses compared to nearby sediments without the direct carcass influence." (643)
Benefit_4:
ESB: researchers
ESP: salmon life history
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon migrations provide a useful model for investigating the effect of biogeochemical transformations on nutrient subsidies, as they deliver inorganic nitrogen (N) to streams as ammonium (NH4+) via excretion, often increasing this form of dissolved N by orders of magnitude above background concentrations (see meta-analysis by Janetski et al. 2009)" (644)
Benefit_5:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon run
Sentence describing benefit: "The concentration of both streamwater NH4+ and N03~ increased during the salmon run (Fig. 1)." (647)
Benefit_6:
ESB: sediment
ESP: salmon run
Sentence describing benefit: " Ambient sediment nitrification rates were low before salmon, but increased during the salmon run (Fig 2.)" (648)
Benefit_7:
ESB: sediment
ESP: carcasses 
Sentence describing benefit: "The carcass addition experiment conducted during the salmon run confirmed the localized effect of salmon-derived NH4+; sediment nitrification rates were up to 100-fold higher under salmon carcasses, compared to sediments without carcasses" (648)
Benefit_8:
ESB: nitrifying bacteria
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "In our study, nitrifying bacteria responded to a pulsed subsidy of N, both from the natural subsidy during the salmon run and our artificial NH4+ amendment (i.e., hot moment) as well as the experimental under-carcass sampling (i.e., hot spot)." (653)

Full_citation: Rinella, D., Wipfli, M., Walker, C., Stricker, C., & Heintz, R. (2013). Seasonal persistence of marine-derived nutrients in south-central Alaskan salmon streams. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 4(10), Art122-18.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Persistence of MDN in riparian systems
Benefit_1:
ESB: riverine ecosystems
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Spawning salmon deliver annual pulses of marine-derived nutrients (MDN) to riverine ecosystems around the Pacific Rim, leading to increased growth and condition in aquatic and riparian biota." (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: streams
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Stream water ammonium-N and orthophosphate-P concentrations increased with spawner density during the summer salmon runs, but responses did not persist into the following fall" (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream and riparian ecosystems
ESP: eggs, carcasses, fry, spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Annual pulses of marine-derived nutrients (MDN), conveyed to freshwater ecosystems by millions of spawning, semelparous Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) in the form of eggs, excreta, carcasses, and emergent fry, are an ecologically important energy and nutrient subsidy to stream and riparian ecosystems (Gende et al. 2002, Naiman et al. 2002, Schindler et al. 2003)" (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: periphyton, leaf litter decomposition
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Dissolved MDN, excreted by live salmon and liberated from decomposing carcasses, can boost periphyton biomass (Wipfli et al. 1998, 1999, Johnston et al. 2004) and leaf litter decomposition (Claeson et al. 2006)" (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: macroinvertebrates
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " The presence of salmon carcasses enhances growth and development rates for taxa that scavenge carcass material (Minakawa et al. 2002, Walter et al. 2006) and is often associated with increased abundance and biomass of aquatic macroinvertebrates (e.g., Wipfli et al. 1998, 1999, Minakawa and Gara 1999, Claeson et al. 2006, Lessard and Merritt 2006)." (2)
Benefit_6:
ESB: stream-dwelling fishes
ESP: eggs, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Growth and energy storage among stream-dwelling fishes is increased by MDN (Bilby et al. 1996, Wipfli et al. 2003, Heintz et al. 2004, Rinella et al. 2012) and the direct consumption of eggs and carcass material appears to be more important than bottom-up pathways for conveying MDN benefits (Scheuerell et al. 2007, Denton et al. 2009, Armstong et al. 2010)." (2)
Benefit_7:
ESB: riparian soils
ESP: salmon MDN via scavengers and hyporheic processes, flooding, etc.
Sentence describing benefit: "MDN is transferred to the riparian environment by hyporheic processes, flooding, and terrestrial scavengers (Cederholm et al. 1989, Ben-David et al. 1998, Hilderbrand et al. 1999, O’Keefe and Edwards 2002, Quinn et al. 2009), where it enriches riparian soils (Bartz and Naiman 2005, Drake et al. 2005)." (2)
Benefit_8:
ESB: riparian vegetation
ESP: MDN in soils
Sentence describing benefit: " Riparian vegetation can derive a substantial proportion of nitrogen from this pool (Bilby et al. 2003, Reimchen et al. 2003), which may lead to enhanced growth rates (Helfield and Naiman 2001, 2002; but see Kirchhoff 2003 and Helfield and Naiman 2003)." (2)
Benefit_9:
ESB: commercial, subsistence, and sport fisheries
ESP: sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "The Cooper Landing study streams are within the Kenai River basin, the Kenai Peninsula’s largest watershed, which supports substantial commercial, subsistence, and sport fisheries. " (3)
Benefit_10:
ESB: streams
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Concentrations of both nutrients increased with spawner abundance during the summer spawning season, when point estimates of concentrations for both nutrients increased by approximately two orders of magnitude across the observed range in spawner density (i.e., 0–20 MT/km; Fig. 2)." (11)
Benefit_11:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Ammonium-N and orthophosphate-P concentrations increased with spawner density during the summer but not during spring or fall, indicating the presence of a dissolved nutrient spike that had largely attenuated by fall sampling." (12)
Benefit_12:
ESB: macros and Dolly Varden
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " Predictions based on these models showed that generalist macroinvertebrates and Dolly Varden incorporated more MDN as spawner density increased. The evidence was particularly strong for Dolly Varden, where three independent biochemical metrics indicated assimilation of marine nitrogen, sulfur, and fatty acids" (12-13)
Benefit_13:
ESB: Dolly Varden
ESP: salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: ". Dolly Varden x3:x6 exceeded the maximum observed in salmon flesh (i.e., 7.3; R. A. Heintz, unpublished data), suggesting that salmon eggs (with x3:x6 of 12.1–13.9; R. A. Heintz, unpublished data) were an important dietary component (Denton et al. 2009, 2010, Jaecks 2010)." (13)
Benefit_14:
ESB: Dolly Varden, juvenile coho
ESP: MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "An independent data set for Dolly Varden and juvenile coho salmon collected in Kenai Peninsula salmon streams showed MDN presence and associated nutritional benefits to persist through winter and into the following spring (Rinella et al. 2012)." (14)

Full_citation: Bryan, H., Darimont, C., Paquet, P., Wynne-Edwards, K., & Smits, J. (2014). Stress and reproductive hormones reflect inter-specific social and nutritional conditions mediated by resource availability in a bear–salmon system. Conservation Physiology, 2(1), Cou010.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors connected salmon availability to grizzly bear and black bear stress levels.
Benefit_1:
ESB: grizzly bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: ". Cortisol in grizzly bears was higher in individuals that consumed less salmon, possibly reflecting nutritional stress" (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: black bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: ". In black bears, cortisol was better predicted by salmon availability than salmon consumption; specifically, individuals in areas and years with low salmon availability showed higher cortisol levels" (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: grizzly and black bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In areas of North America where they still co-occur, coastal populations of grizzly (Ursus arctos) and black bears (Ursus americanus) have co-evolved with spawning Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) as a nutritious but spatially and temporally constrained food (Jacoby et al., 1999; Reimchen, 2000; Darimont et al., 2010; Levi et al., 2012). " (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: female bears
ESP: salmon fat and protein
Sentence describing benefit: "The fat and protein from salmon come at a critical time for bears before hibernation; pre-denning fat stores are positively correlated with the reproductive success of females the following year (Hilderbrand et al., 2000; Belant et al., 2006)." (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: male grizzly bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Among male grizzly bears, and regardless of year and salmon availability, most bears assimilated >80% of their yearly protein from salmon (Fig. 1C)." (6)
Benefit_6:
ESB: male black bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Among male black bears, salmon consumption was more variable, and all bears assimilated <70% of their yearly protein from salmon." (6)
Benefit_7:
ESB: grizzly bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Cortisol decreased with increasing salmon consumption in both the larger data set (n = 54) and the subset (n = 33) (Table 4 and Fig. 3G)." (6)
Benefit_8:
ESB: black bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Black bear cortisol...Cortisol decreased with salmon availability (Fig. 3B) and increased with testosterone (Table 4)." (6)
Benefit_9:
ESB: grizzly bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Our model selection approach showed that the amount of salmon that grizzly bears consumed—a direct measure of a bear’s nutritional context—better predicts cortisol than salmon availability and watershed productivity, which would affect the number of bears present and the type of intra-specific interactions. These findings support our nutritional hypothesis and are consistent with studies attributing elevated cortisol to nutritional stress in other species (Hellgren et al., 1993; Kitaysky et al., 2007; Behie et al., 2010; Ayres et al., 2012)." (8-10)
Benefit_10:
ESB: black bears
ESP: salmon 
Sentence describing benefit: "In contrast to grizzly bears, cortisol in black bears was more strongly predicted by salmon availability than salmon consumption; cortisol was lower when more salmon were available. These findings indicate that cortisol in black bears is influenced more strongly by the social environment mediated by yearly trends in salmon abundance than by the nutritional context alone" (10)

Full_citation: Harding, J., & Reynolds, J. (2014). From earth and ocean: Investigating the importance of cross-ecosystem resource linkages to a mobile estuarine consumer. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 5(5), Art54-23.

Benefit_1:
ESB: FW + terrestrial communities
ESP: Pacific salmon

Benefit_2:
ESB: watersheds
ESP: carcasses via carnivores and water movement
Sentence describing benefit: "Their carcasses are spread throughoutwatersheds by water movement and carnivores, releasing high concentrations of nitrogen in addition to other nutrients such as carbon and phosphorous. " (2)
Benefit_3:
ESB: FW + riparian habitats
ESP: spawners, eggs, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "However, the net effects of spawning salmon can vary (Harding et al. 2014); salmon can subsidize freshwater and riparian habitats through excretion and egg and carcass deposition (Kline et al. 1990, Cederholm et al. 1999, Janetski et al. 2009), and can export nutrients with juvenile emigration and disturbance as adults dig and defend nests (Moore et al. 2007, Kohler et al. 2013)." (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Dungeness crab
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Individuals have been observed scavenging on salmon carcasses in estuaries during fall salmon runs (J. M. S. Harding, personal observation) and Dungeness crab stable isotope ratios can be enriched relative to salmon (Christensen et al. 2013). This suggests salmon could provide a substantial dietary contribution to Dungeness crabs" (3)
Benefit_5:
ESB: Dungeness crab
ESP: spawning salmon 
Sentence describing benefit: "Also as predicted, crab d15N enriched with increasing salmon density (Fig. 2B)." (9)
Benefit_6:
ESB: Dungeness crab
ESP: adult salmon/carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In contrast to watershed size and red alder, upstream adult salmon density had a strong enrichment effect on Dungeness crab d15N. This confirms our observation that crabs feed on salmon carcasses and our prediction that the density of salmon upstream can mediate this effect." (14)
Benefit_7:
ESB: estuaries
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Our work suggests estuaries can also benefit directly from these annual nutrient pulses in the Northern Pacific" (15)
Benefit_8:
ESB: First Nations, commercial, recreational fisheries
ESP: Estuarine salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Lastly, estuaries support rich ecosystems that host traditional resources utilized by Coastal First Nations and support commercial and recreational fisheries. Therefore, conservation efforts should prioritize areas where industrial land-use activities are being considered upstream of estuaries that are of particular food, social and ceremonial importance to First Nations, support abundant food resources or possess other high conservation values." (16)

Full_citation: Wheeler, T., Kavanagh, K., & Daanen, S. (2014). Terrestrial Salmon Carcass Decomposition: Nutrient and Isotopic Dynamics in Central Idaho. Northwest Science, 88(2), 106-119.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of freezing and pasteurizing salmon carcasses on decomposition and release of nutrients and other things into semi-arid soil.
Benefit_1:
ESB: soil
ESP: hatchery carcass
Sentence describing benefit: " Soil dissolved organic C (DOC) and dissolved total N (DTN) increased dramatically with respective increases from pretreatment concentrations of 7 and 48 fold by the time skeletonization occurred. " (106)
Benefit_2:
ESB: soil
ESP: hatchery carcass
Sentence describing benefit: ". Isotopic analysis of fluids beneath the carcasses revealed up to a 6‰ change in fluid δ13C and δ15N during decomposition as well as an overall 4‰ enrichment in mean fluid δ15N, relative to whole reference carcasses. " (106)
Benefit_3:
ESB: terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: carcasses via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Bears in particular are known to transport large quantities of nutrient rich salmon carcasses into terrestrial ecosystems (Cederholm et al. 1989, Gende and Quinn 2004, Quinn et al. 2009) and to redistribute salmon derived nutrients through metabolic wastes (Hilderbrand et al. 1999). " (106)
Benefit_4:
ESB: coastal rainforest soil
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Soil nutrients have been found to increase markedly in the immediate vicinity of decaying salmon carcasses in coastal rainforests (Holtgrieve et al. 2009) and remain elevated for at least 154 days (Drake et al. 2005, Gende et al. 2007)." (106)
Benefit_5:
ESB: coastal riparian forest soil
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: ". The decomposition of salmon carcasses and the subsequent release of nutrients in a coastal riparian forest have also been documented (Drake et al. 2005). " (106)
Benefit_6:
ESB: soil
ESP: hatchery carcass
Sentence describing benefit: "The timing of soil DOC and DTN accumulation closely tracked the carcass decomposition rates. Large increases in DOC and DTN were measured at 191 ADD (Figures 3A and B), which coincides with the period of greatest relative daily weight loss (Figure 2A). The mean cumulative increase in soil DOC and DTN was 1057 mg C kg-1 dry soil (SE 159) and 885 mg N kg-1 dry soil (SE 115) per kg of pretreatment carcass mass at the termination of decomposition (Figures 3A and 3B)." (112)
Benefit_7:
ESB: fly larvae
ESP: hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The colonization of fly larvae was not impacted as flies readily laid their eggs through the mesh stocking and egg presence on the salmon carcasses was noted on the second calendar day (40ADD)." (114-5)
Benefit_8:
ESB: soil
ESP: hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Our findings suggest that the release of carcass nutrients to the soil predominantly occurs after decomposition has progressed roughly half way to skeletonization. We observed a respective 6 fold and 40 fold increase, relative to pretreatment values, in soil DOC and DTN (data not shown) between 106 and 299 ADD (Figure 3A and B). This rapid increase in soil DOC and DTN coincided with the period of rapid carcass weight loss or decomposition (Figure 2A and B) and was most likely due to fluid discharge from the carcasses" (115)
Benefit_9:
ESB: plants and microbes
ESP: carcasses via decomposition
Sentence describing benefit: "The end result is a large increase in soil inorganic N that becomes available for plant and further microbial utilization." (116)

Full_citation: Nelson, M., & Reynolds, J. (2014). Time-delayed subsidies: Interspecies population effects in salmon. PloS One, 9(6), E98951.

Benefit_1:
ESB: juvenile coho

Benefit_2:
ESB: FW streams + lakes
ESP: spawning salmon

Benefit_3:
ESB: adult coho
ESP: spawning pinks

Benefit_4:

Benefit_5:

ESP: salmon MDN

(1)
Benefit_6:
ESB: primary producers, aquatic invertebrates, terrestrial invertebrates
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "However, stable isotope tracing has shown spawning salmon nutrients are readily taken up by primary producers, aquatic invertebrates [30] and terrestrial invertebrates [25], and these may provide indirect pathways to juvenile coho salmon." (2)
Benefit_7:
ESB: juvenile salmonids, esp. coho
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Studies have shown increased spawning salmon resource availability is linked to improved condition and growth in juvenile salmonids ([21] Scheuerell et al. 2007), and coho in particular [18,31–32]." (2)
Benefit_8:
ESB: juvenile coho
ESP: adult pink and chum
Sentence describing benefit: "High summer juvenile coho abundance was associated with high pink and chum abundance and large watershed size (PC1, Figure 1). " (5)
Benefit_9:
ESB: juvenile coho
ESP: spawning pink salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We found that streams containing higher densities of spawning pink salmon had more juvenile coho salmon." (6)
Benefit_10:
ESB: juvenile coho
ESP: spawning chum
Sentence describing benefit: "Juvenile coho were also more abundant in streams that had more spawning chum salmon, though this was true only in the summer period prior to the arrival of spawning adult chum" (6)
Benefit_11:
ESB: stream biofilm
ESP: spawning salmon

(6)
Benefit_12:
ESB: aquatic invertebrates

Benefit_13:

Full_citation: Bellmore, J., Fremier, A., Mejia, F., & Newsom, M. (2014). The response of stream periphyton to Pacific salmon: Using a model to understand the role of environmental context. Freshwater Biology, 59(7), 1437-1451.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors model relationship between spawning salmon and periphyton production/biomass to determine conditions in which the net effect will be positive vs. negative.
Location: Columbia River Basin, USA and Canada
Essential_notes: -Main takeaway: "This suggests that any increase in production by fish or invertebrates in response to returning salmon is more likely to occur via direct consumption of salmon carcasses and/or eggs, rather than the indirect effects of greater periphyton production." (1437)
Benefit_1:
ESB: stream ecosystems
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " In stream ecosystems, Pacific salmon deliver subsidies of marine-derived nutrients and disturb the stream bed during spawning." (1437)
Benefit_2:
ESB: primary producers, streams
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In stream ecosystems, spawning Pacific salmon both deliver subsidies of marine-derived nutrients and disturb the stream bed during spawning (Gende et al., 2002; Moore, Schindler & Scheuerell, 2004). The net effect of this resource subsidy and physical disturbance on primary producers at the base of stream food webs is mixed, with empirical studies showing both increases and decreases in periphyton biomass and production (Janetski et al., 2009; Verspoor, Braun & Reynolds, 2010)." (1437)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream chem
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The contribution of dissolved nitrogen [Nsalmon] and phosphorus [SRPsalmon] in the water column from live salmon spawners (in mg L1) is calculated as: ½Nsalmon ¼ BsalmonNexcret Q86 400 ½  SRPsalmon ¼ BsalmonSRPexcret Q86 400 ð10Þ where Bsalmon is the total biomass of salmon in the spawning reach, Nexcret and SRPexcret are mass-specific daily nutrient excretion rates (mg g1 day1) and Q is discharge (L s1), which is multiplied by the number of seconds in a day, to calculate the total volume of water moving through the spawning segment per day." (1441)
Benefit_4:
ESB: stream chem
ESP: salmon carcass
Sentence describing benefit: " After mortality, the contribution of nutrients from carcasses is determined by replacing live salmon biomass and nutrient excretion rates, with carcass biomass (Bcarcass) and associated nutrient leaching rates (Nleach, SRPleach)." (1441)
Benefit_5:
ESB: periphyton
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "At low background concentrations of nutrients, salmon initially increased periphyton biomass above background conditions (no spawners; Fig. 5a–c). After spawning began, however, the response depended on the proportion of the habitat suitable for spawning. When 10% of the habitat was suitable (Fig. 5a), periphyton biomass generally remained above background throughout the simulation." (1444)

Full_citation: Harding, J., Harding, J., & Reynolds, J. (2014). Movers and shakers: Nutrient subsidies and benthic disturbance predict biofilm biomass and stable isotope signatures in coastal streams. Freshwater Biology, 59(7), 1361-1377.

ESB: FW streams

Benefit_2:

Benefit_3:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: live salmon, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Some experimental studies with live salmon, salmon carcasses or analogues of carcasses have shown a positive effect on biofilm chlorophyll a (chl a; a measure of algal abundance) and ash-free dry mass (AFDM; a measure of total organic matter) in natural streambeds and experimental channels (Lamberti & Steinman, 1997; Wipfli et al., 1999; Chaloner et al., 2004; Johnston et al., 2004; Merritt et al., 2008; Ruegg € et al., 2012)." (1362)
Benefit_4:
ESB: researchers, including First Nation researchers

Benefit_5:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: spawning salmon

Benefit_6:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit:
Benefit_7:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "As predicted, streams with higher salmon densities had higher biofilm d15N in both spring and autumn (Figs 5 & 6a), with a positive salmon effect almost twice that of any other variable included in the averaged model (spring and autumn effect sizes = 2.56 and 2.52; Fig. 5)." (1370)
Benefit_8:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: spawning salmon

" (1370)

ESB: biofilm
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "As seen in other studies, and consistent with our predictions, biofilm from salmon spawning areas had consistently higher d15N and d13C than sites with no spawning adults, regardless of season (Kline et al., 1990; Bilby, Fransen & Bisson, 1996; Verspoor et al., 2010; Reisinger et al., 2013). This was particularly true in the autumn for d15N." (1372)
Benefit_11:
ESB: algae
ESP: previous years of spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "What is most interesting is that even though disturbance by salmon results in a decrease in biofilm during spawning, salmon-derived nutrients from previous years are linked to an increase in both isotopes and algal biomass in salmon spawning reaches, prior to the arrival of salmon." (1374)

Full_citation: Rüegg, J., Currier, C., Chaloner, D., Tiegs, S., & Lamberti, G. (2014). Habitat influences Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) tissue decomposition in riparian and stream ecosystems. Aquatic Sciences, 76(4), 623-632.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors studied decomposition and colonization rates in terrestrial vs. aquatic habitat as well as nutrient patterns.
Location: Prince of Wales Island, AK, USA
Benefit_1:
ESB: aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Decomposition incorporates organic material delivered by Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) into aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems of streams where salmon spawn. " (623)
Benefit_2:
ESB: North Pacific watersheds
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " In watersheds along the North Pacific rim, annual spawning migrations of Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) provide a source of marine-derived organic matter potentially more important than leaves (Gende et al. 2002; Schindler et al. 2003)." (623)
Benefit_3:
ESB: riparian vegetation, invertebrates, other consumers
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "In terrestrial ecosystems, salmon influence has been measured as incorporation of salmon nutrients into riparian vegetation (e.g., Hocking and Reynolds 2011), colonization of carcasses by invertebrates (e.g., Hocking and Reimchen 2006), and consumption by higher trophic-level consumers (Christie et al. 2008)" (624)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Sphaeroceridae and Calliphoridae
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In terrestrial habitats, two necrophagous dipteran families, Sphaeroceridae and Calliphoridae, were the dominant colonizers of salmon tissue in riparian and gravel bar habitats, respectively." (628-9)
Benefit_5:
ESB: chironomids, stoneflies (Sweltsa)
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "While overall number of taxa was similar in the two aquatic habitats, chironomids dominated the tissue fauna at the sediment surface while the stonefly genus Sweltsa dominated on buried tissue." (629)
Benefit_6:
ESB: streams
ESP: spawners, eggs, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon spawners have been shown to alter dissolved nutrient concentration in streams (Levi et al. 2011), and both N and C have been shown to be taken up isotopically in food webs (Janetski et al. 2009), with potential to create ‘hot moments’, due to the pulsed nature of salmon migrations (cf. McClain et al. 2003), and ‘hotspots’ where eggs are laid and carcasses senesce (cf. McIntyre et al. 2008)." (630)
Benefit_7:
ESB: flies, beetle (Nicrophorus investigator)
ESP:  carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The two dominant families of flies in this study and the beetle Nicrophorus investigator have been documented to rely almost exclusively on salmon carcasses during their development (Hocking and Reimchen 2006; Hocking et al. 2006). " (631)
Benefit_8:
ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:

Full_citation: Collins, S., & Baxter, C. (2014). Heterogeneity of riparian habitats mediates responses of terrestrial arthropods to a subsidy of Pacific salmon carcasses. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 5(11), Art146-14.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of salmon carcasses on arthropod community composition and abundance in vegetated and non-vegetated patches.
Location: North Fork of Boise River drainage, central Idaho, USA
Benefit_1:
ESB: dipteran arthropods
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Arthropod community composition differed between habitats, and salmon additions yielded strong positive changes in arthropod abundance among select families. Four dipteran families responded positively to additions of carcasses to riparian habitats, and effects were generally stronger in vegetated habitats" (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: coleopteran Staphylinidae
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: ". Of the five predatory arthropod families observed, only the coleopteran, Staphylinidae, increased in response to the salmon carcass subsidy, and only in vegetated habitats." (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: FW habitats, riparian and terrestrial plants, arthropods, mammals, and birds
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The carcasses of salmon are a resource subsidy frequently trans-located to a mosaic of patch types. They provide a marine-derived nutrient and food resource not only for the freshwater habitats to which these animals return to spawn, but for many riparian and upland plants, arthropods, mammals, and birds (Quinn and Buck 2000, Helfield and Naiman 2001, Hocking et al. 2009, Quinn et al. 2009)." (3)
Benefit_4:
ESB: arthropods
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " Stable isotope analyses indicate that a wide range of arthropods, encompassing numerous feeding guilds, utilize salmon-derived C and N (Hocking et al. 2009)." (3)
Benefit_5:
ESB: arthropods
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Arthropods were observed on the carcasses in deposited in both vegetated and un-vegetated habitats...Subsequently, carcasses were consumed and decomposed faster in vegetated than in unvegetated habitats" (6)
Benefit_6:
ESB: arthropods
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "At the patch scale, the addition of salmon carcasses to both vegetated and un-vegetated habitats had a positive effect on the total abundance of arthropods (MANOVA, F ¼ 4.28, P ¼ 0.0057). " (7)
Benefit_7:
ESB: Calliphoridae larvae
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Carcasses did not increase the abundance of adult Calliphoridae flies captured in pitfall traps during the experiment, but those present deposited eggs, and the larvae consumed carcass material." (7)
Benefit_8:
ESB: Drosophilia
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Similarly, abundance of Drosophilidae was greatest in vegetated patches with salmon carcasses, though the overall magnitude of effect was low in comparison to those on other taxa." (7)
Benefit_9:
ESB: Calliphoridae
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Consistent with our findings at the patch scale, total abundance of adult Calliphoridae increased both initially and four to six weeks after treatment additions on sticky traps along carcass treated streams in comparison to controls (Fig. 4, Time 3 Treatment, F ¼ 6.82, P ¼ 0.004)." (7)
Benefit_10:
ESB: arthropods
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "We observed that salmon carcasses in riparian habitats caused increases in arthropod abundance among four saprophagic families and one predatory family over the duration of our experiment, and that in most cases the strength of response differed by patch type." (9-10)
Benefit_11:
ESB: Drosophilia, Sphaeroceridae, Sciaridae
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Salmon carcasses added to riparian habitats caused increases in three other dipterans, Drosophilidae, Sphaeroceridae, and Sciaridae, all of which likely fed directly on putrefied tissue and bacteria at advanced stages of decomposition. " (10)

Full_citation: Harding, J., & Reynolds, J. (2014). Opposing forces: Evaluating multiple ecological roles of Pacific salmon in coastal stream ecosystems. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 5(12), Art157-22.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of salmon MDN and disturbance on stream invertebrate nutrients and density.
Essential_notes: -varies by stream narrative
Benefit_1:
ESB: streams and lakes
ESP: migrating salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Annual mass migrations of Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) to coastal watersheds import vast quantities of potentially limiting nutrients that have been shown to increase primary and secondary productivity in streams and lakes." (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: stream invertebrates
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "We found that stream invertebrates assimilate salmon-derived nutrients in proportion to availability but invertebrate biomass density declines in both seasons with increasing salmon density. " (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: FW + terrestrial environments
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) have long been recognized as vectors of high quality nutrients to freshwater and terrestrial environments (Juday et al. 1932, Naiman et al. 2002, Janetski et al. 2009) and more recently as a significant source of disturbance to benthic freshwater communities (Moore and Schindler 2008, Janetski et al. 2009, Harding et al. 2014)." (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: streams
ESP: migrating salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Mass migrations of salmon can import as much as 266 g/m2 of nitrogen to streams on the central coast of British Columbia in high abundance years (Harding et al. 2014), while as much as 55% of nitrogen imported by salmon can be exported out of streams through their spawning behavior (Moore et al. 2007)." (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: invertebrates
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " Some studies have found that invertebrates from streams with higher salmon density have a more enriched nitrogen and carbon isotope signature (Bilby et al. 1996, Hicks et al. 2005) and are found in greater numbers (Wipfli et al. 1999, Verspoor et al. 2011), while other studies have found fewer invertebrates in the presence of spawning salmon (Moore et al. 2004, Moore and Schindler 2008)." (2)
Benefit_6:
ESB: invertebrates
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "As predicted, invertebrates from sites downstream of the barriers had higher d15N than those from upstream sites in both seasons and this difference was more pronounced in the fall (spring, mean difference ¼ 3.1%, ANOVA, F1,98 ¼ 47.75, p , 0.0001; fall, mean differenc ¼ 4.5%, ANOVA, F1,68¼ 81.31, p , 0.0001; Fig. 2A–H)." (9)
Benefit_7:
ESB: predator invertebrates
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " Predators downstream of the barriers in the fall had the most enriched d15N (mean 6 2 SD ¼ 10.06% 6 2.93%; Fig. 2H, whereas the least enriched invertebrates were collector-gatherers upstream of the barriers in the spring (1.43% 6 1.61%; Fig. 2C)." (9)
Benefit_8:
ESB: invertebrates
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "The d15N of invertebrates increased with salmon density from the previous spawning year; d15N of shredders and predators became more enriched with salmon density in both seasons, while salmon density had the greatest positive effect on grazers and collector-gatherers d15N in the fall (Fig. 5A, B and Fig. 6A-D)." (9-11)
Benefit_9:
ESB: invertebrates
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Invertebrate d13C became more enriched with salmon density and to a greater extent in fall when salmon were present (Fig. 5C, D). The greatest enrichment was in spring collectorgatherers and fall shredders (Fig. 7A, C)." (11-2)
Benefit_10:
ESB: invertebrates **USE THIS ONE**
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "As predicted, when we controlled for habitat in the within-stream comparison, we found that all four functional feeding groups of invertebrates had enriched d15N and d13C signatures below spawning barriers compared to upstream, particularly in the fall when salmon were spawning. Also, d15N varied by functional feeding group, with predators having the most enriched signature followed by collector-gatherers, shredders and grazers." (13)
Benefit_11:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " Harding et al. (2014) showed that biofilm in the same streams were enriched in both 15N and 13C in spring and fall, which was linked to salmon density" (13)
Benefit_12:
ESB: riparian plants
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Riparian plants in this region are more enriched in 15N and have higher percent nitrogen in streams with higher salmon densities (Hocking and Reynolds 2012)." (14)
Benefit_13:
ESB: invertebrates
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In summary, we found that regardless of functional feeding group, benthic macroinvertebrate d15N and d13C increased with salmon density from the previous fall" (15)

Full_citation: Coutré, K., Beaudreau, A., & Malecha, P. (2015). Temporal Variation in Diet Composition and Use of Pulsed Resource Subsidies by Juvenile Sablefish. Transactions of the American Fisheries Society (1900), 144(4), 807-819.
Journal: Transactions of the American Fisheries Society
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Identifying sablefish prey in nearshore environment over time.
Location: St. John Baptist Bay, Baranof Island, AK
Benefit_1:
ESB: juvenile sablefish
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " In September of both years, spawning Pink Salmon Oncorhynchus gorbuscha were observed within the study area and juvenile Sablefish capitalized on this high energy subsidy, and salmon carcasses were among the top contributors to their diets by weight" (807)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Arctic grayling and rainbow trout
ESP: sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, Bentley et al. (2012) documented the profound impact that the influx of Sockeye Salmon Oncorhynchus nerka had on ration size and growth rate of Rainbow Trout O. mykiss and Arctic Grayling Thymallus arcticus in two freshwater streams" (807)
Benefit_3:
ESB: bears
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " For example, in years of high salmon run size, bears Ursus spp. in Alaska selectively consumed the parts of salmon with the highest energetic value, while in years of low salmon returns, bears ate more whole fish (Gende et al. 2002)." (808)
Benefit_4:
ESB: predators
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " In the nearshore marine environment, anadromous fishes such as Pacific salmon Oncorhynchus spp. and Eulachon Thaleichthys pacificus provide a seasonal energy source for many predators (Sigler et al. 2004)" (808)
Benefit_5:
ESB: juvenile sablefish
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Unlike previous juvenile Sablefish studies in lower latitudes, the current study documents juveniles scavenging on salmon carcasses (McFarlane and Beamish 1983; Cailliet et al. 1988)." (815)
Benefit_6:
ESB: juvenile sablefish
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " The only sampling period in which forage fish made up <50% of the diet by weight was September 2013, when the majority of the diet was composed of scavenged salmon. We estimated the highest energy diet for juvenile Sablefish during this period." (816)
Benefit_7:
ESB: terrestrial, freshwater, and avian predators
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Pacific salmon pulses have been widely documented to be a beneficial source of marine derived nutrients to terrestrial predators, such as bears, wolves, foxes, and martens; freshwater predators, such as Arctic Grayling, Dolly Varden Salvelinus malma, and Rainbow Trout; and avian predators, such as bald eagles Haliaeetus leucocephalus, gulls, crows, and common ravens Corvus corax (Willson and Halupka 1995; Schindler et al. 2003; Bentley et al. 2012)." (816)
Benefit_8:
ESB: mammals
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Documentation of marine predators exploiting adult spawning salmon pulses in the nearshore has primarily focused on mammals including seals, sea lions, and cetaceans (Willson and Halupka 1995; Saulitis et al. 2000; Sinclair and Zeppelin 2002)." (816)
Benefit_9:
ESB: juvenile sablefish
ESP: juvenile salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " In 1999, juvenile Sablefish fed on juvenile salmon migrating from freshwater to the Gulf of Alaska, suggesting that they cue to multiple life stages of salmon as a food resource (Sturdevant et al. 2009)." (816)
Benefit_10:
ESB: arctic grayling and rainbow trout
ESP: sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Other fishes such as Rainbow Trout and Arctic Grayling experience significantly increased ration size and growth rate as a result of increased salmon densities (Bentley et al. 2012). Average ration size increased by up to 491% for Arctic Grayling and 200% for Rainbow Trout when Sockeye Salmon densities were high in two freshwater streams, and Rainbow Trout switched to a diet of almost entirely salmon (Bentley et al. 2012)" (817)

Full_citation: Scheuerell, M., Buhle, E., Semmens, B., Ford, M., Cooney, T., & Carmichael, R. (2015). Analyzing large‐scale conservation interventions with Bayesian hierarchical models: A case study of supplementing threatened Pacific salmon. Ecology and Evolution, 5(10), 2115-2125.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of hatchery supplementation on adult Chinook populations in Snake River Basin, based on 43 years and 22 populations' worth of data.
Benefit_1:
ESB: Chinook populations
ESP: hatchery Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "We found that varying degrees of supplementation over a period of 25 years increased the density of natural-origin adults, on average, by 0–8% relative to nonsupplementation years" (2115)
Benefit_2:
ESB: residents near Columbia River Basin
ESP: Pacific salmon via taxpayers
Sentence describing benefit: "Efforts to rebuild depressed populations are extensive and expensive. For example, in the Columbia River Basin, which contains 13 listed ESUs of Pacific salmon, more than 15,000 habitat restoration projects have been undertaken at an annual cost of over $150 million USD (Barnas and Katz 2010)." (2116)
Benefit_3:
ESB: tribal, commercial, recreational fisheries
ESP: hatchery salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In the US Pacific Northwest, salmon hatcheries release about 400 million juveniles per year at a cost of roughly $40 million USD (Naish et al. 2008). Many of these fish are produced to meet tribal, commercial, or recreational harvest demands, or to mitigate for habitat loss." (2116)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Chinook populations
ESP: hatchery chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "We found that, on average, supplementation has increased adult density among the 12 supplemented populations by only 3.3%." (2116)

Full_citation: Naves, L., Simeone, W., Lowe, M., Valentine, E., Stickwan, G., & Brady, J. (2015). Cultural Consensus on Salmon Fisheries and Ecology in the Copper River, Alaska. Arctic, 68(2), 210-222.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors analyzed consensus and divergence in knowledge and opinions of three groups: Ahtna involved in subsistence fisheries, commercial fishers, fishery managers and biologists
Benefit_1:
ESB: commercial fishery
ESP: salmon, esp. sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "In 2001-10, the Copper River commercial fishery harvest averaged 1.6 million salmon per year, of which 75% were sockeye salmon." (212)
Benefit_2:
ESB: dip-net fishers (residents mostly outside Copper River watershed)
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The personal-use dip net fishery (about 8000 household permits per year) averaged about 114000 salmon annually. Most personal-use dip net permits are issued to residents of urban centers outside the Copper River watershed" (212)
Benefit_3:
ESB: subsistence fisheries
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The subsistence dip net and fish wheel fisheries (about 1100 annual household permits) averaged 80000 salmon per year" (212)
Benefit_4:
ESB: subsistence fishery
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "An upper river subsistence fishery operates along the main stem between the communities of Chitina and Slana. Smaller subsistence fisheries operate at the traditional site of Batzulnetas (in the headwaters) and also in estuarine and marine waters at the river mouth (Botz and Somerville, 2011; Botz et al. 2012)." (212)
Benefit_5:
ESB: sport fishery
ESP: Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "The sport rod and reel fishery averages about 15000 salmon per year and targets king salmon, accounting for the second-largest harvest component for this species after the commercial fishery (Somerville, 2011)" (212)"
Benefit_6:
ESB: contemporary Ahtna communities
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "salmon is a main subsistence resource for these communities while diverse other resources, such as moose, berries, and small land mammals, are also harvested (Kukkonen and Zimpelman, 2012; La Vine et al., 2013)" (212)
Benefit_7:
ESB: Ahtna communities
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Ahtna relations with salmon date back more than 2000 years" (212)
Benefit_8:
ESB: Ahtna communities
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Over this time, they developed sophisticated methods for harvesting and processing salmon, protocols governing the treatment and use of salmon, and an oral tradition on the origin of Copper River salmon (de Laguna, 1969; Workman, 1977; de Laguna and McClellan, 1981; Kari, 1986)" (212)
Benefit_9:
ESB: commercial fisheries, Cordova
ESP: salmon via commercial fisheries
Sentence describing benefit: "Commercial fishing began in the Copper River delta region in 1889, and since then it has been the mainstay of the economy and culture of the city of Cordova (population of 2239 in 2010; US Census Bureau, 2011)." (212)
Benefit_10:
ESB: Cordova households
ESP: salmon via commercial fisheries
Sentence describing benefit: "Almost have of Cordova's households have at least one member working in fish harvesting or processing" (212)
Benefit_11:
ESB: permitted Cordova residents
ESP: salmon via commercial fisheries
Sentence describing benefit: "In 2008, 347 commercial salmon permits (out of a total of 500) were issued to Cordova residents, leading to local earnings of about 29 million dollars (Alaska Commercial Fisheries Entry Commission, 2008a)" (212)
Benefit_12:
ESB: managers and biologists
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In the Copper River fisheries management system..., managers and biologists conduct research on salmon population dynamics, including assessments of salmon abundance and timing of migrations, characterization of stocks, genetic and ecological interactions between hatchery and wild stocks, and monitoring of wild stock productivity. The data generated are used to inform policies and actions for fisheries management" (212)
Benefit_13:
ESB: Ahtna people
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The Ahtna believe salmon to be sentient, moral beings that give themselves to people as long as they are treated with respect and users are not wasteful" (212)
Benefit_14:
ESB: rural communities with recognized customary and traditional uses
ESP: salmon via feds
Sentence describing benefit: "Participation in federally authorized subsistence fisheries is limited to residents of rural communities with recognized customary and traditional uses" (213)
Benefit_15:
ESB: Ahtna communities
ESP: salmon via feds
Sentence describing benefit: "All Ahtna communities have federally recognized customary and traditional uses of Copper River salmon" (213)
Benefit_16:
ESB: wild salmon returns
ESP: hatchery fish
Sentence describing benefit: "Supplementing wild salmon returns with hatchery fish is another management tool used in the Copper River. In the early 1970s, a hatchery was established in the headwaters of the Gulkana River to mitigate loss of spawning habitat due to road construction. Fertilized eggs are produced from local wild salmon and released as juvenile fish. In 2002-11, the estimated average return of hatchery sockeye salmon was 300000 fish/year and represented 5%-29% of the total returns (Stopha, 2013)." (213)
Benefit_17:
ESB: Ahtna communities, Yup'ik people
ESP: salmon via social structures
Sentence describing benefit: "To show respect for and placate salmon, Ahtna have developed protocols for diverse aspects of salmon fishing such as building a fish rack, handling and processing the catch, and sharing salmon foods (Workman, 1977; de Laguna and McClellan, 1981; Simeone and Kari, 2002). Similar views have been documented among Yup'ik people in western Alaska (Wolfe, 1988)" (217)
Benefit_18:
ESB: Ahtna communities
ESP: salmon via social structures
Sentence describing benefit: "Some Ahtna comments referred to relationships between people and salmon (e.g. 'I know they say to be real careful when you handle fish, keep your mind on what you're doing, don't drop them' and 'We have to take really good care of the fish in all we do. The old people who lived before us knew lots. We don't do like them anymore. I would like to go back so I can see the old people, how they do things')" (217)
Benefit_19:
ESB: Ahtna communities
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Ahtna have a long history of discussing and challenging practices and decisions in fisheries management and they testify before the Board of Fisheries and submit proposals to change regulations (Simeone and McCall Valentine, 2007)." (218)
Benefit_20:
ESB: Ahtna communities
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Ahtna familiarity with individual salmon stocks is demonstrated by many traditional place names for upper-river spawning streams, which often refer to a stream's characteristics or morphological aspects of its salmon (Kari and Tuttle, 2005)." (218)

Full_citation: Swain, N., & Reynolds, J. (2015). Effects of salmon-derived nutrients and habitat characteristics on population densities of stream-resident sculpins. PloS One, 10(6), E0116090.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of pink and chum spawning density on population density of sculpins.
Essential_notes: -context dependent/varies by stream narrative
Benefit_1:
ESB: vertebrate consumers
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "While a growing body of research has highlighted the importance of both pulsed nutrient subsidies and disturbance by spawning salmon, their effects on population densities of vertebrate consumers have rarely been tested, especially across streams spanning a wide range of natural variation in salmon densities and habitat characteristics" (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: coastrange sculpins
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Coastrange sculpins occurred in the highest densities in streams with high densities of spawning pink and chum salmon." (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: FW systems
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Semelparous Pacific salmon accumulate up to 99% of their body mass at sea before returning to freshwater systems where they spawn and die, often in high densities, delivering marine-derived nutrients to these typically nutrient-limited systems through their eggs, excretions and decomposing carcasses [10, 11, 12]. " (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: consumers + foodwebs
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "This provides strong pulsed nutrient subsidies that can affect organisms consuming salmon eggs and carcasses directly (e.g., [13, 14], but see [15]), and also influence food webs through bottom-up effects of increased primary productivity (e.g., [16, 17]), or when consumers switch their diets to salmon (e.g., [14, 18])." (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: periphyton, benthic macroinvertebrates, juvenile salmonids, stream-resident fish
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Researchers have used stomach content and stable isotope analyses to trace nutrients from salmon through multiple trophic levels in streams, including periphyton, benthic macroinvertebrates, juvenile salmonids, and resident freshwater fish (e.g., [17, 18, 25, 26, 27])." (2)
Benefit_6:
ESB: adult sculpins
ESP: salmon eggs and spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, we have found that salmon-derived nutrients in sculpin diets are highest in streams with high salmon densities, through both direct consumption of eggs by adult sculpins, and via consumption of benthic invertebrates, which also have elevated salmon nutrient signatures [18]." (2)
Benefit_7:
ESB: juvenile salmonids
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Increased availability of salmon subsidies has also been linked to condition and growth in juvenile salmonids [14, 28, 29], and more recently, to their distribution and aggregation within freshwater habitats [30]." (2)
Benefit_8:
ESB: researchers, Heiltsuk First Nation
ESP: salmon enumeration
Sentence describing benefit: "From 2006–2010, autumn salmon enumeration was conducted jointly by people from Simon Fraser University, the Heiltsuk First Nation, and Fisheries and Oceans Canada from late August to early November. Spawning salmon counts were done by stream surveys on foot, with the aim of visiting each stream at least three times during the spawning season." (6)
Benefit_9:
ESB: coastrange sculpin
ESP: spawning pink and chum
Sentence describing benefit: " In general, coastrange sculpins were found in the highest densities in streams with greater spawning densities of pink and chum salmon adults, high water pH, less area covered by pools and large wood, and lower gradients...Our results suggest that coastrange sculpin density and biomass may benefit from increased availability of salmon nutrients in these streams." (12)
Benefit_10:
ESB: juvenile salmonids
ESP: spawning salmon + hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Bilby et al. [13] compared two reference streams with low spawning salmon densities to two streams where naturally spawning salmon carcasses were augmented by hatchery carcasses in autumn and found that condition of juvenile salmonids increased with carcass additions when salmon were spawning" (14)
Benefit_11:
ESB: juvenile and resident salmonids
ESP: carcasses, salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Similarly, Wipfli et al. [66] found increased growth in juvenile salmonids with carcass additions in artificial stream channels and natural stream reaches, and Denton et al. [30] found that growth rates of resident salmonids increased with the availability of salmon eggs and blowfly larvae associated with naturally spawning salmon in ponds." (14)
Benefit_12:
ESB: trout and grayling
ESP: productivity via spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Bentley et al. [31] recently showed that growth rates of resident trout and grayling were positively related to natural salmon spawning densities in two streams over the course of over a decade, and that this relationship was influenced by in situ stream productivity" (14)
Benefit_13:
ESB: sculpin
ESP: spawning density
Sentence describing benefit: "Swain et al. [18] also found some evidence that sculpin condition increased with salmon densities across over 30 coastal streams" (14)

Full_citation: Nelson, M., & Reynolds, J. (2015). Effects of subsidies from spawning chum and pink salmon on juvenile coho salmon body size and migration timing. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 6(10), Art209.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Relationship between spawning density of pink and chum on body size and age composition - as a proxy for migration timing - in juvenile coho.
Benefit_1:
ESB: juvenile coho
ESP: spawning chum
Sentence describing benefit: "Chum salmon density was the most consistently important and positive correlate of coho body size, in comparison with pink salmon density, juvenile coho salmon density, and numerous characteristics of habitats" (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: juvenile rainbow trout and coho
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The presence of spawning salmon increased energy intake of juvenile rainbow trout (Scheuerell et al. 2007), and coho salmon (Heintz et al. 2004, Armstrong et al. 2010)." (2)
Benefit_3:
ESB: juvenile coho
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Furthermore, nutrients from spawning salmon have been linked to improved condition and growth rate of juvenile coho in a number of carcass addition experiments (e.g., Bilby et al. 1998, Wipfli et al. 2010)" (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Heiltsuk First Nation scientists
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Additional on-foot stream counts were used for the remainder of sites, undertaken in partnership with the Heiltsuk First Nation’s Integrated Resource Management Department." (4)
Benefit_5:
ESB: juvenile coho salmon
ESP: spawning chum
Sentence describing benefit: "We found larger juvenile coho salmon in streams with higher densities of spawning chum salmon, and larger juvenile coho salmon below natural barriers to spawning chum and pink salmon compared to above barriers at high spawning salmon density streams. For age 0 coho salmon, these positive impacts are due to indirect effects. " (9-10)
Benefit_6:
ESB: stream autotrophs, invertebrates
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " A concurrent study of many of the same streams that we used found spawning salmon biomass predicted primary productivity better than habitat characteristics, and that aquatic invertebrates used both nitrogen and carbon resources from spawning salmon (Harding and Reynolds 2014)." (10)
Benefit_7:
ESB: juvenile coho, juvenile Atlantic salmon
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, carcass addition positively affected juvenile coho salmon body condition (Bilby et al. 1998, Wipfli et al. 2010), juvenile coho salmon mass and body size (Wipfli et al. 2003), juvenile coho salmon growth (Lang et al. 2006, Giannico and Hinch 2007, Wipfli et al. 2010), and biomass of juvenile Atlantic salmon (Williams et al. 2009)." (11)
Benefit_8:
ESB: dolly varden
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Another study looking at naturally occurring spawning salmon found increased growth rate in dolly varden in seven ponds increasing in spawning salmon biomass (Denton et al. 2009). " (11)

Full_citation: Vélez-Espino, L., Ford, J., Araujo, H., Ellis, G., Parken, C., & Sharma, R. (2015). Relative importance of chinook salmon abundance on resident killer whale population growth and viability. Aquatic Conservation, 25(6), 756-780.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Relationship between chinook and Resident Killer Whale population dynamics as well as implications of harvest pressure or lack thereof on both.
Essential_notes: -Authors never spell out fishery details
Benefit_1:
ESB: PNW residents/conservationists
ESP: North Puget Sound and Fraser River chinook stocks
Sentence describing benefit: "In addition, the North Puget Sound spring-run and autumn-run chinook salmon stocks and several Fraser River spring-run and summer-run stocks have been identified as having medium to high conservation concern in the strategic plan of the Pacific Salmon Commission’s Southern Fund Committee.3" (757)
Benefit_2:
ESB: RKW survivorship
ESP: chinook
Sentence describing benefit: " The study of Ford et al. (2005) revealed that mortality indices were most highly correlated with changes in chinook abundance after a lag of 1 year. " (762)
Benefit_3:
ESB: SRKW
ESP: Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Seven significant (P < 0.05) and positive (slope > 0.0) relationships between chinook abundance and SRKW vital rates were identified after applying the Holm–Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons (Table 2)....Five of the seven interactions involved fecundity (two for young reproductive females and three for old reproductive females) and two involved the survival of old reproductive females." (765)
Benefit_4:
ESB: NRKW
ESP: Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Within the context of fishing scenarios under the strong hypotheses, the terminal run of Northern BC chinook showed the greatest potential to influence NRKW expected population growth" (775)
Benefit_5:
ESB: RKW
ESP: chum
Sentence describing benefit: " Recently, chum salmon (Oncorhynchus keta) have been recognized as an important component of the autumn diet (Ford et al., 2010a; Hanson et al., 2010)." (777)
Benefit_6:
ESB: RKW
ESP: chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "The predominance of chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha) in the summer diets of both killer whale populations has been shown by recent studies, and correlations between indices of chinook salmon abundance and resident killer whale (RKW) vital rates have generated hypotheses about the potential for chinook salmon abundance to limit RKW population dynamics." (756)

Full_citation: Collins, S., Baxter, C., Marcarelli, A., Wipfli, M., & Peters, D. (2016). Effects of experimentally added salmon subsidies on resident fishes via direct and indirect pathways. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 7(3), N/a.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of nutrient addition in the form of salmon carcasses or similar on stream-resident fish.
Location: North Fork of Boise River drainage, central Idaho, USA
Benefit_1:
ESB: resident trout
ESP: hatchery carcass
Sentence describing benefit: "Resident trout directly consumed 10.0–24.0 g·m−2·yr−1 of salmon carcass and <1–11.0 g·m−2·yr−1 of analog material, which resulted in 1.2–2.9 g·m−2·yr−1 and 0.03–1.4 g·m−2·yr−1 of tissue produced." (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: resident trout
ESP: hatchery carcasses 
Sentence describing benefit: ". Overall, treatments increased annual trout production by 2–3 fold, though density and biomass were unaffected." (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: terrestrial consumers, landscape
ESP: salmon via bears, for example
Sentence describing benefit: "In addition, carcasses are frequently removed (e.g., by bears) to adjacent riparian habitats, where a variety of organisms readily consume, convert, and transport the marine-derived energy and nutrients throughout the landscape (Hocking and Reimchen 2006, Quinn et al. 2009, Collins and Baxter 2014)." (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: stream fishes
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "As stream fishes also directly consume materials derived from salmon (Bilby et al. 1998, Scheuerell et al. 2007, Denton et al. 2009), this may improve their growth and condition (Wipfli et al. 2004, Guyette et al. 2013), but it is uncertain how long these may persist or if these changes influence the potential top-down effects of these fish. " (2-3)
Benefit_5:
ESB: chlorophyll/ stream autotrophs
ESP: hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "However, 2–6 fold increases in chlorophyll a biomass (Treatment × Time, F3,50 = 7.41, P = 0.0003) and AFDM (Treatment × Time, F3,50 = 3.68, P = 0.0179) were observed in the short term (2–6 weeks) following treatment additions. Short-term increases occurred in 2008–2010 for analog and 2008 and 2009 for carcass treatments (Fig. 2a, b). " (8)
Benefit_6:
ESB: benthic invertebrates
ESP: hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Overall, treatment additions increased total benthic invertebrate biomass (Treatment, F2,6 = 9.79, P = 0.012), with carcasses having the strongest effect (Carcass vs. control, F1,6 = 18.46, P = 0.005; Carcass vs. analog, F1,6 = 9.41, P = 0.022), but in general responses became dampened with each subsequent year of the experiment" (8)
Benefit_7:
ESB: resident trout
ESP: hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In contrast to the lack of response in terms of trout density or biomass, but consistent with the observed increases in growth, treatment additions caused 2–3 fold increases in estimates of annual trout production (Fig. 7a; Treatment, F2,6 = 12.23, P=0.007). Within control streams, trout production ranged from 3.1 to 4.2 g·m−2·y−1 over the duration of our experiment (Fig. 7a), whereas within analog and carcass-treated streams it ranged from 6 to 8 g·m−2·y−1 and 8 to 12.5 g·m−2·y−1, respectively" (9)
Benefit_8:
ESB: resident trout
ESP: hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The trophic basis of production of resident trout was influenced by salmon subsidies through direct consumption of the materials added, and via both aquatic and terrestrial pathways. Across treated streams, trout populations directly consumed 10–24 g·m−2·yr−1 of salmon carcass tissue and <1–11 g·m−2·yr−1 of analog material during the weeks it was available. This consumption accounted for an estimated 3–5% of the carcass material added and 4–11% of analog material added, and fueled 17% and 6% of trout annual production, respectively (Fig. 8)" (10)
Benefit_9:
ESB: trout and sculpin
ESP: aquatic invertebrates via hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The annual consumption of aquatic invertebrates by trout and sculpin was greatest in treatment streams, based on our estimates of the annual flows of aquatic invertebrate biomass required to fuel the fish production we observed (Treatment, F2,6 = 6.28, P = 0.033; Fig. 7)." (11)
Benefit_10:
ESB: stream *replace with flies*
ESP: terrestrial arthropods via salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Moreover, the removal of salmon carcasses from the stream and subsequent utilization by terrestrial organisms resulted in increased allochthonous inputs of terrestrial arthropods back into the stream." (12-13)
Benefit_11:
ESB: resident trout
ESP: hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Both carcass and analog material were readily consumed in the weeks when it was available to fishes. Trout consumed more carcass than analog material, and in turn, exhibited more production" (13)
Benefit_12:
ESB: sculpin and trout
ESP: hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Sculpin production increased through time in two of three streams treated with carcasses..... Nevertheless, our trophic basis calculations indicated that more trout production was attributable to the consumption of sculpin in streams treated with salmon carcasses relative to control streams. To our knowledge, this is the first evidence of increased piscivory through multiple pathways due to salmon-derived subsidies" (13)
Benefit_13:
ESB: resident trout
ESP: flies via carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Our results indicated that, on average, the allochthonous input of Diptera maggots accounted for 7% of annual trout production when salmon carcasses were present. This pathway did not occur in streams treated with analog because the pellets were not removed from the stream and therefore could not be colonized by flies" (14)
Benefit_14:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: ". Stream biofilms increased in the short-term following treatment additions during the first 2 years of the experiment, however, no carry-over effects were observed in the following summer (prior to the following annual treatment addition) for either treatment (for more detail regarding biofilm and stream nutrient chemistry responses, see Marcarelli et al. 2014)." (14)
Benefit_15:
ESB: benthic invertebrates
ESP: hatchery carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Standing crop biomass of benthic invertebrates doubled after the first year in streams treated with salmon carcasses and was highly variable among streams treated with analog" (14)
Benefit_16:
ESB: resident trout
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "However, estimates of annual production (i.e., accrual of biomass per year) of resident trout increased 125–282% and 78–161% in carcass and analog treatments, respectively, over the duration of the experiment. " (14)

Full_citation: Armstrong, J., Takimoto, G., Schindler, D., Hayes, M., & Kauffman, M. (2016). Resource waves: Phenological diversity enhances foraging opportunities for mobile consumers. Ecology (Durham), 97(5), 1099-1112.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Resource waves and relationship with phenological diversity in consumers.
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW and terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon...generate pulsed marine subsidies in freshwater and terrestrial ecosystems when they spawn in streams and along lake shores (Gende et al. 2002)." (1104)
Benefit_2:
ESB: inland consumers
ESP: spawning salmon, eggs, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Over 50 species of inland consumers prey on spawning salmon, consume salmon eggs, or scavenge carcasses" (1104)
Benefit_3:
ESB: mobile consumers
ESP: sockeye diversity
Sentence describing benefit: "Across a watershed, which may be comprised of dozens of hydrologically distinct spawning areas, the spawn-timings of populations are locally adapted to ambient thermal regimes and range from early summer to autumn (Lisi et al. 2013). This inter-population phenological diversity protracts the foraging opportunities of mobile consumers, enabling them to feed on salmon for three months or longer as they move across the landscape to sequentially exploit  individual salmon populations (Fig. 2b; Schindler et al. 2010, 2013)" (1104)
Benefit_4:
ESB: rainbow trout
ESP: salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Rainbow trout...which accumulate most of their seasonal growth by feeding on salmon eggs, moved within a stream network to track population-level variation in salmon phenology (Ruff et al. 2011)" (1104)
Benefit_5:
ESB: glaucous-winged gulls, grizzly bears
ESP: spawning sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "Glaucous-winged Gulls (Larus glaucescens) and grizzly bears also appear to track population-level variation in salmon spawn timing (Schindler et al. 2013). The spatial distributions of both consumers tracked the spawn timing of sockeye salmon populations across tributary streams of the Wood River watershed in coastal Alaska (Fig. 2b)" (1104)
Benefit_6:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Though commercial fisheries may harvest >50% of the many North American salmon runs, many consumer species are digestively constrained when feeding on salmon (Gende et al. 2002, Bentley et al. 2012, Armstrong et al. 2013)" (1109)

Sentence describing benefit:
