Full_citation: Harding, J., Harding, J., Field, R., Pendray, J., Swain, N., Wagner, M., & Reynolds, J. (2019). Landscape Structure and Species Interactions Drive the Distribution of Salmon Carcasses in Coastal Watersheds. Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution, 7, Frontiers in ecology and evolution, 2019-06-07, Vol.7.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Relationship between salmon abundance and distribution to terrestrial landscape by bears and wolves as well as other factors contributing to distribution (i.e. watershed characteristics).
Benefit_1:
ESB: coastal ecosystems
ESP: migrating adults
Sentence describing benefit: "Semelparous salmon rear in and then return to natal streams as adults to reproduce, thereby importing mass quantities of marine-derived material into coastal ecosystems throughout the North Pacific Rim" (2)
Benefit_2:
ESB: streams, estuaries, forests
ESP: carcasses via consumers and water movement
Sentence describing benefit: "After spawning, their nutrient-rich carcasses are dispersed along streams, estuaries, and into adjacent forests by consumers and the movement of water Cederholm et al., 1989; Payne and Moore, 2006; Quinn et al., 2009." (2)
Benefit_3:
ESB: bears
ESP: adult salmon/carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Bears exploit this predictable and accessible annual pulse of protein, which constitutes a crucial resource during their preparation for winter dormancy (Quinn et al., 2003; Hilderbrand et al., 2011)." (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: gray wolves
ESP: salmon adults/carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Gray wolves (Canis lupus) are another major consumer that depend on salmon and can transfer significant numbers of salmon carcasses to riparian areas (Darimont et al., 2003). Isotope evidence suggests that coastal wolves shift their diet from ungulates to salmon during fall spawning events (Darimont and Reimchen, 2002; Darimont et al., 2008). " (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: bears and wolves
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Bears consume multiple parts of a salmon including the brain, eggs and muscle tissue (Reimchen, 2000; Gende et al., 2004a), while wolves almost exclusively consume the brain in a surgical manner (Darimont et al., 2003)." (4)
Benefit_6:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Bear consumption of salmon increased in streams with larger spawning areas but stream depth and estuary meadow area had negligible or uncertain effects (Figure 7B). " (9)
Benefit_7:
ESB: estuaries
ESP: salmon carcasses via wolves and bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Overall, the total quantity of salmon carcasses transferred to riparian zones, by wolves and bears combined, was highest in estuaries and declined upstream. " (11)
Benefit_8:
ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:

Full_citation: Moody, E., Albright, E., Cope, K., Fleck, R., Grigel, H., Ortiz, D., & Wilkinson, G. (2019). Taxonomic and geographic gaps in understanding the functional effects of imperilled fishes on freshwater ecosystems. Fish and Fisheries (Oxford, England), 20(4), 795-801.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Quantifying functional effects of migrating freshwater fish - what species have been studied and how.
Benefit_1:
ESB: researchers
ESP: pink, rainbow trout, chum
Sentence describing benefit: " The five most frequently studied species were rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss, Salmonidae), brook trout (Salvelinus fontinalis, Salmonidae), pink salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha, Salmonidae), chum salmon (Oncorhynchus keta, Salmonidae) and gizzard shad (Dorosoma cepedianum, Clupeidae)" (797)
Benefit_2:
ESB: researchers
ESP: salmonids
Sentence describing benefit: "Most studies of the functional effects of imperilled fishes focused on salmonids (Benjamin, Bellmore, & Watson, 2016; Claeson, Li, Compton, & Bisson, 2006; LeRoy et al., 2016; Marcarelli, Baxter, & Wipfli, 2014; Samways & Cunjak, 2015), with this family being significantly overrepresented relative to their total number of species in North America (Figure 2). This focus is likely in part because the migratory patterns of salmonids from marine to freshwater ecosystems make them an ideal study system to investigate resource flows between environments using before–after comparisons (Levi et al., 2013)." (799)
Benefit_3:
ESB: researchers
ESP: stocked salmonids
Sentence describing benefit: "Further, salmonids that have been stocked to promote fisheries create a convenient system to investigate the effects of species additions on ecosystem function (Alexiades, Flecker, & Kraft, 2017)." (799)
Benefit_4:
ESB: recreational, commercial fisheries
ESP: salmonids
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmonids are relatively charismatic fishes which are sought in both recreational and commercial fisheries, which may be why they are so heavily studied relative to other imperilled species. " (799)

Full_citation: Phang, S., Cooperman, M., Lynch, A., Steel, E., Elliott, V., Murchie, K., . . . Cowx, I. (2019). Fishing for conservation of freshwater tropical fishes in the Anthropocene. Aquatic Conservation, 29(7), 1039-1051.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Freshwater biodiversity and managing for conservation as well as fisheries livelihoods.
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW + terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The river also supports Chinook (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha) and sockeye salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka) populations, and their anadromous migrations are vital to both freshwater and terrestrial ecosystems because of nutrient input from post‐spawning decomposition of their bodies (Gende, Edwards, Willson, & Wipfli, 2002)." (1046)
Benefit_2:
ESB: commercial and sport fisheries
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon also have important socioeconomic value to local communities and the state of Alaska by supporting commercial and sport fisheries worth over a billion US dollars annually (Schoen et al., 2017)" (1046)
Benefit_3:
ESB: subsistence fishers
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Alaskan salmon have a strong cultural value as an important food source for many subsistence fishers." (1046)
Benefit_4:
ESB: group members
ESP: Kenai Fish Habitat Partnership via salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The Kenai Fish Habitat Partnership was set up to address the threats of degrading aquatic habitat, declining fish populations and loss of fisher livelihood. The partnership consists of more than 30 organizations, and the large number reflects the complex and large spatial extent of environmental threats across the peninsula as well as the diversity of stakeholders, including government agencies, sportfishing groups and Alaska Native Tribes that depend on or are involved in the Kenai River." (1046)
Benefit_5:
ESB: future generations
ESP: salmon via Kenai Fish Habitat Partnership
Sentence describing benefit: "The stated vision of the partnership is ‘for future generations to have healthy, sustainable fish and aquatic ecosystems’, and they work to identify freshwater habitats for conservation, evaluate current condition, and rank threats from human action to specific habitats (Kenai Peninsula Fish Habitat Partnership Plan 2011)" (1046)

Full_citation: Armstrong, J., Schindler, D., Cunningham, C., Deacy, W., & Walsh, P. (2020). Watershed complexity increases the capacity for salmon–wildlife interactions in coastal ecosystems. Conservation Letters, 13(2), N/a.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Modelling effects of watershed development and commercial harvest on foraging opportunities for terrestrial predators (especially bears)
Benefit_1:
ESB: fisheries
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We found that, where salmon are abundant, fisheries can harvest large fractions of runs without substantially reducing bear consumption of salmon, but that watershed development could strongly reduce bear consumption if it shortens the duration of foraging opportunities by reducing population-level variation in salmon spawn timing" (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon in small streams
Sentence describing benefit: "Habitats with the lowest resource abundance (small streams) were particularly profitable for bear foraging because they offer salmon at unique times of the season." (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: aquatic and terrestrial consumers
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "After accumulating most of their body mass in the ocean, salmon return to their natal rivers to spawn and then die, generating a highquality resource pulse that supports a wide variety of aquatic and terrestrial consumers in coastal watersheds (Willson & Halupka, 1995)." (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: consumers
ESP: salmon and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Consumers ranging from insects to bears scavenge or prey on salmon and their eggs." (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: consumers
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "At higher latitudes where growing seasons are shorter (and winters longer), salmon provide a critical energy source for a wide variety of taxa (Armstrong & Bond, 2013; Bentley et al., 2012)" (2)
Benefit_6:
ESB: fisheries
ESP: marine salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Marine fisheries often harvest a large proportion of salmon returning to watersheds, leading to concerns that harvest reduces the resource base supporting terrestrial and freshwater food webs in salmon watersheds and that an ecosystem-based approach to salmon management would more explicitly consider the roles of salmon as a resource subsidy to watershed predators (Darimont et al., 2010; Levi et al., 2012)." (2)
Benefit_7:
ESB: fisheries and predators
ESP: salmon diversity
Sentence describing benefit: "A growing body of work demonstrates that intraspecific diversity in salmon attributes mediates energy flows to both fisheries and predators (Deacy, Leacock, Armstrong, & Stanford, 2016; Ruff et al., 2011; Schindler et al., 2013)." (2)
Benefit_8:
ESB: commercial fisheries, tourism, recreational fisheries
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " For example, the Bristol Bay region of western Alaska is famous for its prolific commercial salmon fisheries (Hilborn et al., 2003; Schindler et al., 2010), tourism focused on bear viewing (Richardson, Huber, & Loomis, 2017), and recreational fisheries for species that rely heavily on salmon resource subsidies (Bentley et al., 2012; Dye & Borden, 2018). " (2)
Benefit_9:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: ". In contrast, at our maximum escapement levels of 6 million fish, bears consumed nearly 1,200–2,500 salmon and showed little response to further increases in salmon abundance." (3)
Benefit_10:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon diversity
Sentence describing benefit: "Phenological variation had strong positive effects on bear foraging that were enhanced by salmon escapement, but dampened by competition (Figures 2 and S1)" (3)
Benefit_11:
ESB: bears
ESP: small salmon populations
Sentence describing benefit: "However, because stream populations exhibit unique phenologies and are more vulnerable to predation, they contributed disproportionately more to bear foraging,  providing 48% ± 17% (mean ± 1 standard deviation) of the total salmon consumed by bears over the course of a season. ... small populations of salmon contributed roughly half of total bear consumption while representing only one-fifth of total salmon escapement (Figure 3)." (5)
Benefit_12:
ESB: Kodiak brown bears
ESP: salmon diversity
Sentence describing benefit: "Kodiak brown bears that tracked phenological variation to prolong their salmon foraging exhibited nearly 40–90% higher consumption levels (Deacy et al., 2018)" (5)
Benefit_13:
ESB: black bears
ESP: salmon diversity
Sentence describing benefit: "Similarly, salmon species diversity (a proxy for phenological variation) outperformed salmon biomass in predicting the contribution of salmon to black bear diets in coastal British Columbia (Service et al., 2019)" (5)
Benefit_14:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon diversity
Sentence describing benefit: "Diversity in spawn timing determines how long salmon are present on the landscape, whereas salmon abundance primarily influences bear energy intake on the days when salmon are present." (6-7)

Full_citation: Nelson, B., Shelton, A., Anderson, J., Ford, M., & Ward, E. (2019). Ecological implications of changing hatchery practices for Chinook salmon in the Salish Sea. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 10(11), N/a.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Long term change in hatchery release characteristics (release size, timing, etc) over 65 years and comparison with naturally spawning Chinook population.
Location: Puget Sound, Strait of Juan de Fuca, Strait of Georgia
Benefit_1:
ESB: Fish, birds, marine mammals
ESP: juvenile salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Research suggests that predation on juvenile salmon by other fish, avian, and marine mammal species could be size-dependent, and our results indicate that current hatchery practices are releasing Chinook salmon in the size range preferred by these predators." (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: rsearchers
ESP: hatchery salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Some of the most studied hatchery fishes in the world are Pacific salmon raised and released by hatcheries into the northeast Pacific Ocean (USA, Canada)." (2)
Benefit_3:
ESB: marine and terrestrial predators, esp. killer whales and grizzly bears
ESP: marine and anadromous salmon (hatchery)
Sentence describing benefit: " Ecologically, salmon provide prey subsidies to marine and terrestrial predators, including grizzly bears and killer whales (Schindler et al. 2013). " (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: birds and marine mammals
ESP: juvenile hatchery salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Populations of avian (e.g., cormorants, Collis et al. 2001, and gulls, Osterback et al. 2013) and marine mammal predators (e.g., seals, Lance et al. 2012) are also supported by migrations of juvenile salmon from rivers to the ocean" (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: commercial, recreational, treaty fisheries
ESP: hatchery salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " As the primary target for both commercial, recreational, and treaty fisheries in southern British Columbia and the states of Washington, Oregon, and California, Chinook salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha) represent the majority of hatchery production in this region (Naish et al. 2007, Flagg 2015)." (2)
Benefit_6:
ESB: indigenous North Americans
ESP: Chinook salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Chinook salmon are also iconic species throughout their range, with profound cultural significance to indigenous North Americans." (2)
Benefit_7:
ESB: bird, fish, marine mammals
ESP: hatchery Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: " When compared to avian, fish, and marine mammal predator size preferences, hatchery Chinook in the Puget Sound overlap with the preferred prey size windows to a greater extent than Chinook of natural origin (Fig. 8)." (9)
Benefit_8:
ESB: harbor seals
ESP: hatchery coho
Sentence describing benefit: "A recent study near the most productive hatchery in the Strait of Georgia (Big Qualicum River) provides evidence for such size selectivity of salmonids by harbor seals in the Salish Sea (Allegue 2017). Seals tagged with GPS devices exhibited increased feeding behavior in the estuary shortly after releases of coho salmon (mean release size: 130 mm) but did not respond to far more abundant, smaller Chinook (release size: 80 mm) released only a few weeks later. " (14)
Benefit_9:
ESB: mergansers, spiny dogfish
ESP: hatchery salmonids
Sentence describing benefit: "Numerical responses by avian (mergansers, Mergus merganser) and piscivorous fish species (spiny dogfish, Squalus suckleyi) have been documented in the Salish Sea in response to high densities of hatchery salmonids (Wood 1987, Beamish et al. 1992)." (14)
Benefit_10:
ESB: southern resident killer whales
ESP: marine Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: " Maintaining diversity—and the stability it may confer—in the composite of Chinook stocks along the west coast of North America could be a critical factor for the recovery of southern resident killer whales, which depend heavily on Chinook salmon for prey (Ford et al. 2016)." (15)

Full_citation: Lincoln, A., Hilborn, R., Wirsing, A., & Quinn, T. (2020). Managing salmon for wildlife: Do fisheries limit salmon consumption by bears in small Alaskan streams? Ecological Applications, 30(3), E02061-N/a.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Relationship between sockeye salmon availability and their consumption by bears.
Location: Wood River watershed, southwestern AK, USA
Benefit_1:
ESB: fisheries and wildlife, esp brown bears
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Pacific salmon are an important resource for both fisheries and populations of wildlife around the Pacific rim, including coastal brown bears (Ursus arctos); salmon consumption has been positively linked to bear density, body size, and reproductive rate" (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Under modeled scenarios, bear consumption of salmon was predicted to increase only with dramatic (on the order of 50–100%) increases in prey availability." (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: southern resident killer whales, freshwater and terrestrial consumers
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " In the ocean, salmon dominate the diet of protected southern resident killer whales (Orcinus orca; Ford and Ellis 2006, Ford et al. 2010), and after returning from the ocean to reproduce in freshwater, salmon also provide food for freshwater and terrestrial consumers (e.g., fishes, bears, eagles; Schindler et al. 2003, Levi et al. 2015)." (1)
Benefit_4:
ESB: FW + terrestrial habitats
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon that avoid predation senesce and die after spawning, releasing nutrients to freshwater and terrestrial habitats (Cederholm et al. 1999, Gende et al. 2002, Naiman et al. 2002, Schindler et al. 2003)." (1-2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: brown bears, black bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Among terrestrial predators of salmon, brown (Ursus arctos) and black (U. americanus) bears rely heavily on salmon in coastal regions (Reimchen 2000, 2017, Hilderbrand et al. 2004), providing one example of fisheries–wildlife competition for salmon."
Benefit_6:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " The majority of annual bear diet can be composed of salmon (Hilderbrand et al. 1999a, b, Mowat and Heard 2006), and salmon consumption is positively correlated with body size and population productivity (Hilderbrand et al. 1999b)." (2)
Benefit_7:
ESB: fisheries
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Fisheries are managed so that the number of salmon reaching the spawning grounds is far below levels in the absence of harvest, resulting in longterm maximum sustainable yield (Ricker 1958). Great effort is devoted to determine the optimal levels of escapement for sustainable fisheries (i.e., number of salmon escaping fisheries to spawn), but it is unclear how to integrate ecosystem benefits into this calculation" (2)
Benefit_8:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Partial consumption reduces the benefits of increased escapement, as doubling the number of salmon would not double the biomass consumed, although it allows for the consumption of higher quality tissues (Gende et al. 2001, Lincoln and Quinn 2019)." (4-6)
Benefit_9:
ESB: bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In some years at Hansen Creek and the Pedro Bay ponds, bears were estimated to have consumed a biomass of salmon that was near (within 20%) the maximum biomass consumed, indicating that salmon were sufficiently available under current fishery management in those years." (6)

Full_citation: Collins, S., Baxter, C., Marcarelli, A., Felicetti, L., Florin, S., Wipfli, M., & Servheen, G. (2019). Reverberating effects of resource exchanges in stream–riparian food webs. Oecologia, 192(1), 179-189.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Subsidy dynamics (trophic transfer, creation of new subsidies based on input from old subsidy, etc) in a riparian system, from salmon carcasses or pellets.
Location: North Fork Boise River, Idaho, USA
Benefit_1:
ESB: stream fishes, carrion flies
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "We found that salmon carcasses altered stream-riparian food webs by directly subsidizing multiple aquatic and terrestrial organisms (e.g., benthic insect larvae, fishes, and terrestrial flies). Such responses further influenced food webs along indirect pathways, some of which spanned land and water (e.g., subsidized fishes reduced aquatic insect emergence, with consequences for spiders and bats). Subsidy-mediated feedbacks manifested when carcasses were removed to riparian habitats where they were colonized by carrion flies, some of which fell into the stream and acted as another prey subsidy for fishes." (np)
Benefit_2:
ESB: benthic insects
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: ". Standing stock biomass (mg dry mass m-2) of benthic insects was two times higher in the carcass treatment (treatment, F 2, 6 = 9.79, p = 0.01; carcass vs. control, F 1, 6 = 18.46, p = 0.005; Fig. 1a), whereas benthic insect responses to salmon-pellet addition were variable and did not differ from the carcass subsidy or control." (np)
Benefit_3:
ESB: carrion flies
ESP: carcasses via bears
Sentence describing benefit: ". In riparian habitats, translocated carcasses (presumably by black bears, Ursus amaricanus) increased the biomass of terrestrial carrion flies relative to controls (treatment, F 2, 6 = 5.28, p = 0.04; Fig. 1d)." (np)
Benefit_4:
ESB: stream fishes
ESP: carrion flies via carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "By increasing the relative biomass of terrestrial carrion flies, salmon subsidy additions enhanced reciprocal feedbacks from riparian to stream habitats, as evidenced by the consumption of greater quantities of terrestrial invertebrates by stream fishes (Fig. 1c)" (np)
Benefit_5:
ESB: bats
ESP: carrion flies via carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "For instance, riparian environments with a higher relative biomass of carrion flies had fewer Araneidae spiders (r (9) = - 0.77, p = 0.01; Fig. 3b, white circles) and higher activities of open-canopy foraging bats (r (9) = 0.75, p = 0.02; Fig. 3b, black circles)." (np)
Benefit_6:
ESB: carrion flies, stream resident fish
ESP: carcasses via bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Terrestrial scavengers, primarily black bears (S.F. Collins, personal observations), facilitated (or mediated) the transfer of salmon carcasses to the riparian zone (20-31 carcasses per 100 m, as estimated in 2010; Collins and Baxter 2014) which had important consequences for food-web responses that did not accompany the salmon-pellet treatment. The simple act of moving (i.e., as an output from the stream) carcasses to riparian areas increased carrion fly larvae and adults, many of which fell into streams and were consumed by fishes (Fig. 4c), and which contributed to enhanced fish growth rates (Collins et al. 2016). " (np)
Benefit_7:
ESB: carrion flies, bats
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Although salmon subsidies directly increased carrion flies, we detected a negative correlation with Araneidae spiders (generalist predators), such that more carrion flies corresponded with fewer Araneid spiders. Additionally, the activity of open-canopy foraging bats (e.g., comprised of Myotis thysanodes, M. evotis, M. ciliolabrum, Eptesicus fuscus; Ober and Hayes 2008) positively tracked the relative biomass of carrion flies. " (np)
Benefit_8:
ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:

Full_citation: Wyllie de Echeverria, V., & Thornton, T. (2019). Using traditional ecological knowledge to understand and adapt to climate and biodiversity change on the Pacific coast of North America. Ambio, 48(12), 1447-1469.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Indigenous perspective on environmental change and adaptation, especially as relates to cultural keystone species.
Location: northern coastal British Columbia and the panhandle of southeast Alaska; Cascadia bioregion
Benefit_1:
ESB: Haida, Tlingit, and Tsimshian 
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Although all three groups are ‘salmon cultures’, like many Northwest Coast groups, The Haida, Tlingit and Tsimshian represent distinct language groups with their own knowledge systems, social structures, and livelihood adaptations to the microclimates in which they dwell (cf. Langdon 1979)." (1451)
Benefit_2:
ESB: knowledge holders
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Overall, all five species of salmon are used to indicate environmental characteristics such as changes in human and natural disturbances in watersheds (e.g. landslides and logging), the condition of the watershed (debris, sediment), stream flow, temperature (both marine and stream), salinity, and ocean currents (Hyatt and Godbout 2000; Gilkeson et al. 2006; Bryant et al. 2008; MOE 2016)." (1456)
Benefit_3:
ESB: researchers
ESP: coho, sockeye, pink
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, coho is ideal for monitoring the effects of human and natural disturbance on watersheds due to its longer life history in fresh water (Bryant et al. 2008), sockeye prefer colder water, so are ideal for monitoring temperature changes (MOE 2016), and pink salmon are known for their steady population fluctuations, and thus significant changes in population can be tracked easily (Estes 2014)." (1458)
Benefit_4:
ESB: researchers
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon... are wide-ranging in their distribution, and occur in both marine and freshwater systems; they contain variety with regard to genetics and life histories both within and between species; they are extremely sensitive to environmental cues; there are many longterm studies of salmon populations; and finally, they are extremely relevant both socially and economically to both Indigenous and non-Indigenous people in this area" (1458)
Benefit_5:
ESB: animals, humans
ESP: eggs through carcass (all life stages)
Sentence describing benefit: " Pacific salmon are considered to be an EKS because they are a very important food source for a host of other animals, ranging from large predators, such as bears and wolves, birds (including eagles), predatory fish, aquatic and riparian scavengers, and insects (Willson and Halupka 1995; Cederholm et al. 2000; Hyatt and Godbout 2000; Reimchen et al. 2003), in addition to humans. They are preyed upon at every stage of their life history, from eggs to carcasses (Willson and Halupka 1995)." (1458)
Benefit_6:
ESB: plants, soil
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " In addition to being eaten, their carcasses are often moved into terrestrial environments and broken down by detritivores to provide nutrients to the plants and enrich the soil, which provides a pathway for nutrients to connect the ocean and forest (Cederholm et al. 1999; Reimchen et al. 2003; Hocking and Reynolds 2012)." (1458)
Benefit_7:
ESB: FW ecosystems
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "The nutrient input of salmon into the coastal environment has influenced the structure and function in this ecosystem, and the yearly contribution affects entire ecosystem survival and reproductive capacity (Willson and Halupka 1995; Cederholm et al. 1999)." (1458)
Benefit_8:
ESB: co-managers
ESP: sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Another example of co-management that emerged in the interviews was that of sockeye salmon by the Alaskan government and the Hydaburg Cooperative Association, described by Native leader Anthony Christianson (Hydaburg, see quote in Table 4). Through the community’s TEK of salmon, they were able to identify the specific timings of different runs and collaborate to fine tune regulations to both enhance the monitoring and protection of fifish stocks and ensure that local people are still able to harvest salmon under optimal conditions (Cartwright et al.2005; Conitz et al. 2007). A" (1463-4)

Full_citation: Kaylor, M., White, S., Sedell, E., Sanders, A., & Warren, D. (2020). Carcass Additions Influence Food Webs Through Bottom-Up and Direct Consumption Pathways Along a Fish Species Assemblage Gradient. Ecosystems (New York), 24(1), 168-184.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of carcass additions on stream-resident fish
Location: Upper Grande Ronde River, tributary to Snake River, Oregon
Benefit_1:
ESB: juvenile chinook, steelhead
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " In contrast, across the three study pairs, juvenile Chinook Salmon (Oncorhynchus tshawytscha) and steelhead trout (O. mykiss) assimilated MDN rapidly, obtaining up to 25% and 57% of their nitrogen from carcasses, respectively. Diet analysis and isotopic enrichment patterns indicated that juvenile salmonid assimilation occurred primarily through direct consumption of eggs and carcass tissue." (168)
Benefit_2:
ESB: juvenile salmonids
ESP: salmon eggs
Sentence describing benefit: " Given observations of egg consumption by juvenile salmonids in response to natural salmon spawning (Armstrong and others 2010; Bentley and others 2012) and the addition of salmon carcasses (Bilby and others 1996, 1998), we expected juvenile salmonids to directly ingest eggs." (170)
Benefit_3:
ESB: bald eagles
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Trail camera footage revealed that bald eagles (Haliaeetus leucocephalus) were the dominant terrestrial scavenger, but most consumption occurred in the stream, likely releasing carcass material to the water." (175)
Benefit_4:
ESB: black bears
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " In the upstream pair, scavenging by black bears (Ursus americanus) resulted in a rapid loss of carcasses from the reach" (175)
Benefit_5:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Overall these results suggest nutrients released from carcasses resulted in a short-term increase in biofilm Chl a and AFDM in the middle and downstream pairs, but these effects did not persist 8 weeks after carcass additions." (176)
Benefit_6:
ESB: macroinvertebrates
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Enrichment patterns of scrapers, shredders, and predators mirrored those of periphyton and suggest assimilation of MDN assimilation occurred through bottom-up pathways." (180)
Benefit_7:
ESB: crayfish
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Crayfish consistently exhibited MDN assimilation in response to carcass additions at all three pairs" (180)
Benefit_8:
ESB: non-salmonid stream-resident fish
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Although non-salmonids rarely consumed eggs and carcass tissue, limited enrichment of non-salmonids did occur in the middle and downstream pairs (up to 11% of N was MDN derived)." (181)
Benefit_9:
ESB: chinook and steelhead
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmonid enrichment was far greater than enrichment of non-salmonids (up to 25% and 57% of fish N was MDN derived for Chinook and steelhead, respectively). This degree of MDN assimilation, coupled with the abundance of eggs and carcass material observed in diets, is clear evidence that direct consumption was the dominant pathway of MDN assimilation" (181)
Benefit_10:
ESB: salmonids
ESP: carcass and eggs
Sentence describing benefit: ". Salmonids in these study reaches also exhibited greater energy intake, growth rates, and body condition (Kaylor and others 2020), indicating that consumption of eggs and carcass material led to biological responses beyond assimilating MDN. " (181)
Benefit_11:
ESB: non-salmonid resident, invertebrates
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Our results indicate that the addition of carcasses resulted in limited MDN enrichment of invertebrates and non-salmonids and that this assimilation primarily occurred through bottom-up pathways." (182)
Benefit_12:
ESB: juvenile chinook and steelhead
ESP: eggs and carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In contrast to non-salmonids, juvenile Chinook Salmon and steelhead consumed an abundance of eggs and carcass tissue and exhibited far greater enrichment." (182)

Full_citation: D'Amore, D., Chaloner, D., Gerig, B., Berkowitz, J., & Bridgham, S. (2020). The nutrient legacy left by salmon tissue on riparian soils in Southeast Alaska. Soil Science Society of America Journal, 84(3), 877-887.
Journal: Soil Science Society of America Journal
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Tracking salmon MDN trends in soil over 1 year.
Location: Prince of Wales Island, southeast AK, USA
Benefit_1:
ESB: terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon-derived nutrients (SDN) are a distinctive aquatic subsidy to terrestrial ecosystems. Streamwater nutrient increases in response to SDN have been documented but uncertainties about the magnitude and persistence of their effects in riparian areas remain." (877)
Benefit_2:
ESB: stream organisms
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Multiple studies have shown that aquatic organisms use the energy and nutrients (especially N and P) associated with salmon runs, as reflected in increased stream productivity and biomass (Levi, Tank, Tiegs, Chaloner, & Lamberti, 2013; Ruegg et al., 2012) and altered stable isotope composition (Reisinger, Chaloner, Ruegg, Tiegs, & Lamberti, 2013)." (877)
Benefit_3:
ESB: soil
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " The salmon amendment resulted in an average 99% increase in NH4 +–N concentrations (F(1, 67) = 666.5; P < .001)." (880)
Benefit_4:
ESB: soil
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The salmon amendment resulted in an average increase of 56% in NO3−–N concentrations (F(1, 67) = 48.5; P < .001)." (880)
Benefit_5:
ESB: soil
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The salmon amendment resulted in an average increase of 76% in PO4 − concentrations (Figure 2; F(1, 67) = 93.5; P < .001)." (880)
Benefit_6:
ESB: soil 
ESP:carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Resin beads revealed the mobility of NH4 +–N and NO3 −– N within Tonowek and Tuxekan soils. The concentration of NH4+–N in resin beads was significantly increased by salmon amendment (F(1, 41) = 72.9; P < .001). " (882)
Benefit_7:
ESB: soil
ESP: carcass
Sentence describing benefit: "The concentration of NH4 +–N was 97% higher in salmonamended soils than in nonamended soils" (882)
Benefit_8:
ESB: soils, plants
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In our study, Tonowek and Tuxekan soils clearly retained a large quantity of plant-available NH4 +–N after the initial dose of salmon tissue. In addition, the NH4 +–N permeated the soil rooting zone (∼25 cm), further enhancing the ability of plants to access the labile nutrient pool." (883)
Benefit_9:
ESB: soils
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Perhaps more important to the nutrient subsidy is the addition of SRP via SDN." (883-4)
Benefit_10:
ESB: soils, microbes, plants
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "The capacity of the soils to retain inorganic N and P as NH4 +–N and SRP during the observation period confirms that SDN remains available in the soil matrix for riparian microbial and plant consumption beyond the salmon spawning period." (884)

Full_citation: Currier, C., Chaloner, D., Rüegg, J., Tiegs, S., D’Amore, D., & Lamberti, G. (2020). Beyond nitrogen and phosphorus subsidies: Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) as potential vectors of micronutrients. Aquatic Sciences, 82(3), Aquatic sciences, 2020-04-29, Vol.82 (3).
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Testing for transport of micronutrients by spawning salmon to freshwater systems.
Location: Prince of Wales Island, southeast AK, USA
Benefit_1:
ESB: streams
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Arrival of salmon increased stream water loads for Ca, Fe, Mg, and Na and the concentration of Co in bioflm across the seven study streams" (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: salmon run
Sentence describing benefit: "By examining one stream at fner temporal resolution, bioflm increased in Ca, Fe, and Mn concentrations near the end of the salmon run, indicating possible lag efects between peak salmon densities and bioflm micronutrient uptake" (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: streams and stream communities
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Studies have shown that salmon spawners increase the abundance, biomass, or primary production in streams via macronutrient provision (Schindler et al. 2005; Janetski et al. 2009; Rüegg et al. 2012)" (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: stream
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "s. In stream water, micronutrient loads for Ca, Fe, Mg, and Na signifcantly increased in the presence of salmon while B decreased (Fig. 2B), indicated by signifcant fxed efect estimates for the diference between micronutrient loads for these elements during compared to before the salmon run (Fig. 2D, Table 2). " (4)
Benefit_5:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "In bioflm, concentrations of Co signifcantly increased in the presence of salmon while concentrations of Cu and Na signifcantly decreased (Fig. 2C), as indicated by the signifcant fxed efects estimates for the diference between concentrations during compared to before the salmon run (Fig. 2E, Table 2)." (4)
Benefit_6:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Finally, some changes in micronutrient composition of bioflm were captured through time. Concentrations of Fe and Mn showed signifcant increases in concentration over the duration of the salmon run (p=0.049 for Fe, p=0.0086 for Mn; Fig. 5)." (5)
Benefit_7:
ESB: streams
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Importantly, we were able to determine that stream water element loads for Ca, Fe, Mg, and Na, elements essential for growth, signifcantly increased due to the presence of salmon spawners, which indicates an increase in nutrient availability for potential uptake by stream bioflm or other biota." (5-6)

ESB:
ESP:

Full_citation: Rüegg, J., Chaloner, D., Ballantyne, F., Levi, P., Song, C., Tank, J., . . . Lamberti, G. (2020). Understanding the Relative Roles of Salmon Spawner Enrichment and Disturbance: A High-Frequency, Multi-Habitat Field and Modeling Approach. Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution, 8, Frontiers in ecology and evolution, 2020-02-07, Vol.8.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Biofilm and stream metrics related to spawning runs over 3 habitat types.
Location: Twelve Mile Creek, Prince of Wales Island, SE AK, USA
Essential_notes: -Main takeaway: "the overall integrated salmon effect over the run was one of biofilm loss" (1)
Benefit_1:
ESB: FW ecosystems
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: " During their spawning runs, Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) deliver nutrients to freshwater ecosystems, but also disturb benthic sediments during upstream migration and nest building" (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Biofilm stable isotope composition indicated incorporation of salmon-derived carbon and nitrogen (N) during the latter part of the run" (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: stream ecosystems
ESP: spawners, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Salmon provide nutrients through excretion and decomposition of their carcasses, but they also disturb the benthos by scouring substrates during redd construction." (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: benthic biofilm
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The net ecological effect of salmon on benthic biofilms is one of nutrient enrichment, that may enhance biofilm productivity, and its offset by benthic disturbance" (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: streams
ESP: spawners, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Nutrient concentrations increased concomitantly with salmon presence. Soluble reactive phosphorous (SRP) concentrations increased from fairly constant levels prior to and during the initial stages of the run (∼5 µg L−1) to much higher levels as carcasses became very abundant (up to 28 µg L−1; Figure 1B)." (5)
Benefit_6:
ESB: streams
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Nitrate concentrations also increased in the presence of salmon, but more slowly than ammonium concentrations and peaked at 250 µg L−1 in mid-September (Figure 1D)." (5)
Benefit_7:
ESB: streams
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Ammonium concentrations increased from fairly constant and low levels of ∼2 µg L−1 prior to salmon arrival to over 20 µg L −1 within 2 weeks of the arrival of live salmon spawners (Figure 1C)." (5)
Benefit_8:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: early spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Biofilm production, biomass, and nitrogen isotopes increased early in the run. Biofilm exhibited rapid δ 15N enrichment (within a few days) similar to the isotopic signature of salmon material (cf. Chaloner et al., 2002), likely reflecting uptake of salmon-derived nitrogen by otherwise nutrient-limited biofilms (Rüegg et al., 2011)" (9-10)

Full_citation: Benbow, M., Receveur, J., & Lamberti, G. (2020). Death and Decomposition in Aquatic Ecosystems. Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution, 8, Frontiers in ecology and evolution, 2020-02-07, Vol.8.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of carrion subsidies on aquatic systems.
Benefit_1:
ESB: mink, brown bears
ESP: adult salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Predators, such as mink (Mustela vison) or brown bears (Ursus arctos), alter their behavior and timing of reproduction to coincide with the availability of salmon runs (Ben-David, 1997). These scavengers use salmon as a major nutritional source, in some locations obtaining >90% of their carbon and nitrogen from these fish (Willson and Halupka, 1995; Hilderbrand et al.1996, 1999)." (6)
Benefit_2:
ESB: eukaryotes
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: ". In addition to direct consumption by eukaryotes, carcasses in aquatic systems can have strong interactions with microbial communities (Wipfli et al., 1998; Pechal and Benbow, 2016; Pechal et al., 2019)." (6)
Benefit_3:
ESB: microbes and autotrophs
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Although the impact of decomposing carcasses is highly dependent on biotic and abiotic factors (e.g., stream physical structure, riparian conditions, organisms present, etc.) the input of nutrients from carcasses stimulates microbial activity and primary production (Mitchell and Lamberti, 2005), leading to additional effects on higher trophic levels (Wipfli et al., 1998; Cederholm et al., 1999; Gende et al., 2002)." (6)
Benefit_4:
ESB: autotrophs, invertebrates
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Isotopic studies have shown that salmon-derived carbon and nitrogen is incorporated into both primary producers and invertebrate feeding groups that consume microbes (e.g., filterers and grazers) (Bilby et al., 1996; Johnston et al., 1997; Guyette et al., 2014). " (6)
Benefit_5:
ESB: researchers
ESP: salmon phenology
Sentence describing benefit: "While salmon remains the best studied example of phenology-based mortality (Schindler et al., 2003), they are by no means the only group of aquatic animals with programed mortality that leads to cascading effects in aquatic ecosystems." (6)

Full_citation: Schmidt, J., Putera, J., & Wilson, T. (2019). Direct and indirect effects of temperature and prey abundance on bald eagle reproductive dynamics. Oecologia, 192(2), 391-401.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of salmon availability and weather events on bald eagle brood status
Location: Copper River drainage, south-central AK, USA
Benefit_1:
ESB: bald eagles
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "As expected, nest success was also positively related to salmon abundance; however, the negative effect of spring warmth suggested that access to salmon resources is indirectly diminished in warm springs as a consequence of increased glacial melt." (np)
Benefit_2:
ESB: consumers, terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In coastally connected systems in the north, salmon often represent a large potential prey resource for a variety of consumers (Buehler 2000; Gende et al. 2004; Hilderbrand et al. 2004) and transport large quantities of marine-derived nutrients into terrestrial ecosystems (Helfield and Naiman 2006)." (np)
Benefit_3:
ESB: bald eagle nests
ESP: salmon runs
Sentence describing benefit: "In addition, the probability that an occupied nest was successful within a given year was lower in warmer springs and higher in years with strong early salmon runs (Table 2, Fig. 2a), consistent with our predictions." (np)
Benefit_4:
ESB: waterfowl, invertebrates
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " Salmon are known to provide a nutrient subsidy in freshwater and terrestrial environments that can affect ecosystem productivity (Gende et al. 2002; Naiman et al. 2002; Schindler et al. 2003), and salmon carcasses serve as food resources for both adults and juvenile waterfowl (Gleason 2007) and are associated with higher invertebrate densities (Wipfli et al. 1998; Verspoor et al. 2011)." (np)

Full_citation: Brown, C., Parker, B., Hocking, M., & Reynolds, J. (2020). Salmon abundance and patterns of forest greenness as measured by satellite imagery. The Science of the Total Environment, 725, 138448.
Journal: The Science of the Total Environment
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors use satellite imaging to quantify the effect of salmon runs on greenness of riparian vegetation and comparison between vegetation types.
Location: lower Fraser River Valley, BC, Canada; central coast, BC, Canada
Benefit_1:
ESB: deciduous trees
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: ". In the first case study, we find that deciduous trees are greener in years following large salmon spawning events, and that the magnitude of this effect was related to the specific abundance of spawning salmon. " (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: trees
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We found greenness was related positively to salmon spawning density near streams with high evergreen cover and flat stream banks" (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: FW + terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: ". For instance, rivers can deliver terrestrial nutrients to coastal oceans where they enhance fish production (Connolly et al., 2009), seabird guano can reshape island food-webs (Polis and Hurd, 1996), and carcasses from spawning salmon deliver marine nutrients to freshwater and terrestrial ecosystems (Lyle and Elliott, 1998; Helfield and Naiman, 2001; Drake et al., 2006; Field and Reynolds, 2011; Hocking and Reynolds, 2011). " (1-2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: vegetation
ESP: salmon carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon fertilization also has an impact on vegetation at multiple scales, including significant local scale fertilization by individual carcasses (Hocking and Reynolds, 2012) and regional effects that are detectable in natural gradients of salmon density across watersheds (Hocking and Reynolds, 2011)" (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: riparian forests
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Fertilization of riparian forests by salmon is also of interest to ecosystem managers, because salmon fisheries operating in the ocean may interrupt this natural linkage and impact riparian ecosystems (Darimont et al., 2010; Levi et al., 2012)" (2)
Benefit_6:
ESB: trees
ESP: spawning pinks
Sentence describing benefit: "We found strong evidence for an effect of pink spawning years on greenness of trees as measured by Landsat satellite imagery in the Lower Fraser River valley (Table 1, Fig. 2). " (5)
Benefit_7:
ESB: riparian vegetation
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: ". For the lower Fraser River site, we found a temporal effect of salmon spawning on riparian vegetation such that greenness was greater in years following the major salmon spawning run." (6)
Benefit_8:
ESB: trees
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " For the central coast site, we found support for a spatial effect of salmon spawning density, where streams with less alder cover, shallow streambank slopes and higher salmon returns had higher greenness. " (6)

Full_citation: Collins, S., & Baxter, C. (2020). Multiple lines of evidence reveal complex rainbow trout responses to stream habitat enhancements. Freshwater Biology, 65(11), 1962-1972.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Response of rainbow trout to annual carcass supplementation, within a management context.
Location: North Fork Boise River drainage, central Idaho, USA
Benefit_1:
ESB: rainbow trout
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "All told, additions of salmon carcasses alleviated apparent food limitation and thereby increased secondary production of rainbow trout." (1962)
Benefit_2:
ESB: rainbow trout
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "We found multiple lines of evidence that indicated that annual additions of salmon carcasses aggregated rainbow trout and enhanced their annual production" (1963)
Benefit_3:
ESB: rainbow trout
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Rainbow trout consumed more food resources in treatment streams relative to controls in the weeks following salmon carcass additions (Table 1; Figure 1e). The mass of individual rainbow trout gut contents was 58–68% higher in treated streams relative to controls in the 2–4 weeks following carcass additions. Consequently, daily growth rates during these periods were 4–6 times greater than controls (Table 1; Figure 1f)." (1966)
Benefit_4:
ESB: rainbow trout
ESP: carcasses, aquatic invertebrates and terrestrial flies
Sentence describing benefit: "Multiple lines of evidence indicated that annual additions of salmon carcasses enhanced the annual production of rainbow trout. As trout immigrated to enhanced stream reaches, we observed that they ate 58–68% more and exhibited short-term increases (4–6×) in growth, results that other analyses (Collins et al., 2016, 2020) have revealed were due to direct foraging on carcass material, as well as increased consumption of aquatic invertebrates and terrestrial flies (the latter owing to colonisation of carcasses translocated to riparian zones)." (1967)
Benefit_5:
ESB: rainbow trout
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Thus, in response to treatment with salmon carcasses, we found increased secondary production occurred because fish grew faster (i.e. alleviated resource limitation), not because more fish were recruited into the local population (Collins et al., 2016)." (1967)
Benefit_6:
ESB: rainbow trout
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Movements into enhanced reaches were beneficial for individual trout, as we showed that they consumed more food (e.g. salmon carcass material, terrestrial and aquatic insects) and grew faster, which ultimately resulted in greater annual trout production (see also Collins et al., 2020; Collins et al., 2016)" (1968)

ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:
Benefit_8:
ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:

Full_citation: Adams, Megan S., Connors, Brendan, Levi, Taal, Shaw, Danielle, Walkus, Jennifer, Rogers, Scott, . . . Adams, Megan S. (2021). Local Values and Data Empower Culturally Guided Ecosystem‐Based Fisheries Management of the Wuikinuxv Bear–Salmon–Human System. Marine and Coastal Fisheries : Dynamics, Management, and Ecosystem Science., 13(4), 362-378.
Journal: Marine and Coastal Fisheries: Dynamics, Management, and Ecosystem Science
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Modelling tradeoffs between salmon harvest and benefits to bears, with bears functioning as a proxy for salmon ecosystems.
Essential_notes: -Authors emphasize need to incorporate local and Indigenous perspectives into management.
Benefit_1:
ESB: People, grizzly bears
ESP: Sockeye salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Grizzly bears Ursus arctos horribilis hold particular importance for the Wuikinuxv First Nation in Rivers Inlet, British Columbia, where people and bears have coexisted as consumers of Sockeye Salmon Oncorhynchus nerka for millennia." (362)
Benefit_2:
ESB: Indigenous people in the PNW
ESP: Salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Indigenous people in the Pacific Northwest harvest salmon for food, social, and ceremonial (FSC) purposes as participants in complex, salmon-driven socioecological systems (Brown and Brown 2009; Campbell and Butler 2010; Housty et al. 2014)." (363)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Plants and animals
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Common to Indigenous stories, songs, and dances from the region is respect for the plants and animals that also depend on salmon (Turner et al. 2013; Thornton et al. 2015; Artelle et al. 2018)." (363)
Benefit_4:
ESB: settler and indigenous economies
ESP: commercial fisheries
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon have also supported commercial fisheries that are vital to settler and Indigenous economies of the Pacific Northwest." (363)
Benefit_5:
ESB: Indigenous governments
ESP: Wild Salmon Policy and Fisheries Act
Sentence describing benefit: "Whereas federal agencies responsible for the management of salmon and other species are increasingly overextended (Marshall et al. 2017; Price et al. 2017), the potential for locally driven monitoring and governance of salmon by Indigenous governments—in this case supported by federal implementation of the Wild Salmon Policy (DFO 2005) and the Fisheries Act (2019)—creates a promising opportunity for management that can incorporate local values, governance, and ecosystem-based approaches (Atlas et al. 2021)." (364)
Benefit_6:
ESB: Grizzly bears
ESP: Spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Like local Indigenous harvesters, bears are terminal predators that consume salmon in their final spawning life history phase." (364)
Benefit_7:
ESB: Ocean-based consumers
ESP: Marine salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Sufficient spawner abundances for bear populations may indicate adequate abundance for ocean-based consumers, such as seabirds, pinnipeds, and sharks, which access salmon before the fish become available to bears (Levi et al. 2012)." (364)
Benefit_8:
ESB: surrounding ecosystems
ESP: grizzly bears + salmon carcass
Sentence describing benefit: "Bears are a main vector of marine-derived nutrients from salmon carcasses into surrounding ecosystems (Hilderbrand et al. 1999; Quinn et al. 2009) that benefit many other species (Schindler et al. 2003; Hocking and Reimchen 2009; Hocking and Reynolds 2011; Wagner and Reynolds 2019). " (364)
Benefit_9:
ESB: bear population density and surrounding ecosystems
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: " Salmon-subsidized populations of bears are denser (Hilderbrand et al. 1999) and have a greater influence on their surrounding ecosystems (Harrer and Levi 2018; Shakeri et al. 2018)." (364)
Benefit_10:
ESB: ecotourism economy
ESP: bears
Sentence describing benefit: "Grizzly bears also contribute to a growing coastal ecotourism economy for communities transitioning away from extractive industries (Clark et al. 2021)." (364)
Benefit_11:
ESB: people and bears
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "In the region of Wuikinuxv Territory (Owikeno or Rivers Inlet, British Columbia; Figure 1), people have harvested Pacific salmon alongside bears Ursus spp. for millennia." (364)
Benefit_12:
ESB: commercial fishery
ESP: River inlet sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: "Rivers Inlet Sockeye Salmon O. nerka were historically abundant, with upwards of 3 million fish returning to the system each year (Groot and Margolis 1991; Cox-Rogers and Sturhahn 2005), thus supporting one of the largest commercial fisheries in British Columbia (Walters et al. 1993; McKinnell et al. 2001)." (364)
Benefit_13:
ESB: Wuikinuxv Nation
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Since the closure of the commercial fishery, the Wuikinuxv Nation has worked with federal managers to develop in-season monitoring that can inform FSC harvest efforts (e.g., CPUE, sonar observations of spawners), allowing the Nation to adjust fishing effort accordingly to ensure that bears and other wildlife have allocation of salmon." (365)
Benefit_14:
ESB: Wuikinuxv people and families
ESP: FSC fishery
Sentence describing benefit: "The FSC fishery provides Sockeye Salmon for Wuikinuxv people and their families from on and off the reserve and from neighboring communities." (366)
Benefit_15:
ESB: grizzly bear density
ESP: salmon abundance
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon are of particular importance to density patterns in grizzly bear populations, and our work here corroborates other patterns of salmon consumption in grizzly bear populations as reported by Hilderbrand et al. (1999; Figure S2), which underlies our assumption in this linear relationship" (373)
Benefit_16:
ESB: local food sovereignty and ecological wellbeing
ESP: EBFM
Sentence describing benefit: "The opportunity for and apparent benefits of values-driven EBFM are illustrated in the Wuikinuxv Sockeye Salmon system. Here, values of local food sovereignty and respect for ecological well-being support a balance among cultural, economic, and ecological goals (Marshall et al. 2017)." (374)
Benefit_17:
ESB: Wuikinixv fisheries
ESP: sockeye stock
Sentence describing benefit: "Put plainly, our analysis indicates that the needs of local Wuikinuxv FSC fishers and the surrounding ecosystem are likely to be supported by the Sockeye Salmon stock, while there simply may not be enough to support commercial interests." (374)
Benefit_18:
ESB: decision-making
ESP: research
Sentence describing benefit: "Locally driven and executed research, including the data on bears and salmon from which we draw, can continue to support place-based and localized decision making (e.g., Adams et al. 2014; Service et al. 2014, 2018)." (374)

Full_citation: Benjamin, J., Bellmore, J., Whitney, E., & Dunham, J. (2020). Can nutrient additions facilitate recovery of Pacific salmon? Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences, 77(10), 1601-1611.
Journal: Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Will carcass supplementation improve long term conditions for salmon populations?
Essential_notes: -Main takeaway: "Overall, results of this work suggest that benefits during carcass and nutrient additions may not translate into persistent productivity of salmon unless additions are sustained indefinitely or other limiting factors are addressed." (1601)
Benefit_1:
ESB: periphyton, macroinvertebrates, fish
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Model results confirmed immediate increases in the biomass of periphyton, macroinvertebrates, and fish during carcass additions." (1601)
Benefit_2:
ESB: juvenile salmon
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "In turn, juvenile salmon grew larger and experienced improved freshwater and smolt survival, which translated to a greater number of adults returning to spawn." (1601)
Benefit_3:
ESB: FW foodwebs
ESP: salmon MDN, eggs, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Upon returning to natal streams to spawn, they contribute these marine-derived nutrients to local food webs in the form of inorganic nutrients, salmon eggs, and their own carcasses" (1601)
Benefit_4:
ESB: juvenile salmon
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "When carcasses were added to the model, the mass of an individual smolt, as well as the densities of salmon smolts and adults increased (Fig. 2). Compared with baseline, the mass of a smolt increased from 19% to 84% with additions of 0.1–2.0 carcasses·m−2 (0.5–10 kg·m−2). Similar results were simulated for smolt and adult densities with increases up to 49% and 173%, respectively" (1605)
Benefit_5:
ESB: adult salmon
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Adult densities in most (69%–82%) of the 2000 simulations had a positive response to carcass additions (Table 2)." (1605)
Benefit_6:
ESB: juvenile Chinook, other resident fish, invertebrates
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "With the addition of salmon carcasses, the annual biomass (g AFDM·m−2·year−1) of stocks increased, and diets shifted to take advantage of the additional carcass material (Fig. 3). The average annual biomass of juvenile Chinook salmon increased up to 81%, at 2.0 carcasses·m−2 (10 kg·m−2), as did the annual biomass of nontarget fishes (up to 221% increase) and aquatic invertebrates (up to 570%), owing to a substantial increase in the direct consumption of carcass material (up to 32% of diet for juvenile salmon; 48% for nontarget fishes; 66% for aquatic invertebrates)." (1606)
Benefit_7:
ESB: juvenile and adult salmon
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "During carcass additions, the density of smolts and returning adults increased in our model simulations and began to level at a density of 2.0 carcasses·m−2 (10 kg·m−2)....This is consistent with mesocosm experiments that found up to 60% increase in juvenile salmon mass with carcass additions that leveled off after 1.0 carcass·m−2 (5 kg·m−2; Wipfli et al. 2003; but see Kiffney et al. 2018)" (1607)
Benefit_8:
ESB:
ESP:
Sentence describing benefit:

Full_citation: Siemens, L., Dennert, A., Obrist, D., & Reynolds, J. (2020). Spawning salmon density influences fruit production of salmonberry (Rubus spectabilis). Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 11(11), N/a.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of salmon subsidy on salmonberry reproduction (fruits per shrub, seeds per fruit, weight, sugar content).
Location: Heiltsuk territory, central coast of BC near Bella Bella
Benefit_1:
ESB: salmonberry
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We found that the number of fruits per salmonberry shrub increased with increasing salmon density" (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: salmonberry
ESP: chum spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "The effect of salmon density was species-dependent; the number of fruits per shrub increased with chum salmon density but was not affected by pink salmon density." (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: coastal FW and riparian ecosystems
ESP: anadromous salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The anadromous life history of Pacific salmon allows them to provide a significant subsidy to coastal freshwater and riparian ecosystems." (1)
Benefit_4:
ESB: riparian ecosystems
ESP: carcasses and eggs via predators, scavengers, and water flow
Sentence describing benefit: "Nutrients typically flow from freshwater systems towards the ocean; however, salmon reverse this process by creating a nutrient flux upstream during spawning migrations. During this process, salmon carcasses and eggs are transferred from streams to riparian areas by predators, scavengers, and water flow (Ben-David et al. 1998, Gende et al. 2002)." (1-2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: soils, plants, invertebrates
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon-derived nutrients have been identified in soils, plants, and invertebrates in riparian areas through stable isotope analysis, showing that these nutrients cycle through terrestrial ecosystems (Reimchen et al. 2002, Bartz and Naiman 2005)." (2)
Benefit_6:
ESB: terrestrial plants
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Furthermore, a salmon carcass transfer experiment found direct effects of salmon-derived nutrients on the isotopic composition of terrestrial plants (Hocking and Reynolds 2012)" (2)
Benefit_7:
ESB: riparian trees and plants, birds
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " Examples of salmon subsidy linkages include increased growth rates of riparian trees (Helfield and Naiman 2001, Reimchen and Fox 2013, Quinn et al. 2018), increased bird abundance and diversity (Wagner and Reynolds 2019), and shifts in riparian plant community composition toward lower diversity and higher densities of nitrophilic species (Hocking and Reynolds 2011)." (2)
Benefit_8:
ESB: conifers, nitrophilic plants
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Studies have shown that salmonderived nutrients correlate with increased conifer tree growth (Helfield and Naiman 2001, Reimchen and Fox 2013, Quinn et al. 2018) and stomatal density of nitrophilic plants (van den Top et al. 2018)." (2)
Benefit_9:
ESB: First Nations
ESP: salmon via salmonberry
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmonberry... is a culturally important plant to many First Nations people and is known as Gˆ ul ´ ̓ali by the ´Ha´ıɫzaqv (Heiltsuk) First Nation." (4)
Benefit_10:
ESB: First Nation researchers
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We derived salmon densities for each of the 14 streams using multiple years of count data from JDR’s research group, Fisheries and Oceans Canada, and the Ha´ıɫzaqv (Heiltsuk) First Nation." (4-5)
Benefit_11:
ESB: salmonberry
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: ' As predicted, we found a significant positive relationship between the number of fruits produced per shrub and salmon density (Fig. 3A)." (6)
Benefit_12:
ESB: salmonberry
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We estimate that an increase in salmon density by one standard deviation above the average (8.8 kg salmon per meter of stream) would amount to approximately 23% more salmonberry fruits per shrub." (6)
Benefit_13:
ESB: salmonberry
ESP: spawning chum salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Chum salmon density had a strong, positive relationship with the number of fruits produced per shrub, while pink salmon density showed no effect (Fig. 4A, B). Likewise, chum density was a moderately important predictor of fruit count (RVI = 0.76), while pink salmon was not important (RVI = 0.30)." (7)
Benefit_14:
ESB: salmonberry
ESP: chum spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "We estimate that an increase in chum salmon density by one standard deviation above the average (6.8 kg chum per meter of stream) would amount to approximately 31% more salmonberry fruits per shrub." (7)

Full_citation: Muñoz, N., Reid, B., Correa, C., Neff, B., & Reynolds, J. (2021). Non‐native Chinook salmon add nutrient subsidies and functional novelty to Patagonian streams. Freshwater Biology, 66(3), 495-508.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Are nutrients from introduced Chinook subsidizing algae in historically Nitrogen-poor Patagonian streams?
Location: Patagonia region of South America, Aysen province, southern Chile
Essential_notes: -Main takeaway: "These subsidies represent a novel resource linkage between marine and freshwater ecosystems in Patagonia, with non-native salmon contributing marine-derived nutrients to systems in which nutrients have historically only flowed downstream, from stream to sea. By performing a novel function in these invaded systems, salmon in Patagonia are likely to have ecological impacts (Ricciardi & Atkinson, 2004; Ricciardi et al., 2013; Vitousek, 1990)." (503)
Benefit_1:
ESB: Algae
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "Using spatial and temporal variation in the presence of salmon among multiple streams and across two spawning seasons, we found strong evidence of salmon-subsidised algae in three out of four streams examined that have spawning salmon populations." (495)
Benefit_2:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "The biofilm of subsidised streams had enriched stable isotopic ratios of nitrogen and carbon, indicating that marine-derived nutrients were incorporated by biofilms. This nutrient uptake translated into increased algal biomass and percent of total biofilm biomass composed of algae, indicating that the incorporation of marine-derived nutrients stimulated autotrophic production of biomass." (495)
Benefit_3:
ESB: Patagonia stream ecosystems
ESP: introduced Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "These results indicate that Chinook salmon have bridged the historical gap between productive marine ecosystems and nutrient-poor stream ecosystems in Patagonia." (495)
Benefit_4:
ESB: collector and shredder invertebrates, stream fishes
ESP: carcasses, eggs
Sentence describing benefit: "Direct consumption of salmon carcasses increases the biomass of collector and shredder invertebrates (Chaloner & Wipfli, 2002; Lessard & Merritt, 2006), and consumption of salmon eggs increases the biomass of a variety of stream fishes (Armstrong et al., 2010; Bailey & Moore, 2020; Bentley et al., 2012; Hermann et al., 2020; Scheuerell et al., 2007; Swain et al., 2014)." (496)
Benefit_5:
ESB: terrestrial insects, soils, spruce trees, riparian plants
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Carcasses that are deposited in the riparian zone are heavily consumed by terrestrial insects (Hocking & Reimchen, 2002) and cause soils to accumulate nitrogen, affecting the composition of riparian plant assemblages (Hocking & Reynolds, 2011; Morris & Stanford, 2011) and enhancing the growth of spruce trees (Quinn et al., 2018). " (496)
Benefit_6:
ESB: gulls, subtidal invertebrates
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Some carcasses are flushed downstream into estuaries, where they are scavenged by gulls and subtidal invertebrates (Field & Reynolds, 2013; Reimchen, 2017)." (496)
Benefit_7:
ESB: biofilm, macroinvertebrates
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, biofilm biomass and macroinvertebrate density are 15 and 25 times higher, respectively, in a salmon subsidised stream in Alaska relative to a non-subsidised stream (Wipfli et al., 1998)." (496)
Benefit_8:
ESB: mayflies and insectivorous birds
ESP: biofilm via salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "In British Columbia, salmon spawner density among streams is positively associated with the abundance of biofilm-grazing mayflies (Verspoor et al., 2011) and insectivorous forest birds (Wagner & Reynolds, 2019)" (496)
Benefit_9:
ESB: stream primary production
ESP: Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, low densities of spawning Chinook salmon (<0.001 spawners/m2) caused a 46% increase in the gross primary production of three streams in Washington, U.S.A. (Benjamin et al., 2016), whereas moderate densities of spawning sockeye (Oncorhynchus nerka) salmon (>0.6 spawners/m2) caused a 72% reduction in gross primary production in three streams in Alaska (Holtgrieve & Schindler, 2011). " (496-7)
Benefit_10:
ESB: biofilm
ESP: spawners
Sentence describing benefit: "As predicted, biofilm δ13C and δ15N were significantly enriched in the downstream (Impact) sites of each salmon-bearing stream relative to upstream (Control) sites, and they were not different between sites in the salmon-free reference stream (i.e. Emperador; Figure 2a, b)." (501)
Benefit_11:
ESB: algae
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " In three streams (El Toqui, Jaramillo, and Huemules), we found evidence that marine-derived nutrients were incorporated by biofilms and increased the biomass of algae (chl a; including cyanobacteria) as well as the proportion of biofilm biomass that is composed of algae (chl a %). We also found that total biofilm biomass (AFDM) and chl a were strongly and positively associated in all salmon-bearing streams and, in the BACI study, streams had higher chl a, AFDM, and chl a % in the autumn (after spawning) relative to the summer" (503)
Benefit_12:
ESB: Great Lakes algae
ESP: introduced Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Such influence of environmental conditions on responses to spawning salmon has been observed in the catchments of the Laurentian Great Lakes, where Chinook salmon have similarly established non-native populations. There, some streams are nutrient-limited and have increased algal biomass in reaches downstream of Chinook spawning relative to upstream (Schuldt & Hershey, 1995), whereas other streams have negligible subsidy effects and strong disturbance effects in salmon-impacted reaches, probably due to high background nutrient levels and small substrate sizes (Janetski et al., 2014)" (504)
Benefit_13:
ESB: algae
ESP: spawners 
Sentence describing benefit: ". Indeed, 6 months after salmon spawning in British Columbia, algal biomass is higher in salmon-impacted stream reaches (Harding et al., 2014)." (505)
Benefit_14:
ESB: recreational fisheries, tourism industry
ESP: introduced Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "At the same time, recreational fisheries in Patagonia are a key contributor to the regional tourism industry, and Chinook have added value to these fisheries." (505)

Full_citation: Dunlop, K., Wipfli, M., Muladal, R., & Wierzbinski, G. (2020). Terrestrial and semi-aquatic scavengers on invasive Pacific pink salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha) carcasses in a riparian ecosystem in northern Norway. Biological Invasions, 23(4), 973-979.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Energy and nutrient transfer from introduced pink salmon to Norweigen streams.
Location: river Vesterelv, Eastern Finnmark, northern Norway
Benefit_1:
ESB: terrestrial ecosystems
ESP: carcasses via scavengers
Sentence describing benefit: "Scavengers feeding on pacific salmon carcasses are important vectors for the transport of marine derived energy and nutrients to terrestrial ecosystems in the Pacific Northwest, North America, where the salmon naturally occur." (973)
Benefit_2:
ESB: birds (Eurasian magpie, hooded crow, common raven, European herring gull, redwing, goosander)
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " Avian scavengers filmed by a camera placed near sites baited with pink salmon carcasses included the Eurasian magpie (Pica pica), hooded crow (Corvus cornix), common raven (Corvus corax), the European herring gull (Larus argentatus), redwing (Turdus iliacus) and goosander (Mergus merganser)." (973)
Benefit_3:
ESB: red foxes
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " However, the largest carcass weight was removed by red foxes (Vulpes vulpes)." (973)
Benefit_4:
ESB: river ecosystem
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Carcasses entering Vesterelv River in 2019 were estimated to provide energy and nutrients to the river ecosystem an order of magnitude lower than in the Pacific Northwest" (973)
Benefit_5:
ESB: North Pacific Rim countries
ESP: Pacific salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon (genus; Oncorhynchus) are an ecological, economic and subsistence resource for countries of the North Pacific Rim (Schoen et al. 2017). Because of their attractiveness as a food and sport fish, they have been introduced far beyond their native geographical range (Groot and Margolis 1991)." (973)
Benefit_6:
ESB: terrestrial and aquatic vertebrates
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: " The consumption of salmon carcasses by terrestrial and aquatic vertebrates in and alongside rivers is well known as a major pathway by which marine derived energy and nutrients (MDN) enter terrestrial and freshwater food webs (Ben-David et al. 1998; Cederholm et al. 1999; Wipfli et al. 2003)." (974)
Benefit_7:
ESB: vertebrates
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Salmon carcasses provide a valuable food source to terrestrial vertebrates (Reimchen 1994). As a result, linkages have been made between the occurrence of Pacific salmon runs and the diversity, abundance (Field and Reynolds 2013; Wilson and Halupka 1995), movement, feeding and reproductive patterns of vertebrates (Ben-David et al. 1997)." (974)
Benefit_8:
ESB: bears, wolves, otter, mink, marten, eagles, vultures, gulls
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Terrestrial vertebrates known to commonly scavenge on Pacific salmon carcasses in rivers in the Pacific Northwest of North America include bears (genus Ursus) (Quinn et al. 2009), wolves (Canis lupus), otter (Enhydra sp.), mink (Neovison vison), marten (Martes sp.) (Cederholm et al. 1989; Ben-David et al. 1997), eagles (Haliaeetus leucocephalus), vultures (Cathartes aura) and gulls (genus Larus) (Christie and Reimchen 2005; Shardlow and Hyatt 2013)." (974)
Benefit_9:
ESB: Eurasian magpie, hooded crow, common raven, European herring gull, redwing
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Five bird species, that included the Eurasian magpie (Pica pica), hooded crow (Corvus cornix), common raven (Corvus corax), the European herring gull (Larus argentatus) and the redwing (Turdus iliacus), attended and fed on the pink salmon carcasses (Fig. 1)." (975)
Benefit_10:
ESB: redwing
ESP: adult and larval insects via carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Redwing were however, most likely to be feeding on the adult or larval insects on the carcasses" (971)
Benefit_11:
ESB: goosander
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "A goosander (Mergus merganser) was captured feeding on the pink salmon carcasses in the river (Fig. 1)." (975)
Benefit_12:
ESB: red foxes
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Red foxes also scavenge on salmon carcasses in Alaska (Gard 1971)." (977)
Benefit_13:
ESB: stream ecosystem
ESP: pink and chum adults
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, Gende et al. (2003) estimated that 5455 kJ m-2 energy, 37 g of nitrogen, 5.3 g of phosphrous was transported to each m2 of stream area in Bear Creek, southeastern Alaska, via chum and pink salmon adults, where these salmon species, and vertebrate predators and scavengers, are abundant." (977)

Full_citation: Price, M., Moore, J., Connors, B., Wilson, K., & Reynolds, J. (2021). Portfolio simplification arising from a century of change in salmon population diversity and artificial production. The Journal of Applied Ecology, 58(7), 1477-1486.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Comparison of sockeye populations now vs. 100 years ago and implications for ecosystems and fisheries.
Essential_notes: -Key note: " However, there is no evidence that the production of enhanced sockeye has reduced the survival of wild populations (Price & Connors, 2014)." (1483)
Benefit_1:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: sockeye salmon diversity
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, the intact habitat complexes of southwestern Alaska support high levels of population richness and asynchrony in sockeye salmon Oncorhynchus nerka that, in turn, stabilize commercial fishery catches (Schindler et al., 2010)." (1478)
Benefit_2:
ESB: commercial fisheries
ESP: sockeye
Sentence describing benefit: ". Commercial fishing for sockeye began at the mouth of the Skeena River in 1877 (Wood, 2008), and a scalecollection programme began in 1912." (1478)
Benefit_3:
ESB: commercial and indigenous fisheries
ESP: sockeye enhancement
Sentence describing benefit: "Enhancement has since increased annual total sockeye returns to 99% of the estimated abundance of one century ago, which has renewed opportunities for commercial marine fisheries and Indigenous fisheries in Babine Lake and the main-stem river downstream." (1483)
Benefit_4:
ESB: Indigenous Peoples
ESP: abundant salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Wild sockeye abundance has declined in all tributaries and headwater regions since the historical era, which—according to oral accounts—has compromised food security for Indigenous Peoples that rely upon these areas for subsistence fisheries (Cleveland et al., 2006; Gottesfeld & Rabnett, 2008)." (1484)
Benefit_5:
ESB: ecosystems
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "Furthermore, these tributaries are important corridors that provision salmon resources to local ecosystems. Such loss in abundance likely constrains foraging opportunities for wildlife dependent on salmon (Deacy et al., 2016), and lessens the overall delivery of salmon-derived nutrients to ecosystems (Gende et al., 2002), which can affect a large number of species (Walsh et al., 2020)." (1484)
