Full_citation: Moravek, J., Clipp, H., Good, T., & Kiffney, P. (2021). Effects of subsidies from small anadromous Pacific salmon populations on stream and riparian food webs are mediated by channel gradient. Freshwater Science, 40(1), 1-20.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Effect of salmon reintroduction to habitat following installation of fish passage facility.
Essential_notes: -Main takeaway: "We found that channel gradient was a key driver of observed biotic variation through its effects on channel morphology and complexity, factors that influence biotic assemblages and ecosystem processes" (1)
Benefit_1:
ESB: macroinvertebrates
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: ". The BA and reach-scale analyses both indicated that salmon biomass inputs were associated with increases in aquatic macroinvertebrate taxa richness and the densities of 2 primary consumers (Glossosoma spp. and Chironomidae larvae)." (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: rainbow trout, sculpin
ESP: adult salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Stable isotope analysis indicated that adult salmon subsidies were also associated with dietary changes in pelagic-foraging predators (the non-anadromous resident Rainbow Trout Oncorhynchus mykiss Walbaum, 1792) and benthic-foraging sculpin (Cottus spp.)." (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: macroinvertebrates, juvenile coho
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, the addition of salmon carcasses (0.6 kg/m2) to flow-through stream mesocosms increased benthic macroinvertebrate density, drift rates, and body size, as well as summer growth of juvenile Coho (Kiffney et al. 2014), with more modest impacts during autumn and winter (Cram et al. 2011, Kiffney et al. 2014)." (2)
Benefit_4:
ESB: macroinvertebrates, stream-resident fish
ESP: carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Stable isotope analysis has shown increased assimilation of marine-derived C and N by macroinvertebrates and fishes in experimental streams, indicating that salmon carcasses represent a key energetic pathway for the Cedar River food web (Kiffney et al. 2014, 2018a)" (2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: Dicosmoecus
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "At the individual level, Dicosmoecus growth rate was 50% higher post-recolonization." (9)
Benefit_6:
ESB: Chironomids, macroinvertebrates
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "At the population level, Chironomidae larvae density (361%), EPT density (328%), and total macroinvertebrate density (31%) on tiles were higher after salmon recolonization. At the assemblage level, EPT richness (57%) and total taxa richness (88%) were higher post-recolonization." (9)
Benefit_7:
ESB: Glossosoma, Chironomids
ESP: adult Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: " Supporting our hypothesis, the density of Glossosoma (r 5 0.87, p =0.01) and Chironomidae (r 5 0.84, p 5 0.02) larvae strongly positively covaried with adult Chinook inputs. For example, Glossosoma and Chironomidae densities in CR1, where adult Chinook inputs peaked, were 2.3- and 2.6-fold higher, respectively, than the overall reach average (110.9 no./m2 for Glossosoma, 1273 no./m2 for Chironomidae)" (10)
Benefit_8:
ESB: Macroinvertebrates
ESP: adult Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Macroinvertebrate taxa richness increased with adult Chinook inputs (r =0.58, p 5 0.2), which also supports our hypothesis." (10)
Benefit_9:
ESB: riparian birds
ESP: Chinook salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "Total riparian bird relative density (r =0.46, p 5 0.3; Fig. 6D) and diversity (r 5 0.82, p 5 0.02; Fig. 6F) positively covaried with Chinook Salmon inputs." (10)
Benefit_10:
ESB: spiders, Tetragnathidae
ESP: adult Chinook
Sentence describing benefit: "Specifically, total spider density weakly but positively correlated with adult Chinook inputs (r =0.23, p =0.6; Fig. 6A), whereas Tetragnathidae density displayed a somewhat stronger (r 5 0.59, p 5 0.2) association (Fig. 6B)" (10)

Full_citation: Kieran, C., Obrist, D., Muñoz, N., Hanly, P., & Reynolds, J. (2021). Links between fluctuations in sockeye salmon abundance and riparian forest productivity identified by remote sensing. Ecosphere (Washington, D.C), 12(8), N/a.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: 36 year time series to study associations between salmon abundance and forest greenness.
Location: lower Adams River, British Columbia, Canada
Benefit_1:
ESB: riparian vegetation
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "We found that variation in forest greenness was consistently explained best by models including dominant cohort year, whereas models lacking an index of salmon abundance were the lowest-ranked. Greenness of riparian vegetation increased by an average of 0.015 NDVI units (approximately 1%) in the summer after a dominant cohort return, and this effect on greenness persisted into the subsequent fall (11–13 months after spawning)." (1)
Benefit_2:
ESB: forests/plants
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: " These results suggest that forests respond to cyclical variation in salmon abundance and that overwinter storage of marine-derived nutrients within catchments allows plants to capitalize on these nutrients in the following growing season. " (1)
Benefit_3:
ESB: FW + forest ecosystems
ESP: spawning salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "The salmon spawning migrations of Pacific North America offer a unique example of mass resource transport across ecosystem boundaries, with hundreds of metric tons of marine-derived nitrogen and phosphorus transported into inland freshwater systems and surrounding forest ecosystems each year (Gresh et al. 2000)." (1)
Benefit_4:
ESB: FW + riparian ecosystems
ESP: gametes, excretion, carcasses
Sentence describing benefit: "Pacific salmon (Oncorhynchus spp.) accrue up to 99% of their body mass in the ocean before they return to freshwater ecosystems to spawn and die (Quinn 2005), delivering marine-derived nutrients to aquatic and riparian ecosystems in the form of gametes, excretion, and carcasses." (1-2)
Benefit_5:
ESB: riparian plants, terrestrial insects, forest birds
ESP: salmon
Sentence describing benefit: "These pulses of nutrients influence the dynamics of riparian ecosystems, where salmon alter the composition of riparian plant assemblages (Hocking and Reynolds 2011, Morris and Stanford 2011), increase the growth rate of riparian trees (Helfield and Naiman 2001, Reimchen and Fox 2013, Quinn et al. 2018), are heavily consumed by terrestrial insects (Hocking and Reimchen 2006), and increase the density of forest birds (Field and Reynolds 2013, Wagner and Reynolds 2019)." (2)
Benefit_6:
ESB: riparian plants
ESP: salmon MDN
Sentence describing benefit: "For example, riparian plants beside salmon streams have increased amounts of foliar 15N compared to those beside streams without salmon (Bilby et al. 1996, Bartz and Naiman 2005, Nagasaka et al. 2006)." (2)
Benefit_7:
ESB: riparian plants
ESP: pink and chum
Sentence describing benefit: "This study found a positive relationship between NDVI in summer months and the combined abundance of pink (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha) and chum (Oncorhynchus keta) salmon among streams in the central coast of British Columbia (BC), Canada, as well as biennial increases in summer NDVI that corresponded with the two-year cycle of pink salmon returns to the lower Fraser River over an 18-yr time series. These results suggest that nutrient enrichment from pink and chum salmon positively influences riparian productivity in the summer after spawning and that this influence is detectable from space" (3)

Sentence describing benefit: "Using the longest time series to date to test for effects of spawning salmon on forest productivity, our study provides evidence that riparian forests respond to cyclical pulses of salmon-derived nutrients and that this response can be identified with remotely sensed data." Full_citation: Rammell, N., Dennert, A., Ernst, C., & Reynolds, J. (2021). Effects of spawning Pacific salmon on terrestrial invertebrates: Insects near spawning habitat are isotopically enriched with nitrogen‐15 but display no differences in body size. Ecology and Evolution, 11(18), 12728-12738.
Briefly_what_is_this_paper_about?: Authors study whether salmon MDN uptake by terrestrial insects translates into changes in body size and percent Nitrogen content.
Location: Heiltsuk first Nation, Kunsoot River, central coast of British Columbia near Bella Bella
Essential_notes: -Main takeaway: "We found elevated δ15N in both the soil and the bodies of herbivorous insects near a salmon-bearing river. Despite this enrichment, we did not find evidence of improved insect body condition; insect δ15N, percent body nitrogen, and distance from the river did not explain patterns of insect body size" (12734)
